Object entry information:
is allowed to rotate at about 20 turns per min. The well is 161 ft. deep, and from 16 to 20 turns of the wheel, according to the level at which the water is standing, are required to bring the bucket to the surface. Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 2.
Object name: MODEL OF A HORSE GEAR AND CRUSHING ROLL.
Maker/Donor: Watt Collection.
Date of creation: 1876.
Object entry information: This horse gear is in the form of a horizontal lever turning on a vertical axis. A projecting stud on the upper side of the lever forms a crank-pin from which a connecting rod is carried to a swinging lever. From this lever two links proceed to the axle of a vertical edge runner, which can be rolled in the fixed trough. The trough has a grid bottom through which the crushed material escapes when sufficiently reduced.
Object/Inventory number: 1876-1249—S.M. 825.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 3.
Object name: MODEL OF HORSE GEAR. (Scale 1: 8.)
Maker/Donor: Lent by Messrs. J. L. Larkworthy & Co.
Date of creation: 1891.
Object entry information: This shows a very general form of machine for applying the power of a horse to the driving of light machinery, such as chaff-cutters, small pumps, etc.; but although larger gears are made to transmit the power of two or four horses, they are not much used in this country when the power required approaches that of a small steam engine.
The machine has a pole attached to the vertical axis of a bevel wheel of 103 teeth, gearing into a bevel pinion of 12 teeth, whose rotation is transmitted by a shaft coupled by universal joints to multiplying spur gear placed outside the circular horse track. The multiplying gear consists of a spur wheel of 76 teeth driving a pinion of 17 teeth, to the shaft of which a pulley is attached for further transmitting the power by belting. The horse in going once round the track causes the pulley to make 38.3 rev., and when walking at 2.5 miles per hour in a path 25 ft. in diam., drives the pulley at 108 rev. per min.
Object/Inventory number: 1891-152—19,241.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 4.
Object name: HORSE GEAR.
Maker/Donor: Lent by Messrs. J. Crowley & Co.
Date of creation: 1888.
Object entry information: This is a small and compact form of gear patented in 1879 and intended for use with a pony. The slow speed of the vertical shaft turned by the animal is multiplied 30.2 times so as to give higher speed to the horizontal shaft from which machinery is to be driven. To the bracket that holds the pole is attached a short horizontal shaft, carrying a bevel wheel of 31 teeth and a bevel pinion of 22 teeth. The pinion gears into a horizontal bevel ring that forms part of the framing, and a bevel pinion of 16 teeth on the high-speed shaft. The bevel wheel gears with a bevel pinion of 22 teeth on a vertical axis in the centre, and this pinion carries gears with a pinion of 16 teeth on the high-speed shaft. The motion is transmitted through two Hooke's joints to the external driving pulley, a pawl gear preventing accidental rotation in the wrong direction.
Object/Inventory number: 1888-391.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 5.
Object name: MODEL OF INCLINED-PLANE HORSE GEAR. (Scale 1: 5.)
Maker/Donor: Made by Mons. J. Digeon.
Date of creation: 1892.
Object entry information: A wooden platform, constructed as an endless belt, is supported on rollers, and at each extremity passes round a polygonal pulley. It is inclined at an angle of 13 deg., giving a rise of 1 in 4.5. The horse stands on the sloping platform, which is set in motion by the component of the horse's weight acting parallel to the platform, less the frictional losses, which are considerable. The horse's head is haltered to a bar in front, so that he is compelled to walk as the platform recedes.
Object/Inventory number: 1892-92—19,250.

Object/Inventory number: 1915-317—S.M. 1948; 1920-84

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 2.
Object name: MODEL OF A HORSE GEAR AND CRUSHING ROLL.
Maker/Donor: Watt Collection.
Date of creation: 1876.
Object entry information: This horse gear is in the form of a horizontal lever turning on a vertical axis. A projecting stud on the upper side of the lever forms a crank-pin from which a connecting rod is carried to a swinging lever. From this lever two links proceed to the axle of a vertical edge runner, which can be rolled in the fixed trough. The trough has a grid bottom through which the crushed material escapes when sufficiently reduced.
Object/Inventory number: 1876-1249—S.M. 825.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 3.
Object name: MODEL OF HORSE GEAR. (Scale 1: 8.)
Maker/Donor: Lent by Messrs. J. L. Larkworthy & Co.
Date of creation: 1891.
Object entry information: This shows a very general form of machine for applying the power of a horse to the driving of light machinery, such as chaff-cutters, small pumps, etc.; but although larger gears are made to transmit the power of two or four horses, they are not much used in this country when the power required approaches that of a small steam engine.
The machine has a pole attached to the vertical axis of a bevel wheel of 103 teeth, gearing into a bevel pinion of 12 teeth, whose rotation is transmitted by a shaft coupled by universal joints to multiplying spur gear placed outside the circular horse track. The multiplying gear consists of a spur wheel of 76 teeth driving a pinion of 17 teeth, to the shaft of which a pulley is attached for further transmitting the power by belting. The horse in going once round the track causes the pulley to make 38.3 rev., and when walking at 2.5 miles per hour in a path 25 ft. in diam., drives the pulley at 108 rev. per min.
Object/Inventory number: 1891-152—19,241.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 4.
Object name: HORSE GEAR.
Maker/Donor: Lent by Messrs. J. Crowley & Co.
Date of creation: 1888.
Object entry information: This is a small and compact form of gear patented in 1879 and intended for use with a pony. The slow speed of the vertical shaft turned by the animal is multiplied 30.2 times so as to give higher speed to the horizontal shaft from which machinery is to be driven. To the bracket that holds the pole is attached a short horizontal shaft, carrying a bevel wheel of 31 teeth and a bevel pinion of 22 teeth. The pinion gears into a horizontal bevel ring that forms part of the framing, and a bevel pinion of 16 teeth on the high-speed shaft. The bevel wheel gears with a bevel pinion of 22 teeth on a vertical axis in the centre, and this pinion carries gears with a pinion of 16 teeth on the high-speed shaft. The motion is transmitted through two Hooke's joints to the external driving pulley, a pawl gear preventing accidental rotation in the wrong direction.
Object/Inventory number: 1888-391.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 5.
Object name: MODEL OF INCLINED-PLANE HORSE GEAR. (Scale 1: 5.)
Maker/Donor: Made by Mons. J. Digeon.
Date of creation: 1892.
Object entry information: A wooden platform, constructed as an endless belt, is supported on rollers, and at each extremity passes round a polygonal pulley. It is inclined at an angle of 13 deg., giving a rise of 1 in 4.5. The horse stands on the sloping platform, which is set in motion by the component of the horse's weight acting parallel to the platform, less the frictional losses, which are considerable. The horse's head is haltered to a bar in front, so that he is compelled to walk as the platform recedes.
Object/Inventory number: 1892-92—19,250.

Object name: DRAWINGS OF WINDMILLS. (Scales 1: 32 and 1: 24.)
Maker/Donor: Contributed by Hyde Clarke, Esq.
Date of creation: 1866.
Object entry information: The sectional drawing, dated 1802, shows a four-armed windmill, driving two pairs of millstones, a dressing machine, and a sack hoist. Beneath the mill is a nearly horizontal water-wheel, connected by bevel gear with the main
Object/Inventory number: N/A
title: Model of inclined plane horse gear
description: Model, scale 1:5, of inclined plane horse gear by J. Digeon, 1892

Maker/Donor: Stephen Hooper
Object entry information: shaft, and probably provided as an alternative source of power. The cap of the mill is carried on friction wheels, and is automatically slewed by a small bevel gear which works with a worm that gears into a ring of large arms. The regulating arrangement of this mill was patented in 1789 by Stephen Hooper, of Margate, and forms an early instance of the application of the centrifugal governor. Each sail is made up of small elements wound on separate rollers. These elements yield as the velocity of the windmill increases, centrifugal action causes these elements to be rolled up against the pull of a weighted spiral drum or fusee within the mill. Hooper also described a conical pendulum governor which, when the speed increased, would move a weighted lever connected with the friction wheels, and so stop the action of the mill. The sectional elevation, dated 1804, shows the construction of a four-armed windmill driving a sugar-cane mill, probably for squeezing the juice from sugar-cane. The cap of the mill is carried on friction wheels, and is turned by a large hand-wheel provided with a worm that gears into a spur ring secured to the top of the tower; by these means the mill can be adjusted as the direction of the wind alters.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 7.
Object name: MODEL OF PUMPING WINDMILL. (Scale 1: 12.)
Maker/Donor: Messrs. J. Warner & Sons (Lent)
Date of creation: 1888.
Object entry information: In this windmill, patented by Mr. F. Warner in 1868, the vanes yield as the pressure of the wind increases, and thus automatically adjust themselves to suit its force. The mill has 24 radial vanes, mounted between two rings, and each pivoted about its front edge so that the angle which it presents to the wind may vary. The ends of the pivots are connected with another ring which is attached to a rod running through the centre of the axle, and connected with a balance weight which keeps adjusting the vanes to such an angle as to make the resultant pressure on them constant. A tail is provided for setting the wheel of vanes in a direction parallel to the wind. The mill is mounted on a wooden tower and is arranged to drive a small pump from an eccentric on the axle. It is stopped by turning the vanes edgeways to the wind by means of a rod attached to the weighted lever.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1888–298, 19,244.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 8.
Object name: MODEL OF PUMPING WINDMILL. (Scale 1: 12.)
Maker/Donor: Messrs. T. McKenzie & Sons (Lent)
Date of creation: 1888.
Object entry information: This form of self-regulating windmill was introduced by Mr. D. Halliday in 1877. The vanes are arranged radially in six groups forming sectors of the complete disc. The sectors are pivoted at the middle on axes forming chords of a circle, and levers on them are connected with a sliding sleeve on the axle, which is in turn connected with a weighted lever normally holding the vanes parallel with the wind. The angle of the sectors is adjusted by means of a lever and a rope passing over a pulley and attached to the weighted lever. The mill is directed by a tail, and is mounted on a tower. In the model it drives a pump, at the ground level, from a crank on the axle, but the machine is also used for driving light machinery by gearing and shafting.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1888–297, 19,382.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 9.
Object name: MODELS OF WOODEN WATER-WHEELS. Made at Freiberg, Saxony. (Scale 1: 10.)
Maker/Donor: N/A
Date of creation: 1895.
Object entry information: These show various types of timber water-wheels, together with details of the joints employed in their construction. In the "current" wheel the radial blades dip into a running stream, and utilise only a small proportion of the energy of the water. The other three models are forms of overshot water-wheel; one has a closed sole plate, and so is unable to fill or empty its buckets rapidly through the lack of ventilation; the other two represent wheels with ventilated buckets.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1895–127 to 130, 19,363.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 10.
Object name: MODEL OF WATER-WHEEL. Watt Collection, 1876.
Maker/Donor: Watt Collection
Date of creation: 1876.
Object entry information: This is an overshot wheel with the usual timber shaft, but on one side the wheel is provided with a toothed ring from which the power can be taken off at once at the highest speed, without transmission through the main gudgeon. The teeth are external to the rim; in later wheels internal teeth were adopted, and this constituted a still further improvement.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1876–1351, S.M. 863.

Object entry information: This form of self-regulating windmill was introduced by Mr. D. Halliday in 1877. The vanes are arranged radially in six groups forming sectors of the complete disc. The sectors are pivoted at the middle on axes forming chords of a circle, and levers on them are connected with a sliding sleeve on the axle, which is in turn connected with a weighted lever normally holding the vanes parallel with the wind. The angle of the sectors is adjusted by means of a lever and a rope passing over a pulley and attached to the weighted lever. The mill is directed by a tail, and is mounted on a tower. In the model it drives a pump, at the ground level, from a crank on the axle, but the machine is also used for driving light machinery by gearing and shafting.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1888–297, 19,382.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 9.
Object name: MODELS OF WOODEN WATER-WHEELS. Made at Freiberg, Saxony. (Scale 1: 10.)
Maker/Donor: N/A
Date of creation: 1895.
Object entry information: These show various types of timber water-wheels, together with details of the joints employed in their construction. In the "current" wheel the radial blades dip into a running stream, and utilise only a small proportion of the energy of the water. The other three models are forms of overshot water-wheel; one has a closed sole plate, and so is unable to fill or empty its buckets rapidly through the lack of ventilation; the other two represent wheels with ventilated buckets.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1895–127 to 130, 19,363.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 10.
Object name: MODEL OF WATER-WHEEL. Watt Collection, 1876.
Maker/Donor: Watt Collection
Date of creation: 1876.
Object entry information: This is an overshot wheel with the usual timber shaft, but on one side the wheel is provided with a toothed ring from which the power can be taken off at once at the highest speed, without transmission through the main gudgeon. The teeth are external to the rim; in later wheels internal teeth were adopted, and this constituted a still further improvement.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1876–1351, S.M. 863.
title: Overshot waterwheel, made in the 1800s
description: model of overshot waterwheel on wooden stand (Watt Collection no. 1813)

Maker/Donor: Lent by Messrs. Whitmore & Binyon.
Object entry information: In this type of wheel the water is laid on at about the level of the axis. The water acts by gravity, and the buckets are so shaped as to retain the water as long as possible during their descent. To ensure rapid filling and emptying, the buckets are ventilated, i.e., a narrow space is left between each on the inner side or sole. The construction of the wheel is wholly in iron ; wrought iron buckets are bolted between two cast-iron spiders with one or more intermediate cast-iron supports, according to the width. The power is taken off by spur gearing, made in segments, bolted to the rim, and is not transmitted through the axle, as in older practice, thus permitting considerable reduction in weight. The sluice gate is controlled by rack and pinion and hand gear. The efficiency of breast wheels is about 55 per cent.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 12
Object name: MODEL OF PONCELET'S WATER-WHEEL. (Scale 1: 10.)
Maker/Donor: Made by MM. Regnard Frères.
Date of creation: 1891.
Object entry information: Smeaton improved the undershot wheel, but it was Gen. J. V. Poncelet who, in 1824, brought it to the high state of efficiency illustrated by the model. The characteristic features of his design are the backwardly curved floats and the absence of a sole plate. The water is projected on to the wheel buckets tangentially, at the periphery, through a sluice inclined at an angle varying between 40° and 60° to the horizontal, according to the diameter of the wheel and to the effective head of water. The sluice gate is operated by a hand-wheel, spur gear and rack. The buckets are proportioned so that the water enters without shock, with the velocity due to the head, and flows up the vanes, until brought to rest by gravity, when it falls, exerting downward pressure. The water is discharged from the floats with but little remaining forward velocity. In wheels of this type, however the power produced by the weight of the water is negligible compared with that due to its momentum. The floats are inclined on the upstream side about 30°, and the radius of the bucket is usually one-eighth the diameter of the wheel. Owing to its slow speed and cumbersome gearing the Poncelet wheel has been displaced by the low-fall turbine. The effective head of water should not exceed 5.5 ft. ; the maximum efficiency is 65 per cent.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1891–109, 19,386.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 13
Object name: MODEL OF HIGH BREAST WATER-WHEEL. (Scale 1: 24.)
Maker/Donor: N/A
Date of creation: Received 1857.
Object entry information: This arrangement was adopted at Wheal Friendship, near Tavistock, for mine drainage. The power of the wheel was transmitted through cranks at 180°, and therefore counterbalanced, to two lengths of horizontal rods coupled to bell-crank levers at the pits, where six plunger pumps were worked. Balance bobs arranged in pits behind the wheel were used to compensate the weight of the pump rods. The wheel was 51 ft. diam. by 10 ft. face and had 180 buckets built of wrought iron. The axle was a hollow iron casting with flanged ends, but the arms were of wood. The wheel made 5 revs. per min. In 1841 it was reported to have given an overall efficiency of 69 per cent. (See Proc. Inst. Civ. Eng., 1842, ii, 97.)
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1857–225.

Catalogue number: 15.
Object name: MODEL OF PELTON OR “ HURDY-GURDY ” WATER-WHEEL. (Scale 1: 4.)
Maker/Donor: Lent by the Sandycroft Foundry and Engine Works Co.,
Date of creation: 1890
Object entry information: This is a form of impulse turbine much used in mining districts and other situations in which a considerable head is available, as its high speed and great power render it a most convenient motor, while its extreme simplicity minimises the risk of failure. The early form of the machine consisted of a wheel having radial floats or paddles projecting from the upon which a rapid stream of water was directed by a shoot; reversal or stop of water in such cases were both effected by moving the shoot—the supply generally far exceeding the power required. Wheels with concave vanes were in use before the year 1737, and Poncelet in 1827 proved their superiority over those with flat vanes, but it was considerably later that in the mining districts of California the practical development of this important form of turbine was chiefly effected. The original “ miner’s wheels ” there employed were shrouded and had vanes made as triangular prisms; they had an efficiency of about 40 per cent., but were subsequently improved by the adoption of cup-shaped vanes. In 1874, however, Mr. J. Moore improved these vanes by forming them with a central wedge-shaped ridge which split the jet, while in 1878 Mr. L. A. Pelton independently arrived at this double construction of cup, and to him the commercial introduction and development of the Pelton wheel is chiefly due. The model has a central wheel of cast iron, to the rim of which are secured twenty-eight double buckets of gunmetal 2.3 in. wide, the over-all diameter of the revolving parts being 20 in. The shaft is carried in three bearings, near the central one of which a screen or partition would be fitted to prevent water splashing upon the belt pulley by which the power obtained is transmitted. The supply water, which is usually brought through light pipes of sheet steel is, after passing through a sluice valve, led by a conical pipe to a removable discharge nozzle, so that by changing the nozzle the load on the wheel may be altered without seriously reducing the efficiency of the motor. Each bucket or cup consists of two semi-cylindrical portions, uniting in a central ridge which divides the entering water jet, so that each half slides round the inside of its cup and has its motion reversed before escaping at the opposite edge* by running the wheel at a circumferential speed slightly less than half the velocity with which the water issues from the nozzle; the whole of the energy being completely transferred from the cups, dead water is discharged from the wheel. To facilitate the escape of the dead water from the wheel, the buckets are given a forward inclination; the wheel must in all cases be above the level of the tail race. (* See Engineering, 1920, CIX., p. 851.)
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1890-69, 19,362.
***
Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 16.
Object name: ENCLOSED PELTON MOTOR.
Maker/Donor: Presented by P. Pitman, Esq.,
Date of creation: 1903.
Object entry information: This is a small example of the impulse turbine known as the Pelton wheel. It is supplied with pressure water from the domestic mains or hydraulic supply, and it is enclosed in a watertight casing to render it suitable for driving small machinery within a building. The used water is led away by a pipe from the bottom of the case. The wheel runner is a cast-iron disc to which are riveted twenty Pelton buckets of bronze, which are given a backward rake to facilitate the discharge of the used water. The water is delivered as a horizontal jet, while the wheel while water falling on the opposite side is fixed a baffle plate to prevent the used water falling on the wheel and thereby absorbing power. The power developed by the motor is varied by interchanging the nozzles, of which there are three sizes, or by the removal of a box nut, or a needle regulating nozzle could be substituted. The stop valve should remain fully open under all circumstances. The wheel shaft is carried in bearings bolted to the casing, and is fitted with a pulley for belt transmission of the power given off. To facilitate examination of the wheel one side of the case is made removable.
Object/Inventory number: N/A

Object name: ENCLOSED PELTON MOTOR.
Maker/Donor: Presented by P. Pitman, Esq.,
Date of creation: 1903.
Object entry information: This is a small example of the impulse turbine known as the Pelton wheel. It is supplied with pressure water from the domestic mains or hydraulic supply, and it is enclosed in a watertight casing to render it suitable for driving small machinery within a building. The used water is led away by a pipe from the bottom of the case. The wheel runner is a cast-iron disc to which are riveted twenty Pelton buckets of bronze, which are given a backward rake to facilitate the discharge of the used water. The water is delivered as a horizontal jet, while the wheel while water falling on the opposite side is fixed a baffle plate to prevent the used water falling on the wheel and thereby absorbing power. The power developed by the motor is varied by interchanging the nozzles, of which there are three sizes, or by the removal of a box nut, or a needle regulating nozzle could be substituted. The stop valve should remain fully open under all circumstances. The wheel shaft is carried in bearings bolted to the casing, and is fitted with a pulley for belt transmission of the power given off. To facilitate examination of the wheel one side of the case is made removable.
Object/Inventory number: N/A
title: Model of Pelton buckets on a Hurdy Gurdy Water Wheel
description: Model (scale 1:4) of Pelton buckets on a Hurdy Gurdy Water Wheel with sluice valve and driving pulley on timber farming
maker: Sandycroft Foundry and Engine Works Co.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 17.
Object name: PHOTOGRAPH OF MULTIPLE NOZZLE PELTON WHEEL.
Maker/Donor: Presented by P. Pitman, Esq.
Date of creation: 1903.
Object entry information: When speed requirements call for a wheel of small diameter in which it is not possible to obtain sufficient power with one nozzle, two or more nozzles may be used. The jets of water are caused to impinge on the same wheel without conflict so that there is no appreciable loss of efficiency. To obtain high efficiency when there is a fluctuating supply of water, one, or two nozzles only may be employed at a time.
The photograph shows a wheel with three nozzles made in 1902 for driving mining machinery; a feature is the low head of water under which the wheel is operating. The runner is of steel plate secured to the shaft by a cast-iron coupling. The buckets of bronze, 16 in number, are bolted to the rim, their interior surfaces being ground and polished to minimize friction losses. The supply pipe, 24 in. diam., terminates in a chamber to which are bolted three curved pipes, each fitted with a bronze nozzle independently controlled by a gate valve. The shaft runs in ring-oiled bearings mounted on cast-iron A-frames bolted to the bedplate, and to the steel plate splash housing. The power is taken off by a belt. The wheel is 5 ft. pitch diam., and under a head of 60 ft. develops 50 brake h.p. at a speed of 135 r.p.m. The efficiency varied from 75 to 80 per cent. according as one, two or three nozzles were used.
In modern practice not more than two nozzles are employed on one wheel; if more power is required two runners are mounted on the same shaft.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1903–183.

Catalogue number: 18.
Object name: MODEL OF PELTON WHEEL. (Scale 1: 5.)
Maker/Donor: Made by Peter Koch.
Date of creation: 1913.
Object entry information: This represents a tangential impulse turbine or Pelton wheel, made by Messrs. Amme, Giessccke & Konegen, of Brunswick, and embodying features patented by Messrs. V. Gelpke & P. Kugel in 1905 and 1911. Its speed is controlled, under varying load, by a servomotor nozzle regulator actuated by a centrifugal governor, while an automatic relief valve, which comes into action when the nozzles are closed rapidly, prevents a dangerous rise of pressure in the pipe line.
The turbine has a single disc wheel with 16 buckets bolted to its edge, the effective diameter being 24.6 in. ; this is keyed on a shaft supported by ring-oiled bearings which are bolted to the sides of the casing enclosing the wheel. Two variable nozzles are mounted in the casing, at right angles to one another, and the supply pipe has a branch leading to each. Each nozzle consists of a cylindrical casing, to the inner end of which is fitted a sliding convergent tip. At the centre of the nozzle is fixed a spear-shaped rod or needle, the point of which projects through the tip, thus constituting an annular channel through which the water issues ; the needle is so shaped that the water beyond its point forms a solid cylindrical jet. The buckets are ellipsoidal in shape, and are notched at the outer edge, so that they do not cut into the jet until they reach their effective position. The sliding nozzle tips are connected, by links, levers and connecting-rods, with the main piston of the servomotor speed regulator; an oil pressure of 220 lb. per sq. in. acts on one side of this, and opposes the water pressure which acts on the nozzles and tends to keep them fully open. The movements of the servomotor piston are controlled by a piston valve which allows oil to enter or leave the cylinder ; this valve is attached to a centrifugal governor, and it works inside a perforated sleeve connected with the piston, by a roller and incline. As the piston moves, the sleeve moves also and counteracts the movement of the governor valve, thus closing the oil passages, and causing the piston, and with it the nozzles, to take up a definite position corresponding with the position of the governor valve.
The pressure relief valve is fitted to the inlet pipe, and it consists of a sluice valve attached to a trunk piston fitted within an oil cylinder. At the centre of the piston is a long hollow rod which serves as a valve to distribute pressure oil to either end of the cylinder, the oil being led through the rod from an upper reservoir. The rod carries a piston fitting easily within another oil-filled cylinder, which is connected with the servomotor in such a manner that it is positively lifted when the nozzles are closed, but is not affected when they are

Object/Inventory number: N/A
title: Photo print 8" x 6" of Multiple Nozzle Pelton Wheel
description: Photo print 8" x 6" of Multiple Nozzle Pelton Wheel, made in 1902, for driving mining machinery

Object entry information: opened. A sudden closing of the nozzles, and consequent lifting of the cylinder, will raise the valve and thus open the relief valve, while the loose-fitting piston will afterwards allow the valve rod, which is weighted, to fall slowly, and cause the relief valve to close again. The servomotor is mounted on the top of a large tank base, which serves as an oil reservoir, and the pressure is obtained by means of a rotary pump driven by a belt from the turbine shaft; a hand-pump is provided for use when starting. The turbine develops 194 h.p. at 600 r.p.m., using 424 cub. ft. of water per min., under a head of 302 ft. It has an efficiency of over 80 per cent. over a wide range of load. In later practice the nozzle tip is made a fixture and the governor operates a "cut-off" which instantly interposes a deflector between the nozzle and the wheel while slowly advancing the needle till the size of the jet corresponds to the load; the deflector is then brought back to its initial position. This slow movement is vital to obviate any dangerous rise of pressure in the pipe line.

Catalogue number: 19.
Object name: PHOTOGRAPH OF IMPROVED PELTON WHEEL BUCKET.
Maker/Donor: Presented by P. Pitman, Esq., 1923.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: The photograph shows an improved form of bucket, applicable to impulse water-wheels of the Pelton type, in which the dividing wedge or "splitter" is curved in a radial direction with a view of prolonging the time of effective action, i.e., when the bucket is in the best position with its face at right angles to the impinging jet. The buckets shown were fitted to a turbine consisting of two wheels of 4.75 ft. diam., working under a head of 1,010 ft., running at a speed of 450 r.p.m., and developing 1,540 brake h.p. In the adjacent drawing, the plan shows the general lay-out of the bucket, and the sections on lines C D and A B the geometrical construction. (See "Engineering," CIX, 851.)
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1923–648 & 1924–94.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 20.
Object name: PHOTOGRAPH OF ENGRAVING OF BARKER'S MILL, 1767.
Maker/Donor: Received 1915.
Date of creation: 1767
Object entry information: This engraving, taken from Ferguson’s “Mechanics,” 1767, shows a corn mill driven by a reaction turbine of the form proposed by Dr. Barker and put into practice by Dr. J. T. Desaguliers about 1743. A similar arrangement had been used by Hero in his steam turbine or aeolipile about A.D. 50 (see No. 35). The machine consisted of a vertical wooden frame supporting a platform at the top, on which rested the lower and stationary millstone. The upper and movable millstone was attached, passed down through the middle of the frame, and its lower end fitted in a footstep bearing, mounted on a pivoted beam extending across the bottom of the frame. A wide tube surrounded and was fixed to the shaft, and its upper end was furnished with a funnel mouth into which the water was delivered from a supply pipe. The lower end of the tube terminated in two straight, horizontal arms, closed at the ends and each provided with a small orifice, through which the water issued in tangential jets which by their reaction caused the tube and shaft to rotate. The free end of the lower bearing lever was suspended by a long bolt from a bracket on the frame, a nut on the bolt serving to adjust the upper millstone. The mill in this simple form was only made in small sizes, as it entailed a central tube equal in length to the head of water available, and the mass of water in the tube and arms was carried round as useless dead weight. This defect was overcome by M. Mathon de la Cour, who, in 1775, proposed to deliver the water directly to the arms of the mill from the upturned end of a fixed pipe, but this improvement was not put in practice until James Whitelaw used it in 1839 (see No. 21). The hydraulic efficiency of the simple Barker’s mill is about 66 per cent. and the brake efficiency 60 per cent., this being attained when the linear speed of the orifices is about equal to the velocity of the water due to its head.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1915–318.

Object entry information: This is an improved form of the reaction turbine known as Barker’s mill (see No. 20), and was patented by Messrs. J. Whitelaw and J. Stirrat in 1839 and 1841. It was known as the Scotch turbine, and was largely used in the middle of the 19th century, but has now been superseded by more efficient types.

Object name: PHOTOGRAPH OF IMPROVED PELTON WHEEL BUCKET.
Maker/Donor: Presented by P. Pitman, Esq., 1923.
Object entry information: The photograph shows an improved form of bucket, applicable to impulse water-wheels of the Pelton type, in which the dividing wedge or "splitter" is curved in a radial direction with a view of prolonging the time of effective action, i.e., when the bucket is in the best position with its face at right angles to the impinging jet. The buckets shown were fitted to a turbine consisting of two wheels of 4.75 ft. diam., working under a head of 1,010 ft., running at a speed of 450 r.p.m., and developing 1,540 brake h.p. In the adjacent drawing, the plan shows the general lay-out of the bucket, and the sections on lines C D and A B the geometrical construction. (See "Engineering," CIX, 851.)

Object entry information: opened. A sudden closing of the nozzles, and consequent lifting of the cylinder, will raise the valve and thus open the relief valve, while the loose-fitting piston will afterwards allow the valve rod, which is weighted, to fall slowly, and cause the relief valve to close again. The servomotor is mounted on the top of a large tank base, which serves as an oil reservoir, and the pressure is obtained by means of a rotary pump driven by a belt from the turbine shaft; a hand-pump is provided for use when starting. The turbine develops 194 h.p. at 600 r.p.m., using 424 cub. ft. of water per min., under a head of 302 ft. It has an efficiency of over 80 per cent. over a wide range of load. In later practice the nozzle tip is made a fixture and the governor operates a "cut-off" which instantly interposes a deflector between the nozzle and the wheel while slowly advancing the needle till the size of the jet corresponds to the load; the deflector is then brought back to its initial position. This slow movement is vital to obviate any dangerous rise of pressure in the pipe line.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1913–466, S.M. 350–351.

Catalogue number: 20.
Object name: PHOTOGRAPH OF ENGRAVING OF BARKER'S MILL, 1767.
Maker/Donor: Received 1915.
Date of creation: 1767
Object entry information: This engraving, taken from Ferguson’s “Mechanics,” 1767, shows a corn mill driven by a reaction turbine of the form proposed by Dr. Barker and put into practice by Dr. J. T. Desaguliers about 1743. A similar arrangement had been used by Hero in his steam turbine or aeolipile about A.D. 50 (see No. 35). The machine consisted of a vertical wooden frame supporting a platform at the top, on which rested the lower and stationary millstone. The upper and movable millstone was attached, passed down through the middle of the frame, and its lower end fitted in a footstep bearing, mounted on a pivoted beam extending across the bottom of the frame. A wide tube surrounded and was fixed to the shaft, and its upper end was furnished with a funnel mouth into which the water was delivered from a supply pipe. The lower end of the tube terminated in two straight, horizontal arms, closed at the ends and each provided with a small orifice, through which the water issued in tangential jets which by their reaction caused the tube and shaft to rotate. The free end of the lower bearing lever was suspended by a long bolt from a bracket on the frame, a nut on the bolt serving to adjust the upper millstone. The mill in this simple form was only made in small sizes, as it entailed a central tube equal in length to the head of water available, and the mass of water in the tube and arms was carried round as useless dead weight. This defect was overcome by M. Mathon de la Cour, who, in 1775, proposed to deliver the water directly to the arms of the mill from the upturned end of a fixed pipe, but this improvement was not put in practice until James Whitelaw used it in 1839 (see No. 21). The hydraulic efficiency of the simple Barker’s mill is about 66 per cent. and the brake efficiency 60 per cent., this being attained when the linear speed of the orifices is about equal to the velocity of the water due to its head.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1915–318.

title: Photograph of engraving of original form of Barker's Mill
description: Photograph of engraving of original form of Barker's Mill (from Ferguson's Lectures on Mechanics c. 1767)
place: London, Greater London, England, United Kingdom

Object entry information:
The feature of the machine is the use of spiral arms, while the water enters the centre of the turbine from the upturned end of a fixed pipe. By these means the frictional and eddy losses are reduced and the efficiency is increased somewhat over that of the simple Barker’s mill.

The small turbine shown consists of two cast iron discs, 2 in. apart, the lower one having a central orifice fitted to the end of the supply pipe so as to rotate without leakage. The inner faces of the discs have spiral grooves formed in them, to which are fitted sheet iron plates forming the sides of the two spiral passages through which the water issues. These passages are of constant depth, but decrease in width from the centre to the outer edge, where they terminate in tangential orifices 0.5 in. wide. The two discs are clamped together by four through bolts. The vertical driving shaft is fixed to the upper disc and its end carries a bevel pinion gearing with a bevel wheel on a horizontal shaft which transmits the power to the machinery to be driven, the speed reduction being 50 to 13. The diameter of the orifice centres is 14 in., and the supply pipe, 3.5 in. diam., is fitted with a sluice valve. The turbine worked with a head of 15 ft., and was in use in North Wales for 35 years before it was acquired for this Museum.

Turbines of this kind were made over 9 ft. diam. and developing about 100 h.p., but larger machines were usually fitted with self-regulating variable orifices. The maximum hydraulic efficiency was about 75 per cent.

Catalogue number: 22.
Object name: MODEL OF FOURNEYRON’S TURBINE.
Maker/Donor: Made by T. B. Jordan, Esq.,
Date of creation: 1842.
Object entry information: This represents the radial outward flow turbine as constructed by Benoit Fourneyron, who completed his first machine in 1827, after having spent four years in experimenting.
The machine consists of a vertical cylindrical chamber with a side inlet for the water, and a central pipe below through which the water passes to an annular outlet at the base of the pipe. This outlet is fitted with thirty guide blades which direct the water in a tangential course as it escapes. Surrounding this passage is a runner, keyed to a vertical shaft, and provided with vanes between which the water flows as it passes from the inner to the outer circumference, where it is finally discharged. A diagram model of the vanes of such a runner is seen adjoining. The water under pressure is discharged in a tangential direction from the fixed guides, and on passing between the vanes of the enclosing wheel has its direction of motion gradually changed until the energy of the water had been transferred to the wheel, when the water is discharged at the outer rims, dead.
The central pipe containing the guides is carried by three screwed rods connected above by gearing, by which the pipe can be accurately raised, so as to contract the supply passage into the wheel if less than full power is required. The toe of the shaft is carried in a special bearing, supplied with oil under pressure. The power given off by the shaft is transmitted by bevel gear at the upper end.
To a scale of 1: 2, the model represents generally a turbine erected by Fourneyron in 1837, at St. Blazien, Baden. The runner was 22 in. diam. and under the head of 354 ft. developed a speed of 2,300 rev. per min.; the efficiency was stated to be 80 per cent.
(See Glynn—Treatise on the Power of Water, 1853, p. 57.)
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1857-181 and 182—19,607.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 23.
Object name: MODEL OF A VORTEX TURBINE. (Scale 1: 6.)
Maker/Donor: Lent by Messer. G. Gilkes & Co.,
Date of creation: 1888.
Object entry information: This is a working model of an inward-flow turbine of the type patented in 1850 by Prof. James Thomson, the result of whose investigations of the laws of the free vortex have been applied in the design.
It consists of a large casing, into which the water enters and from which it escapes axially by two discharge pipes. Pivoted in the casing are blades or vanes, which give a spiral direction to the water as it approaches and impinges upon the curved vanes of the runner to which it imparts rotation. Each vane has a short shaft and lever connected with external brick work by which adjustment of the orifices can be made simultaneously. The advantage of this method of regulation, known as the wicket gate, is that there is little loss of efficiency when working at partial loads.
This turbine would use 600 cub. ft. of water per min. with a fall of 25.5 ft., and would give about 22.4 h.p. at 75 per cent. efficiency; it would make about 250 rev. per min. If the model itself is worked with water it will make about 560 rev. per min.
Object/Inventory number: N/A

Catalogue number: 24.
Object name: MIXED FLOW DOUBLE TURBINE.
Maker/Donor: Lent by Messrs. S. Howes, Ltd.
Date of creation: 1901.
Object entry information: This is an example of the “Little Giant” double turbine much used in America for driving farm and other machinery requiring small power. It is of the mixed flow type and is designed to work drowned. The case and the runner are divided horizontally into two portions by diaphragms so that the two portions form complete machines. A vertical sluice enables the top portion to be shut off and the turbine to be run on half load and to maintain the same efficiency as on full load. The turbine is fitted with a lignum-vitae footstep bearing and an upper steady bearing furnished with lignum-vitae blocks separately adjustable. This underwater bearing is liable to give trouble owing to grit, etc., so that the single runner type furnished with above water suspension is now most used. The example is 6 in. diam.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1901-24.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 25.
Object name: DIAGRAM OF THE NIAGARA FALLS POWER PLANT.
Maker/Donor: Presented by the Institution of Civil Engineers.
Date of creation: 1896.
Object entry information: The available energy of the Niagara Falls is about five million h.p., to generate which by the agency of steam would, it is estimated, require the consumption of the whole of the world’s present output of coal. The hydro-electric schemes already in progress will utilise more than a tenth of this energy. The diagram shows two of the turbines and their dynamos in the first portion of the scheme of one of the supply companies—The Niagara Falls Power Co.—which began work in 1890 and first delivered current in 1895. The water is conveyed by an intake canal, 250 ft. wide, 1,700 ft. long, and 12 ft. deep, to the power house, where there is a wheel slot for the turbines, 17 ft. deep and the same in length, cut in the solid rock. A tail-race tunnel, 21 ft. high by 19 ft. wide, conveys the dead water to the river below the falls. The available fall is 136 ft. and the penstocks are 7.5 ft. diam. The turbines, 10 in number and each of 5,000 h.p., are of the twin outward flow type designed in Switzerland and made in the United States. A governor and a ratchet relay acting on a cylindrical sleeve on the outside of the wheel regulates the supply. The water pressure acts on the cover of the upper turbine, but is relieved from acting on the lower turbine, thus giving an upward pressure counterbalancing the weight of the shaft and the attachments amounting to about 70 tons. The dynamo is at the top of the shaft running at 250 rev. per min., giving a voltage of 2,200 with a frequency of 25 periods per second. The plant has been remodelled and largely extended recently. (See Proc. Inst. Mech. Eng., 1906, p. 135.)
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1896-119.

Object name: DRAWING OF HYDRAULIC TURBINE GOVERNOR.
Maker/Donor: Presented by Percy H. Pitman, Esq.

Object entry information: This form of governor for hydraulic turbines was patented by Mr. Pitman in 1913. Maker/Donor: Lent by Messrs. S. Howes, Ltd.
Object entry information: This is an example of the “Little Giant” double turbine much used in America for driving farm and other machinery requiring small power. It is of the mixed flow type and is designed to work drowned. The case and the runner are divided horizontally into two portions by diaphragms so that the two portions form complete machines. A vertical sluice enables the top portion to be shut off and the turbine to be run on half load and to maintain the same efficiency as on full load. The turbine is fitted with a lignum-vitae footstep bearing and an upper steady bearing furnished with lignum-vitae blocks separately adjustable. This underwater bearing is liable to give trouble owing to grit, etc., so that the single runner type furnished with above water suspension is now most used. The example is 6 in. diam.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 25.
Object name: DIAGRAM OF THE NIAGARA FALLS POWER PLANT.
Maker/Donor: Presented by the Institution of Civil Engineers.
Date of creation: 1896.
Object entry information: The available energy of the Niagara Falls is about five million h.p., to generate which by the agency of steam would, it is estimated, require the consumption of the whole of the world’s present output of coal. The hydro-electric schemes already in progress will utilise more than a tenth of this energy. The diagram shows two of the turbines and their dynamos in the first portion of the scheme of one of the supply companies—The Niagara Falls Power Co.—which began work in 1890 and first delivered current in 1895. The water is conveyed by an intake canal, 250 ft. wide, 1,700 ft. long, and 12 ft. deep, to the power house, where there is a wheel slot for the turbines, 17 ft. deep and the same in length, cut in the solid rock. A tail-race tunnel, 21 ft. high by 19 ft. wide, conveys the dead water to the river below the falls. The available fall is 136 ft. and the penstocks are 7.5 ft. diam. The turbines, 10 in number and each of 5,000 h.p., are of the twin outward flow type designed in Switzerland and made in the United States. A governor and a ratchet relay acting on a cylindrical sleeve on the outside of the wheel regulates the supply. The water pressure acts on the cover of the upper turbine, but is relieved from acting on the lower turbine, thus giving an upward pressure counterbalancing the weight of the shaft and the attachments amounting to about 70 tons. The dynamo is at the top of the shaft running at 250 rev. per min., giving a voltage of 2,200 with a frequency of 25 periods per second. The plant has been remodelled and largely extended recently. (See Proc. Inst. Mech. Eng., 1906, p. 135.)
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1896-119.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE

Object entry information: This form of governor for hydraulic turbines was patented by Mr. Pitman in 1913. Object/Inventory number: N/A

Object entry information:
the piston valve, and its lower end is connected with an eccentric fixed on a shaft that is partially rotated by the movement of the motor piston. Ports are formed in the valve casing and admit pressure of which the pressure fluid is distributed to either end of the servomotor cylinder. When the speed increases the governor lifts the piston valve and admits pressure to one end of the servomotor, while the other end is open to the exhaust. The motion of the piston then raises the compensating sleeve which closes the ports; the piston is thus caused to take up a definite position corresponding with the position of the governor valve, and hunting is prevented. The valve sleeve is coupled by rolling levers with the oil brake cylinder, which is fitted with a check valve so adjusted that, however sudden the change of load, the action of the governor is not interfered with by the back action of the sleeve. The governor is fitted with ball bearings throughout, and is constructed so that all parts are accessible. For starting, the pressure fluid can be admitted directly to the motor cylinder by means of a four-way cock fitted to the supply pipes.
The governor may be worked with either water or oil at a pressure of about 150 lb. per sq. in.; when using oil it is usually mounted on a self-contained tank bed fitted with the pressure pumps, etc. (see No. 18).
(See Proc. Inst. Mech. Eng., 1913, p. 195.)

Catalogue number: 27.
Object name: COMPRESSED AIR MOTOR.
Maker/Donor: Lent by the International Pneumatic Tool Co., Ltd.
Date of creation: 1901.
Object entry information: This is a small portable machine for rotating the tools used in drilling, tapping, tube expanding, etc., by the application of mechanical power, so as to reduce the time otherwise necessary in performing such work by hand labour alone.
The sectional example shown is a piston motor, patented in 1896 by Mr. H. J. Kimmans, in which there are four fixed single-acting cylinders arranged in pairs in two planes at right angles, and driving a two-throw crankshaft having cranks at 180 deg. Two pistons are connected with each crankpin, so that a fairly uniform turning effort shall be maintained. To reduce the bulk of the machine, the connecting-rod ends are in the form of hinged clips embracing their crankpin, one being forked and bearing outside the other; the ends also embrace the rods, to which they are secured by screwed sleeves. Each pair of cylinders is provided with a hollow piston valve, sliding in a bush and driven by an eccentric; the valve admits air to each cylinder alternately, through suitable ports in the casing and bush, which allow exhaust takes place along the axis of the valve.
The cylinders and crankshaft are enclosed in a casing which forms an air chamber, and is provided with a cover through which passes a screwed sleeve with a star handle, for feeding the drill. The tool holder runs on a ball thrust bearing, and has a conical socket for drills and an externally screwed boss; it is driven from the crankshaft by spur gearing which reduces the speed in the ratio of 1: 7.
The cylinders are 2 in. diam., 2 in. stroke, and the brake h.p. exerted is 1.5, with a consumption of 35 cub. ft. of free air per min. The air pressure used is from 70 to 100 lb. per sq. in., and the maximum duty of the machine is to drill, in metal, holes of 2 in. diam. The weight of the motor complete is 35 lb.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1901–44.

Object name: ORGAN BLOWER (working).
Maker/Donor: N/A
Date of creation: N/A (Received 1897.)
Object entry information: This is a water-pressure engine designed for working the bellows supplying air to an organ, but the cylinder in its action resembles the steam cylinder of a direct-acting steam pump. The supply of water is controlled by a valve connected with the air reservoir, so that the speed of working is automatically adjusted to the consumption of wind.
The blower shown has a cylinder 5.5 in. diam. by 10 in. stroke, and is fitted with a valve gear patented by Mr. D. Joy in 1874. The piston-rod is directly attached to the bellows, but has on it a tappet which reverses the distributing slide valve on the completion of each stroke. This slide valve is of the piston type, but is in reality two valves combined in one, for by its sliding motion the valve acts as the main slide valve, while by a rotary motion through 20 deg. it acts as a plug valve. The plug is in the middle of the length of the piston slide, and by its motion lets the water to and from the ends of the chest of the piston valve, so causing the sliding motion of this valve. The rotation of the valve is performed by two inclined horns, secured

Catalogue number: 29.
Object name: BAMFORD HYDRAULIC ENGINE.
Maker/Donor: Presented by S. J. Ambler, Esq.
Date of creation: 1914.
Object entry information: This is an example of the hydraulic engine for organ blowing, the valve gear of which was patented by Mr. H. Bamford in 1885. The piston-rod is connected directly with the bellows, and water is admitted to either end of the working cylinder by a piston valve. This valve is itself moved by the pressure water which is distributed by a small auxiliary slide valve driven from the piston-rod by a tappet-gear.
The engine has a horizontal working cylinder, with the valve chest on top. The main valve consists of four pistons, connected together and sliding in a cylindrical casing which is provided with suitable inlet and exhaust ports. The two inner pistons serve to distribute the pressure water to the end of the working cylinder, the space between them being in communication with the water inlet, while the two outer pistons are packed with cup leathers and work in the closed ends of the casing. These ends serve as cylinders, to which the pressure water is admitted alternately by the auxiliary valve, through ports in the main valve stem, so as to cause the piston valve to move from end to end. The valve stem between the two inner pistons is of rectangular section, and the necessary slide valve is applied to its upper face. Three ports are formed in this face, the outer ports leading to the ends of the main valve and the central one to the exhaust, while side lugs are formed on the auxiliary valve to keep it in place, and to serve as abutments against which the arms of a forked lever bear when moving the valve. This lever is mounted on a shaft which passes through a stuffing-box and has on its outer end a slotted lever connected with a rod which is worked backwards and forwards, through a short distance at each end of the piston stroke, by a tappet-rod fixed to an arm on the piston-rod. The tappets are adjustable so that the valve may be set to reverse the motion without shock.
When the piston nears the end of its stroke, the tappet-gear carries the auxiliary valve in the same direction, thus admitting the pressure water to the opposite end of the piston valve, and driving it in the same direction so as to admit water behind the piston to drive it back. A sectioned valve chest is shown beside the engine.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1914-139 & 396, S.M. 615.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 30.
Object name: WATER MOTOR WITH OSCILLATING CYLINDER (working).
Maker/Donor: Lent by Messrs. W. H. Bailey & Co.
Date of creation: 1894.
Object entry information: This is a small example of de Haag's high-pressure water motor, for pressures up to 300 lb. per sq. in. These motors are frequently used in mine workings, the water for driving being obtained from the delivery pipe of the main pumping engine, and the motor discharging its exhaust water into the mine sump.
The cylinder of the engine oscillates on two hollow trunnions, closed at the outer ends, the hollow spaces within each trunnion being divided into two compartments, one of which on each side communicates with either end of the cylinder. Two slots cut longitudinally in the trunnion serve for ports for admission and exhaust of the water, one giving admission to each end of the cylinder, and the lower part of each bearing there are three ports, a wide one in the middle communicating with the supply pipe, and a narrower one on each side of this leading to the exhaust pipe. The oscillation of the cylinder causes those ports in the trunnions to slide over those in the bearings, so opening up each end of the cylinder to exhaust or pressure alternately, just as in the case of an ordinary slide valve. The supply and exhaust pipes are each fitted with an air vessel to prevent shocks in the pipes.
This motor has a cylinder 2.5 in. diam. by 4 in. stroke, and when making 100 r.p.m. under a pressure of 150 lb. gives off 1 brake h.p. Larger sizes are made up to those having 9 in. cylinders, which, running at 50 r.p.m. exert 24 brake h.p. under 150 lb. pressure.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1894-182—19, 384.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 29.
Object name: BAMFORD HYDRAULIC ENGINE.
Maker/Donor: Presented by S. J. Ambler, Esq.
Date of creation: 1914.
Object entry information: This is an example of the hydraulic engine for organ blowing, the valve gear of which was patented by Mr. H. Bamford in 1885. The piston-rod is connected directly with the bellows, and water is admitted to either end of the working cylinder by a piston valve. This valve is itself moved by the pressure water which is distributed by a small auxiliary slide valve driven from the piston-rod by a tappet-gear.
The engine has a horizontal working cylinder, with the valve chest on top. The main valve consists of four pistons, connected together and sliding in a cylindrical casing which is provided with suitable inlet and exhaust ports. The two inner pistons serve to distribute the pressure water to the end of the working cylinder, the space between them being in communication with the water inlet, while the two outer pistons are packed with cup leathers and work in the closed ends of the casing. These ends serve as cylinders, to which the pressure water is admitted alternately by the auxiliary valve, through ports in the main valve stem, so as to cause the piston valve to move from end to end. The valve stem between the two inner pistons is of rectangular section, and the necessary slide valve is applied to its upper face. Three ports are formed in this face, the outer ports leading to the ends of the main valve and the central one to the exhaust, while side lugs are formed on the auxiliary valve to keep it in place, and to serve as abutments against which the arms of a forked lever bear when moving the valve. This lever is mounted on a shaft which passes through a stuffing-box and has on its outer end a slotted lever connected with a rod which is worked backwards and forwards, through a short distance at each end of the piston stroke, by a tappet-rod fixed to an arm on the piston-rod. The tappets are adjustable so that the valve may be set to reverse the motion without shock.
When the piston nears the end of its stroke, the tappet-gear carries the auxiliary valve in the same direction, thus admitting the pressure water to the opposite end of the piston valve, and driving it in the same direction so as to admit water behind the piston to drive it back. A sectioned valve chest is shown beside the engine.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1914-139 & 396, S.M. 615.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 30.
Object name: WATER MOTOR WITH OSCILLATING CYLINDER (working).
Maker/Donor: Lent by Messrs. W. H. Bailey & Co.
Date of creation: 1894.
Object entry information: This is a small example of de Haag's high-pressure water motor, for pressures up to 300 lb. per sq. in. These motors are frequently used in mine workings, the water for driving being obtained from the delivery pipe of the main pumping engine, and the motor discharging its exhaust water into the mine sump.
The cylinder of the engine oscillates on two hollow trunnions, closed at the outer ends, the hollow spaces within each trunnion being divided into two compartments, one of which on each side communicates with either end of the cylinder. Two slots cut longitudinally in the trunnion serve for ports for admission and exhaust of the water, one giving admission to each end of the cylinder, and the lower part of each bearing there are three ports, a wide one in the middle communicating with the supply pipe, and a narrower one on each side of this leading to the exhaust pipe. The oscillation of the cylinder causes those ports in the trunnions to slide over those in the bearings, so opening up each end of the cylinder to exhaust or pressure alternately, just as in the case of an ordinary slide valve. The supply and exhaust pipes are each fitted with an air vessel to prevent shocks in the pipes.
This motor has a cylinder 2.5 in. diam. by 4 in. stroke, and when making 100 r.p.m. under a pressure of 150 lb. gives off 1 brake h.p. Larger sizes are made up to those having 9 in. cylinders, which, running at 50 r.p.m. exert 24 brake h.p. under 150 lb. pressure.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1894-182—19, 384.

title: Haag's patent oscillating cylinder water motor No.2
description: Haag's patent oscillating cylinder water motor No.2

Object entry information: The two cylinders are double-acting, fixed with their axes at right angles to each other and working by connecting rods a crankpin common to both. One eccentric actuates both valves which are of the solid piston type. To prevent shock at the reversal points a small conical-seated relief valve is fitted to each water passage opening into the valve chamber, the pressure there keeping them closed under normal conditions. The supply and exhaust passages are cast with the framing connecting the two cylinders. This motor has cylinders 1.25 in. diam. by 1.5 in. stroke, and when running at 200 r.p.m. under a pressure of 150 lb. exerts about 0.3 brake h.p.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 32.
Object name: HYDRAULIC MOTOR IN SECTION.
Maker/Donor: Made by the Hydraulic Engineering Co.
Date of creation: 1888.
Object entry information: This is a small motor on Brotherhood’s system, with three single-acting cylinders inclined at 120 deg. to one another, and having trunk pistons with cup-leather packing. The connecting rods are always under compression and are ball-jointed at the piston end, while at the other extremity they each embrace 90 deg. of the crankpin. The water is distributed by a rotating disc valve (shown separately in section) which has an opening from the outside for pressure, while the exhaust passages through the spindle; the port face is of lignum vitæ. The example has cylinders 1.75 in. diam. by 2.5 in. stroke. It gives 2 brake h.p. at 105 rev. with 7 gal. of water per min. at 750 lb. pressure or 2.5 brake h.p. at 87 rev. with 5.75 gal. at 1,050 lb. pressure.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1888-390, 19,280 & 19,388.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 33.
Object name: HYDRAULIC ENGINE.
Maker/Donor: Lent by the Glenfield Co.
Date of creation: 1896.
Object entry information: This is a small example of a three-cylinder water-pressure engine, suitable for pressures up to 1,000 lb. per sq. in. The three cylinders are cast together, their axes radiating at 120 deg. to one another, and they are always open at their inner ends to the crank chamber. The pistons are packed with cupped leathers and are hollowed out to receive the spherical ends of the thrust bars by which motion is given to the crank. The pressure is always on the outer end of the piston, so that the thrust bars are in compression and take up their own wear. The water is admitted and exhausted by means of a circular disc valve driven by a stem from the crankpin and working on a face which in the case of the larger engines is made of lignum vitæ. Water is admitted at the side of the valve chamber and exhausted by the centre of the valve. This example has cylinders 1 in. diam. by 1.5 in. stroke, and when running at 250 r.p.m. with 600 lb. pressure gives off about 0.75 brake h.p.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1896-117.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 34.
Object name: HYDRAULIC SWASH-PLATE ENGINE (working).
Maker/Donor: Made by Messrs. Sir W. G. Armstrong, Whitworth & Co., Ltd.
Date of creation: 1910. Received 1914.
Object entry information: This is a type of engine in which a shaft, having an oblique disc or swash-plate fixed to it, is caused to rotate by the successive pressures upon the disc of a number of pistons, working in cylinders arranged in a circle, with their axes parallel with the shaft. Such an engine may have a large number of cylinders compactly arranged and gives a very uniform torque. The small example shown has 16 cylinders bored horizontally in a single casting; the pistons are packed with cup leathers and bear against the rounded ends of the piston-rods. The outer ends of the rods are ball-shaped and are held in a circular ring which bears against the swash-plate, ball bearings being interposed to reduce the friction. The ring is controlled by two diametrically opposite pins which slide in horizontal slots attached to the bed-plate of the engine. The end thrust is taken by a row of balls placed between the back of the swash-plate and a fixed disc which is surrounded by an outer casing formed in one with the driving shaft. The valve gear is of the simplified form patented by Mr. F. G. D. Johnston and Sir W. G. Armstrong, Whitworth & Co. in 1908. A single rotary valve is used, placed behind the cylinders and having five inlet and five exhaust ports disposed in a circle; the valve seat has 16 cylinder ports symmetrically arranged, and these are connected with the cylinders in a particular order. This arrangement besides reducing the number of ports in the valve, and therefore its size, also requires that the valve shall rotate at only one-fifth of the speed of the main valve.
Object/Inventory number: N/A

Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: The two cylinders are double-acting, fixed with their axes at right angles to each other and working by connecting rods a crankpin common to both. One eccentric actuates both valves which are of the solid piston type. To prevent shock at the reversal points a small conical-seated relief valve is fitted to each water passage opening into the valve chamber, the pressure there keeping them closed under normal conditions. The supply and exhaust passages are cast with the framing connecting the two cylinders. This motor has cylinders 1.25 in. diam. by 1.5 in. stroke, and when running at 200 r.p.m. under a pressure of 150 lb. exerts about 0.3 brake h.p.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1896-116.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 32.
Object name: HYDRAULIC MOTOR IN SECTION.
Maker/Donor: Made by the Hydraulic Engineering Co.
Date of creation: 1888.
Object entry information: This is a small motor on Brotherhood’s system, with three single-acting cylinders inclined at 120 deg. to one another, and having trunk pistons with cup-leather packing. The connecting rods are always under compression and are ball-jointed at the piston end, while at the other extremity they each embrace 90 deg. of the crankpin. The water is distributed by a rotating disc valve (shown separately in section) which has an opening from the outside for pressure, while the exhaust passages through the spindle; the port face is of lignum vitæ. The example has cylinders 1.75 in. diam. by 2.5 in. stroke. It gives 2 brake h.p. at 105 rev. with 7 gal. of water per min. at 750 lb. pressure or 2.5 brake h.p. at 87 rev. with 5.75 gal. at 1,050 lb. pressure.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1888-390, 19,280 & 19,388.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 33.
Object name: HYDRAULIC ENGINE.
Maker/Donor: Lent by the Glenfield Co.
Date of creation: 1896.
Object entry information: This is a small example of a three-cylinder water-pressure engine, suitable for pressures up to 1,000 lb. per sq. in. The three cylinders are cast together, their axes radiating at 120 deg. to one another, and they are always open at their inner ends to the crank chamber. The pistons are packed with cupped leathers and are hollowed out to receive the spherical ends of the thrust bars by which motion is given to the crank. The pressure is always on the outer end of the piston, so that the thrust bars are in compression and take up their own wear. The water is admitted and exhausted by means of a circular disc valve driven by a stem from the crankpin and working on a face which in the case of the larger engines is made of lignum vitæ. Water is admitted at the side of the valve chamber and exhausted by the centre of the valve. This example has cylinders 1 in. diam. by 1.5 in. stroke, and when running at 250 r.p.m. with 600 lb. pressure gives off about 0.75 brake h.p.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1896-117.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 34.
Object name: HYDRAULIC SWASH-PLATE ENGINE (working).
Maker/Donor: Made by Messrs. Sir W. G. Armstrong, Whitworth & Co., Ltd.
Date of creation: 1910. Received 1914.
Object entry information: This is a type of engine in which a shaft, having an oblique disc or swash-plate fixed to it, is caused to rotate by the successive pressures upon the disc of a number of pistons, working in cylinders arranged in a circle, with their axes parallel with the shaft. Such an engine may have a large number of cylinders compactly arranged and gives a very uniform torque. The small example shown has 16 cylinders bored horizontally in a single casting; the pistons are packed with cup leathers and bear against the rounded ends of the piston-rods. The outer ends of the rods are ball-shaped and are held in a circular ring which bears against the swash-plate, ball bearings being interposed to reduce the friction. The ring is controlled by two diametrically opposite pins which slide in horizontal slots attached to the bed-plate of the engine. The end thrust is taken by a row of balls placed between the back of the swash-plate and a fixed disc which is surrounded by an outer casing formed in one with the driving shaft. The valve gear is of the simplified form patented by Mr. F. G. D. Johnston and Sir W. G. Armstrong, Whitworth & Co. in 1908. A single rotary valve is used, placed behind the cylinders and having five inlet and five exhaust ports disposed in a circle; the valve seat has 16 cylinder ports symmetrically arranged, and these are connected with the cylinders in a particular order. This arrangement besides reducing the number of ports in the valve, and therefore its size, also requires that the valve shall rotate at only one-fifth of the speed of the main valve.
Object/Inventory number: N/A

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 35.
Object name: TIDAL MOTOR.
Maker/Donor: Contributed by Richard Roberts, Esq.,
Date of creation: 1858.
Object entry information: This apparatus, patented by Mr. Roberts in 1848, is shown arranged for clock-winding, or doing lighthouse work, by tidal energy. The machine is erected over a tank or well to which the tide has access; into this hangs a weight and also a float, connected by a chain that passes over a sprocket wheel on the overhead shaft, then round a loose wheel on the framing and back over another sprocket wheel. These wheels are connected with the shaft by ratchet and pawl mechanism, which causes both upward and downward movements of the float chain to rotate the shaft, always in one direction. The power so obtained will cease for a while during the turn of the tide, and therefore when continuous motion is required, an additional mechanism is added. On the end of the intermittently rotated shaft is a sprocket wheel, and on the shaft to be continuously rotated, which is in line with it, is another sprocket wheel; over the two wheels hangs an endless chain, in the loops of which are two weighted sheaves, one of which is much the heavier, the difference being the driving weight. When the tidal motion is rapid the excess power is stored by lifting the weight, while, when the tidal movement stops, this weight gives off its stored energy in descending, and so keeps the driving shaft in motion. The weighted sheaves are connected by a hanging chain which prevents the inequalities in the effort which would otherwise arise from the varying length of chain on the driving side.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1858–9.

Object name: DRAWING OF APPARATUS DESCRIBED BY HERO.
Maker/Donor: AEOLIPLIE (working). Made in the Museum. (Hero of Alexandria described the original apparatus).
Date of creation: Prepared in the Museum, 1897. Made in the Museum, 1914.
Object entry information: Hero of Alexandria, a philosopher who flourished probably about A.D. 50, in his treatise on “Pneumatics” describes a light ball, supported by a jet of high pressure steam issuing from a pipe terminating in a cup, and supplied from a cauldron. He also describes the aeolipile, which consists of a hollow ball mounted on its axis between two pivots, one of which, being hollow, serves as a steam pipe from the cauldron below, supporting the whole. The ball is provided with two bent nozzles, in a plane at right angles to the line joining the pivots. The reaction or unbalanced pressure due to the escape of the jets of high pressure steam tangentially to the ball, causes it to revolve on its axis. The reconstruction of an aeolipile shown is based on drawings dating only from about the 15th century however, accompanying the MSS. of Hero’s “Pneumatics.”

Catalogue number: 37.
Object name: DRAWING OF APPARATUS PROPOSED BY SOLOMON DE CAUS.
Maker/Donor: Solomon De Caus (proposed by). Prepared in the Museum (drawing preparer).
Date of creation: Prepared in the Museum, 1897.
Object entry information: This French engineer and architect proposed and published in 1615 an application of steam as a means of elevating water. His scheme required a spherical copper boiler with an internal pipe reaching nearly to the bottom, and with a cock for filling it. The boiler was to be placed on a fire until the steam pressure forced the boiling water through the vertical pipe to a height proportionate to this pressure. In an alternate scheme he proposed using the heat of the sun’s rays to increase the pressure of a confined volume of air, and thus force up some of the water upon which it pressed.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1897–112, 19,606.

Object name: DRAWING OF MACHINE DESIGNED BY GIOVANNI BRANCA. Prepared in the Museum, 1897.
Maker/Donor: Giovanni Branca
Object entry information: Branca was an Italian engineer who, in 1629, published a work in which he suggested a form of steam engine. A powerful horizontal jet of steam was to be directed against vanes on the circumference of a fan wheel with a vertical axis, thus causing the wheel to revolve. Several applications of the resulting motion were described, but that shown in the drawing consists in the use of a reducing train of spur gearing by which pestles or gravitation stamps are lifted. The alteration in the form of the jet and in that of the vanes it will, however, be seen, resemble the efficient steam turbine of Dr. de Laval (see No. 152), provided the requisite high speed could have been maintained.

Catalogue number: 39.
Object name: DRAWING OF APPARATUS OF TORRICELLI AND VON GUERICKE. Prepared in the Museum, 1897.
Maker/Donor: Evangelista Torricelli and Otto von Guericke (Designers)
Date of creation: Original design 1643/1654. Drawing prepared 1897.
Object entry information: This drawing is inserted here to emphasize the fact that in the middle of the 17th century the discovery was made that the atmosphere had weight and that it could be excluded from a closed vessel so as to obtain a vacuum, facts essential in the development of the steam engine. Evangelista Torricelli, an Italian physicist and a pupil of Galileo, in 1643 confirmed his instructor’s speculations that the atmosphere had weight by measuring it with his invention of what is now known as the mercurial barometer. Otto von Guericke, burgomaster of Magdeburg, directed his attention to the means of obtaining a vacuum and adapted the syringe for his purpose; in 1654 he showed his apparatus publicly. In the treatise he published in 1672 he described a number of experiments on the subject, including the one shown in the drawing in which a cylinder is fitted with a tight piston connected by a cord and overhead air-pump to a weight; when the air under the piston was exhausted by an air-pump the weight was lifted. Reproductions of Guericke’s apparatus are to be found in the Physics Collection.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1897–114, 19,599.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 40.
Object name: DRAWING OF CONTRIVANCE DESCRIBED BY THE MARQUIS OF WORCESTER. Prepared in the Museum, 1897.
Maker/Donor: Edward Somerset, second Marquis of Worcester (Designer)
Date of creation: Original design 1655/1663. Drawing prepared 1897.
Object entry information: Edward Somerset, second Marquis of Worcester, in his “Century of Inventions,” which was written in 1655, although not published till 1663, included descriptions of of “a water work”; in 1663 the benefits of a “water commanding engine” were secured to the Marquis for ninety-nine years by Act of Parliament. In 1663 and 1669 eye-witnesses saw one of these engines, which had been erected by the Marquis at Vauxhall, raise water to a height of 40 ft.; this drawing is a speculative attempt to represent that engine. It shows a high pressure boiler, and two vessels into which the water to be pumped was forced by atmospheric pressure after the contained steam had condensed; this water was afterwards discharged by steam pressure on the system subsequently extensively practised by Savery.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1897–115, 19,389.
