Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 98.
Object name: TREVITHICK ENGINE AND BOILER.
Maker/Donor: N/A (Received)
Date of creation: Received 1881.
Object entry information: This is a form of high pressure engine which, combined with the return flue boiler, was patented by Trevithick and Vivian in 1802, and subsequently extensively used for locomotives as well as semi-portable engines.
The boiler shell is of cast iron 1 in. thick, 3.6 ft. diam., and 5.5 ft. long; the back end, which is dished, is cast with it, while the front of the shell has a flange to which the wrought iron front of the boiler is secured by bolts. To this front the two ends of the return, or horseshoe, flue are riveted; the larger leg of the flue is 18 in. diam. and holds the grate, the return portion being only 10 in. diam. The front of the boiler also has a manhole, but the system of construction rendered the whole interior readily accessible for scaling and repairs, owing to the ease with which the boiler front and furnace could be removed.
The steam generated passed into a cast-iron steam dome, surmounted by a 2 in. lever-weighted safety-valve, from which it was led by an external pipe to the valve chest of the steam cylinder, which is 9.5 in. diam. by about 36 in. stroke. The cylinder is arranged vertically, and is steam jacketed, being almost immersed in the boiler to which it is secured by an upper flange. The boiler steam, after passing through a stop valve of the plug type, is admitted alternately to the two ends of the cylinder by a four-way plug valve worked by a tappet motion.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1881-57-25,244.

Object name: PHOTOGRAPHS OF TREVITHICK ENGINE AND BOILER.
Maker/Donor: Presented by F. W. Webb, Esq., 1890.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 98.
Object name: TREVITHICK ENGINE AND BOILER.
Maker/Donor: N/A (Received)
Date of creation: Received 1881.
Object entry information: This is a form of high pressure engine which, combined with the return flue boiler, was patented by Trevithick and Vivian in 1802, and subsequently extensively used for locomotives as well as semi-portable engines.
The boiler shell is of cast iron 1 in. thick, 3.6 ft. diam., and 5.5 ft. long; the back end, which is dished, is cast with it, while the front of the shell has a flange to which the wrought iron front of the boiler is secured by bolts. To this front the two ends of the return, or horseshoe, flue are riveted; the larger leg of the flue is 18 in. diam. and holds the grate, the return portion being only 10 in. diam. The front of the boiler also has a manhole, but the system of construction rendered the whole interior readily accessible for scaling and repairs, owing to the ease with which the boiler front and furnace could be removed.
The steam generated passed into a cast-iron steam dome, surmounted by a 2 in. lever-weighted safety-valve, from which it was led by an external pipe to the valve chest of the steam cylinder, which is 9.5 in. diam. by about 36 in. stroke. The cylinder is arranged vertically, and is steam jacketed, being almost immersed in the boiler to which it is secured by an upper flange. The boiler steam, after passing through a stop valve of the plug type, is admitted alternately to the two ends of the cylinder by a four-way plug valve worked by a tappet motion.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1881-57-25,244.

Maker/Donor: Made in the Museum, 1902.

Object/Inventory number: N/A
title: Drawing of Fentons and Murray's vertical engine
description: Drawing of Fentons and Murray's vertical engine, 1802
place: London, Greater London, England, United Kingdom

Object entry information: of double its diameter, any point in the circumference of the rolling circle describes a straight line. Murray appears to have been the first to construct practically a machine embodying this method of obtaining a straight line, or “parallel” motion ; he, moreover, fully describes a means of taking up the wear on the centre of the rolling wheel by the use of adjustable double cones. On the fly-wheel shaft is a crank pin having loose on it a spur wheel of equal radius to the crank path, while on the rim of the spur wheel is secured a crank pin to which the piston-rod is directly attached ; the spur wheel engages with an internally geared rim of double its diameter rigidly secured to the engine framing. By these arrangements a guided straight line motion is obtained without the use of links or guides, while, owing to there being no extension of the piston-rod or anything beyond it, the engine is remarkably compact, Murray’s mechanism possesses the further advantages of giving a true harmonic motion, and having all its parts revolving so that they can be directly balanced, while there is a total absence of oblique thrust. For these reasons it is, although now no longer used in steam engines, still extensively adopted for giving reciprocating motion to the tables of flat-bed printing machines as shown by a model in another Section.

Catalogue number: 102.
Object name: BEAM ENGINE.
Maker/Donor: Matthew Murray, of Leeds.
Date of creation: Brought out in 1805. Received 1907.
Object entry information: This form of “portable” or self-contained condensing beam engine was brought out in 1805 by Matthew Murray, of Leeds. It proved in practice to be not easily accessible, and only a few engines were therefore made. It is interesting, nevertheless, as having the same general arrangement as the side-lever engine which subsequently became the recognised type for marine purposes. The engine is contained within a tank supported on four feet. A dividing partition enables the cylinder and valve box to be packed with non-conduct-ing material, while the air-pump and condenser are surrounded by water. The cylinder crosshead has two side rods working on to a pin on the end of a beam rocking on a centre on the underside of the tank. The other end of the beam has a connecting rod to a crankshaft above, with a large fly-wheel. The air-pump is worked similarly by side rods from an intermediate point in the beam. Neither cylinder nor air-pump crossheads are guided. Steam is dis-tributed to the cylinder by the “locomotive” slide-valve which had been patented by Murray in 1802. The valve has a rack on the back geared into by a sector which is actuated by a rod having a frame at the other end embracing a cam on the crankshaft; the cam gives a period of rest at the end of each stroke. The injection cock to the condenser can be adjusted by a hand lever moving over an index plate. The engines actually made were of 6 h.p.; the small example shown has a cylinder 3 in. diam. by 5 in. stroke.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1907-23, S.M. I.

Object name: MODELS OF TABLE ENGINES (working). (Scale 1 : 4 and 1 : 24.)
Maker/Donor: Henry Maudslay. Maudslay Collection.

Object entry information: The original form of this engine, as patented by Henry Maudslay in 1807, is represented by an adjacent drawing, from which these models differ only in detail. Object entry information: This form of “portable” or self-contained condensing beam engine was brought out in 1805 by Matthew Murray, of Leeds. It proved in practice to be not easily accessible, and only a few engines were therefore made. It is interesting, nevertheless, as having the same general arrangement as the side-lever engine which subsequently became the recognised type for marine purposes. The engine is contained within a tank supported on four feet. A dividing partition enables the cylinder and valve box to be packed with non-conduct-ing material, while the air-pump and condenser are surrounded by water. The cylinder crosshead has two side rods working on to a pin on the end of a beam rocking on a centre on the underside of the tank. The other end of the beam has a connecting rod to a crankshaft above, with a large fly-wheel. The air-pump is worked similarly by side rods from an intermediate point in the beam. Neither cylinder nor air-pump crossheads are guided. Steam is dis-tributed to the cylinder by the “locomotive” slide-valve which had been patented by Murray in 1802. The valve has a rack on the back geared into by a sector which is actuated by a rod having a frame at the other end embracing a cam on the crankshaft; the cam gives a period of rest at the end of each stroke. Object entry information: of double its diameter, any point in the circumference of the rolling circle describes a straight line. Murray appears to have been the first to construct practically a machine embodying this method of obtaining a straight line, or “parallel” motion ; he, moreover, fully describes a means of taking up the wear on the centre of the rolling wheel by the use of adjustable double cones. On the fly-wheel shaft is a crank pin having loose on it a spur wheel of equal radius to the crank path, while on the rim of the spur wheel is secured a crank pin to which the piston-rod is directly attached ; the spur wheel engages with an internally geared rim of double its diameter rigidly secured to the engine framing. By these arrangements a guided straight line motion is obtained without the use of links or guides, while, owing to there being no extension of the piston-rod or anything beyond it, the engine is remarkably compact, Murray’s mechanism possesses the further advantages of giving a true harmonic motion, and having all its parts revolving so that they can be directly balanced, while there is a total absence of oblique thrust. For these reasons it is, although now no longer used in steam engines, still extensively adopted for giving reciprocating motion to the tables of flat-bed printing machines as shown by a model in another Section.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1902-15.

description: Model of Maudslay's 1807 table engine (scale 1:24) with associated components, made by Maudslay, Sons and Field Limited, Lambeth, London, 1807

Object entry information: The cylinder is mounted on a cast-iron table, which is supported by four columns upon a base plate carrying the crankshaft bearings. The piston-rod passes through the top cover of the cylinder, and its crosshead slides in two pairs of guides cast with the cover. The connecting rod is in the form of a loop, or “kite,” embracing a single crank in the shaft. The slide-valve is worked by a similar “kite” rod from an eccentric which also drives the horizontal force pump for feeding the steam boiler. The speed is regulated by a simple centrifugal governor which controls a disc throttle valve in the steam pipe.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 105.
Object name: TREVITHICK’S HIGH-PRESSURE STEAM ENGINE.
Maker/Donor: Richard Trevithick
Date of creation: 1811
Object entry information: Received 1879. Plate IV., No. 1. This early high-pressure engine and boiler were made by Richard Trevithick in 1811 at Hayle Foundry, Cornwall, for Sir Christopher Hawkins, Bart., of Trewithen, and were in constant use for thrashing, chaff-cutting, and similar work, until removed to South Kensington in 1879. It is stated that this was the first steam engine that drove a thrashing machine. The boiler is of the Cornish type, 7 ft. long by 4.5 ft. diam., with a single internal flue 27 in. diam.; beyond the fire bridge the circular shape is departed from, one side of the flue being flattened so that the section is 28 in. by 21 in. The products of combustion from the furnace flue were led by a “wheel draught” through external masonry flues to the chimney, the total heating surface so obtained being probably about 50 sq. ft. The shell of the boiler is shaped at the top so as to receive the steam cylinder, which is open-topped and placed in the boiler so as to be steam-jacketed. The safety valve is weighted for a maximum pressure of 40 lb. above the atmosphere. The cylinder is 9.5 in. diam. by 26 in. stroke, and the long connecting rod, which is attached directly to the piston, passes up to a crank on a fly-wheel shaft above. The fly-wheel is 10 ft. diam., with a grooved rim for a driving rope, and has cast on it a balance weight that assists the return stroke of the piston. Steam distribution is by a four-way cock which is rocked by a cam on the crankshaft. The feed pump is worked by a lever from the piston.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1879-57, 25,515.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 106.
Object name: HIGH-PRESSURE ENGINE.
Maker/Donor: Presented by the Rt. Hon. the Earl of Shrewsbury and Talbot, K.C.V.O., 1911.
Date of creation: c. 1815
Object entry information: This engine was employed for general purposes at a salt works at Ingestre, near Stafford, for upwards of half a century; it has been disused since 1882, when the works were closed down. It is said to have been removed thither from Brereton, near Rugeley, where it had been used in winding from a coal pit. Nothing is known as to the maker of the engine, but it exhibits several features that were peculiar to the designs of Richard Trevithick, the pioneer in the adoption of high-pressure steam, some of whose engines are known to have been constructed at Bridgnorth about 1815. The engine is later than those (Nos. 98 and 105) shown near at hand, in that the cylinder is separated from the boiler and has an independent framing. The engine is of the vertical, return connecting-rod type, with a cylinder 7 in. diam. by 24 in. stroke. Steam admission and exhaust are controlled by a four-way cock, the lever or spanner of which is struck by two tappets adjustable on a tappet rod hanging from the crosshead, in a similar way to that in Trevithick’s road locomotive model (see the Road Transport Section). The tail of this spanner has a strap attached to limit its fall below the point where the tappet can again strike it. The area of both the steam and exhaust ports in the four-way cock is 1.25 sq. in. There was no governor, but there was a stop-cock on the steam pipe. The exhaust steam passes to a feed water heater of the form adopted by Trevithick in the high-pressure engine which he applied to a dredger in 1803; he foresaw the desirability of saving some of the heat rejected in the exhaust steam. The heater consists merely of a casing surrounding about 4 ft. of the feed pipe which passes through stuffing boxes at either end. The casing is prevented from shifting by iron loops. The feed pump, 2.125 in. diam. by 5.5 in. stroke, is worked from a pin driven into the space between the boss of the pinion and the crankshaft, on one end of the latter. Interesting details of early machine construction may be noted, such as the square cast-iron crankshaft with its narrow bearings, bridles for holding cocks on their seats, and the method of staying the crosshead guides.
Object/Inventory number: N/A

Object entry information: This engine was employed for general purposes at a salt works at Ingestre, near Stafford, for upwards of half a century; it has been disused since 1882, when the works were closed down. It is said to have been removed thither from Brereton, near Rugeley, where it had been used in winding from a coal pit. Nothing is known as to the maker of the engine, but it exhibits several features that were peculiar to the designs of Richard Trevithick, the pioneer in the adoption of high-pressure steam, some of whose engines are known to have been constructed at Bridgnorth about 1815. The engine is later than those (Nos. 98 and 105) shown near at hand, in that the cylinder is separated from the boiler and has an independent framing. The engine is of the vertical, return connecting-rod type, with a cylinder 7 in. diam. by 24 in. stroke. Steam admission and exhaust are controlled by a four-way cock, the lever or spanner of which is struck by two tappets adjustable on a tappet rod hanging from the crosshead, in a similar way to that in Trevithick’s road locomotive model (see the Road Transport Section). The tail of this spanner has a strap attached to limit its fall below the point where the tappet can again strike it. The area of both the steam and exhaust ports in the four-way cock is 1.25 sq. in. There was no governor, but there was a stop-cock on the steam pipe. The exhaust steam passes to a feed water heater of the form adopted by Trevithick in the high-pressure engine which he applied to a dredger in 1803; he foresaw the desirability of saving some of the heat rejected in the exhaust steam. The heater consists merely of a casing surrounding about 4 ft. of the feed pipe which passes through stuffing boxes at either end. The casing is prevented from shifting by iron loops. The feed pump, 2.125 in. diam. by 5.5 in. stroke, is worked from a pin driven into the space between the boss of the pinion and the crankshaft, on one end of the latter. Interesting details of early machine construction may be noted, such as the square cast-iron crankshaft with its narrow bearings, bridles for holding cocks on their seats, and the method of staying the crosshead guides.
Object/Inventory number: N/A
title: Trevithick's patent 1802, high pressure steam engine, constructed 1811 for threshing purposes at Trewithen, in use till 1879
description: Trevithick's patent 1802, high pressure steam engine, constructed at Hayle Foundry, 1811 for threshing purposes at Trewithen, Cornwall, in use till 1879
object_name: high pressure steam engine; high pressure steam engine

Object entry information: At Ingestre, steam at 35 lb. pressure was supplied by an egg-ended boiler, of more recent date than the engine, 8.5 ft. long by 3 ft. diam., set with a partial wheel draught. The engine is said to have developed about 5 h.p., which would have meant a mean effective pressure of 25 lb., and the not improbable speed of 45 r.p.m.; as a boiler of the size stated could evaporate sufficient steam for that power, it is no doubt correct.

Object name: MODEL OF DIAGONAL OSCILLATING ENGINE (working).
Maker/Donor: Maudslay Collection, 1900.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: The double-cylinder diagonal engine with a single crank was designed and patented in 1822 by Sir M. I. Brunel chiefly for use as a marine engine. The model shows the design as modified by the use of oscillating cylinders, and is believed to represent an engine built by Messrs. Maudslay, Sons and Field, for working the drainage pumps used during the construction of the Thames Tunnel, 1825–42. The cylinders are each 0.77 in. diam. by 1.43 in. stroke, and incline upward, at 45 deg., to the single crankshaft. Each cylinder is double-acting, and the steam distribution is performed through ports in one of the trunnions, which, by its oscillation, acts as a slide-valve. As Joseph Maudslay had in 1827 introduced a much more efficient valve-gear for this class of engine (see Marine Engineering Collection), the motor represented was probably made during the early stage of the tunnel works.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1900-25, 28,655.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 108.
Object name: ROTATIVE BEAM ENGINE.
Maker/Donor: Presented by the Salt Union, Ltd., 1920.
Date of creation: c. 1820.
Object entry information: This is a low-pressure engine of the established beam type, and may be taken as representative of practice during the period of twenty or thirty years after the expiration in 1800 of Watt’s patent for the separate condenser, when other engineers could enter the field on equal terms. The engine is believed to have come originally from South Lancashire. It worked at Littler's Rock Mine, Marston, Cheshire, from early in the century up to 1852. It was taken out and converted into a pumping engine, and in that state worked until 1900, when it was again altered to a winding engine and put up at the Fletcher and Rigby Mine, Marston, perhaps the oldest rock salt mine in England. Its duty, which was to lift tubs of rock salt weighing 1 ton from a depth of 330 ft., was performed intermittently until 1910, when rearrangements rendered the engine superfluous. It will be noted that timber framing has now been finally discarded; the base plate, central column, and entablature (cross-shaped in plan) are wholly of cast iron. The engine is, however, not quite self-contained, in that the ends of the base and entablature are built into the walls of the engine house. The steam cylinder is double-acting, and is secured to a rectangular cast-iron beam which is bolted to the tank containing the condensing chamber and air pump. The valves are actuated in such a manner that when the piston reaches the end of its stroke, a tappet on the air pump rod closes one set of valves, simultaneously opening the steam valve to the top of the cylinder and the exhaust to the condensing chamber. The exhaust steam is condensed by the action of a continuously operating jet of water assisted by the surrounding water. The jet was regulated by hand to maintain a constant head of water in tank. The air pump is connected to the condenser chamber by a rectangular pipe having a non-return valve between the two, a similar valve being situated inside the hot well. The capacity of the air pump is large owing to the fact that the injection was always full on, and that steam was admitted throughout the length of the stroke. The cylinder is 18 in. diam. as rebored, by 4 ft. stroke; the air pump is 12 in. diam. by 2 ft. stroke; the beam of cast iron is unequal armed, measuring 6.66 ft. between centre of piston and beam and 6.5 ft. between beam and connecting rod; the crank throw is consequently 23.4 in. Both crank and connecting rod are of cast iron. The fly-wheel, 12.5 ft. diam., is built up as a spider with 8 segmental arms breaking joint. Steam at a pressure of 5 to 10 lb. per sq. in. was supplied by an egg-ended boiler. The speed was 12–15 r.p.m., so that the engine must have developed about 15 h.p.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1920-476.

Maker/Donor: Presented by Loftus P. Perkins, Esq.
Object entry information: This shows the high-pressure steam engine patented by Jacob Perkins in 1827 in which the flow of the steam is unidirectional, i.e., after acting on a first piston it is used on a second piston in a second cylinder, both single-acting. Hence this engine may be considered to be the precursor of the uniflow engine.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 111.
Object name: FACTORY BEAM ENGINE.
Maker/Donor: Received 1915.
Date of creation: about 1830–40
Object entry information: This is a small example of the self-contained non-condensing beam engine made about 1830–40 for factory purposes. It was in use till 1905 for driving a set of drying rolls. The cylinder is 7.25 in. diam. by 14 in. stroke. The slide valve is of unusual design, being a hollow box, shaped like a flat inverted U, the legs of which slide on a flat seating joining the cylinder ports and forming the front of the valve chest. Live steam surrounds the valve and passes underneath to the inside edges of the steam ports, while the exhaust takes place through the interior of the valve to a port at the lower end of the valve face which leads to an exit in the base of the cylinder. A spring on the back of the valve keeps it to its face when steam is shut off. The valve is actuated by an eccentric with a gab-ended rod. A butterfly valve throttled by a Watt centrifugal governor controls steam admission to the valve chest. An interesting feature is the parallel motion, which is a modification of that of Watt; the radius rod is centred at a point above and half way between the end of the beam and its gudgeon, while the link connecting the end of the radius rod and the beam is extended to the parallel point, to which the piston rod is attached. This form of motion is compact and simple, and does not require the pantagraph of the ordinary Watt motion. The framing and entablature of the engine is in the classical style which was much affected in the early years of the 19th century.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1915–128.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 112.
Object name: MODEL OF TWIN-CYLINDER ENGINE. (Scale about 1: 24.)
Maker/Donor: Received 1911.
Date of creation: patented in 1839
Object entry information: The twin-cylinder or “Siamese” engine, patented in 1839 by Joseph Mauds lay and Joshua Field for marine purposes (see Marine Engineering Collection) was modified for land use in exceptional cases, as here shown; the advantage of the arrangement is that a long stroke can be accommodated in a limited height, but mechanically it is undesirable, so that few were made; in common with the “table” (see No. 103) and other engines of this time it was superseded by the direct-acting type. The two cylinders have a common crosshead, which is of a T-shape, working in guides between the cylinders; it is formed of two plates between which swings the connecting rod, whose point of attachment is at the tail of the T while its big end joins to the crankshaft overhead. The valve is a simple four-way cock, the lever of which is actuated by an eccentric.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1911–58.

Catalogue number: 113.
Object name: DIAGRAM MODEL OF DOUBLE-CYLINDER ENGINE.
Maker/Donor: Presented by the Institution of Civil Engineers.

title: Bromide print of Jacob Perkins' Uniflow Steam Engine
description: Bromide print, 6" x 8", mounted, of Jacob Perkins' Uniflow Steam Engine, 1827

Maker/Donor: Received 1915.
Object entry information: This is a small example of the self-contained non-condensing beam engine made about 1830–40 for factory purposes. It was in use till 1905 for driving a set of drying rolls. The cylinder is 7.25 in. diam. by 14 in. stroke. The slide valve is of unusual design, being a hollow box, shaped like a flat inverted U, the legs of which slide on a flat seating joining the cylinder ports and forming the front of the valve chest. Live steam surrounds the valve and passes underneath to the inside edges of the steam ports, while the exhaust takes place through the interior of the valve to a port at the lower end of the valve face which leads to an exit in the base of the cylinder. A spring on the back of the valve keeps it to its face when steam is shut off. The valve is actuated by an eccentric with a gab-ended rod. A butterfly valve throttled by a Watt centrifugal governor controls steam admission to the valve chest. An interesting feature is the parallel motion, which is a modification of that of Watt; the radius rod is centred at a point above and half way between the end of the beam and its gudgeon, while the link connecting the end of the radius rod and the beam is extended to the parallel point, to which the piston rod is attached. This form of motion is compact and simple, and does not require the pantagraph of the ordinary Watt motion. The framing and entablature of the engine is in the classical style which was much affected in the early years of the 19th century.

Catalogue number: 112.
Object name: MODEL OF TWIN-CYLINDER ENGINE. (Scale about 1: 24.)
Maker/Donor: Received 1911.
Date of creation: patented in 1839
Object entry information: The twin-cylinder or “Siamese” engine, patented in 1839 by Joseph Mauds lay and Joshua Field for marine purposes (see Marine Engineering Collection) was modified for land use in exceptional cases, as here shown; the advantage of the arrangement is that a long stroke can be accommodated in a limited height, but mechanically it is undesirable, so that few were made; in common with the “table” (see No. 103) and other engines of this time it was superseded by the direct-acting type. The two cylinders have a common crosshead, which is of a T-shape, working in guides between the cylinders; it is formed of two plates between which swings the connecting rod, whose point of attachment is at the tail of the T while its big end joins to the crankshaft overhead. The valve is a simple four-way cock, the lever of which is actuated by an eccentric.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1911–58.

Object entry information:
16 in. stroke, and the piston rod is connected to a beam about four times the length of the stroke. The centre of the beam is constrained by two bridles attached to the framing and thus a straight line motion is impressed on the crosshead. The other end of the beam is pivoted on two long rocking links and it is the fancied appearance of these in motion which gave rise to the name of the engine.
This particular example was used in the Royal Horticultural Gardens from about 1840 till 1870 when it was moved to the Royal Albert Hall. Its duty in both places was to pump water from an artesian well. As arranged in the last place the crankshaft was connected by a claw clutch and bevel gearing, in the ratio of 3 : 1, to a three-throw bore hole pump, 9 in. stroke, lifting from a depth of about 90 ft. The steam pressure was 50 lb. by gauge.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 115.
Object name: MODEL OF GRASSHOPPER OR HALF-BEAM ENGINE (working). (Scale about 1 : 12.)
Maker/Donor: N/A
Date of creation: Received 1869.
Object entry information: The grasshopper engine, so named from its peculiar motion (see No. 114), has been known also as the half-beam engine.
The cylinder is vertical and its piston-rod is connected with a crosshead whence two connecting rods return to a double-throw crankshaft below. The crosshead is fixed in one end of the beam, the other end being pivoted on two rocking links; the centre of the beam is constrained by two bridles, half the length of the beam, attached to the framing. A straight line motion is thus impressed on the crosshead. The air-pump is attached to the “parallel” point in an extra parallelogram obtained from the centre of the beam. A plunger and a bucket-pump are driven directly from the beam. Steam is distributed by a piston valve actuated by a countershaft which is driven by an eccentric on the crankshaft. A Watt governor controls the throttle valve. The hand-wheels for controlling the engine are grouped on a platform.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1869–63, 19,278.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 116.
Object name: DRAWING (Scale 1: 8) AND PHOTOGRAPHS OF FAIRBAIRN & CO.'S DOUBLE-COLUMNAR ENGINES.
Maker/Donor: Presented by A. J. Hill, Esq., C.B.E.
Date of creation: 1922.
Object entry information: Two high-pressure single-cylinder vertical engines of the form introduced by William Fairbairn are here combined to drive one overhead shaft. The engines were built by Messrs. William Fairbairn & Co., of Manchester, about 1840, for the railway locomotive shops at Norwich, and remained in use till 1922, when electric motors were substituted for the duty.
The framing is in the form of a hollow column resting on a box from which the cylinder depends. The box is supported by two cast-iron girders which are built into the wall of the engine house, thus doing away with the necessity for heavy foundations and economising space. The cylinders are 12.6 in. diam. (bored out from 12 in.) by 30 in. stroke. The slide valve is of the loco. pattern actuated by an eccentric; the exhaust is carried away below the floor. Speed is controlled by a Watt governor to each cylinder driven by bevel gear from the crankshaft and acting upon a butterfly valve in the steam pipe. As fitted, each cylinder could run alone, e.g., when shops were not on full load or when repairs were necessary. In 1920 this contingency did arise owing to a breakdown, and for a week the engine worked satisfactorily with one cylinder. The stop valve is worked by a handle placed close to the column. At 41 r.p.m. and boiler pressure of 125 lb. per sq. in. the estimated h.p. was 145. The spur fly-wheel is 10 ft. 2.5 in. diam. at the pitch line, giving 92 r.p.m. on the shop shafting.
These engines were made in sizes from 6 to 30 h.p., the boiler pressure being about 60 lb. per sq. in.
(See Fairbairn—Mills and Millwork, Pt. I., 246.)
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1922–293 & 294.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 117.
Object name: DRAWING OF MCNAUGHTED BEAM ENGINE. (Scale 1: 16).
Maker/Donor: Presented by Messrs. Petrie & McNaught, 1923.
Date of creation: 1923.
Object entry information: In many factories, where the then standard beam engine had been installed during the early part of the 19th century, the need for greater power was experienced as time went on. In 1845 Mr. John McNaught patented a means of meeting this need with a minimum of expense. He compounded the existing engine by the addition of a high-pressure cylinder at the other end of the beam between the gudgeons and the crankshaft. This was usually possible because existing scantling was generally capable of sustaining the additional stress involved. The practice, admittedly a stop-gap, was known as “McNaughting” and was extensively followed. In the drawing the added parts are indicated by thickened lines.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1923–535.

A straight line motion is thus impressed on the crosshead. The air-pump is attached to the “parallel” point in an extra parallelogram obtained from the centre of the beam. A plunger and a bucket-pump are driven directly from the beam. Steam is distributed by a piston valve actuated by a countershaft which is driven by an eccentric on the crankshaft. A Watt governor controls the throttle valve. The hand-wheels for controlling the engine are grouped on a platform.

Object name: DRAWING (Scale 1: 8) AND PHOTOGRAPHS OF FAIRBAIRN & CO.'S DOUBLE-COLUMNAR ENGINES.
Maker/Donor: Presented by A. J. Hill, Esq., C.B.E.
Object entry information:
Two high-pressure single-cylinder vertical engines of the form introduced by William Fairbairn are here combined to drive one overhead shaft. The engines were built by Messrs. William Fairbairn & Co., of Manchester, about 1840, for the railway locomotive shops at Norwich, and remained in use till 1922, when electric motors were substituted for the duty.
The framing is in the form of a hollow column resting on a box from which the cylinder depends. The box is supported by two cast-iron girders which are built into the wall of the engine house, thus doing away with the necessity for heavy foundations and economising space. The cylinders are 12.6 in. diam. (bored out from 12 in.) by 30 in. stroke. The slide valve is of the loco. pattern actuated by an eccentric; the exhaust is carried away below the floor. Speed is controlled by a Watt governor to each cylinder driven by bevel gear from the crankshaft and acting upon a butterfly valve in the steam pipe. As fitted, each cylinder could run alone, e.g., when shops were not on full load or when repairs were necessary. In 1920 this contingency did arise owing to a breakdown, and for a week the engine worked satisfactorily with one cylinder. The stop valve is worked by a handle placed close to the column. At 41 r.p.m. and boiler pressure of 125 lb. per sq. in. the estimated h.p. was 145. The spur fly-wheel is 10 ft. 2.5 in. diam. at the pitch line, giving 92 r.p.m. on the shop shafting.
These engines were made in sizes from 6 to 30 h.p., the boiler pressure being about 60 lb. per sq. in.
(See Fairbairn—Mills and Millwork, Pt. I., 246.)

Object entry information: 16 in. stroke, and the piston rod is connected to a beam about four times the length of the stroke. The centre of the beam is constrained by two bridles attached to the framing and thus a straight line motion is impressed on the crosshead. The other end of the beam is pivoted on two long rocking links and it is the fancied appearance of these in motion which gave rise to the name of the engine.
This particular example was used in the Royal Horticultural Gardens from about 1840 till 1870 when it was moved to the Royal Albert Hall. Its duty in both places was to pump water from an artesian well. As arranged in the last place the crankshaft was connected by a claw clutch and bevel gearing, in the ratio of 3 : 1, to a three-throw bore hole pump, 9 in. stroke, lifting from a depth of about 90 ft. The steam pressure was 50 lb. by gauge.

Object name: MODEL OF GRASSHOPPER OR HALF-BEAM ENGINE (working). (Scale about 1 : 12.)
Maker/Donor: N/A

Object entry information: The grasshopper engine, so named from its peculiar motion (see No. 114), has been known also as the half-beam engine.
The cylinder is vertical and its piston-rod is connected with a crosshead whence two connecting rods return to a double-throw crankshaft below. The crosshead is fixed in one end of the beam, the other end being pivoted on two rocking links; the centre of the beam is constrained by two bridles, half the length of the beam, attached to the framing. A straight line motion is thus impressed on the crosshead. The air-pump is attached to the “parallel” point in an extra parallelogram obtained from the centre of the beam. A plunger and a bucket-pump are driven directly from the beam. Steam is distributed by a piston valve actuated by a countershaft which is driven by an eccentric on the crankshaft. A Watt governor controls the throttle valve. The hand-wheels for controlling the engine are grouped on a platform.

Catalogue number: 117.
Object name: DRAWING OF MCNAUGHTED BEAM ENGINE. (Scale 1: 16).
Maker/Donor: Presented by Messrs. Petrie & McNaught, 1923.
Date of creation: 1923.
Object entry information: In many factories, where the then standard beam engine had been installed during the early part of the 19th century, the need for greater power was experienced as time went on. In 1845 Mr. John McNaught patented a means of meeting this need with a minimum of expense. He compounded the existing engine by the addition of a high-pressure cylinder at the other end of the beam between the gudgeons and the crankshaft. This was usually possible because existing scantling was generally capable of sustaining the additional stress involved. The practice, admittedly a stop-gap, was known as “McNaughting” and was extensively followed. In the drawing the added parts are indicated by thickened lines.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1923–535.

title: Black line print of "McNaughted" Beam Engine
description: Black line print of "McNaughted" Beam Engine, Scale 1:16

Maker/Donor: Contributed by J. Warriner, Esq. / Patented by Mr. J. Milner
Object entry information: This design for a two-stage expansion engine was patented by Mr. J. Milner in 1853. The cylinders are side by side, with the valve chests between them, and the cranks at right angles. Reversal is effected by loose eccentrics, and a piston-valve which inter-changes the exhaust and steam passages. The steam is first admitted into the smaller cylinder and is cut off at half stroke; it is then led to the larger cylinder whose piston is at the commence- ment of its stroke. While the piston is at the end of its stroke, this steam will have been doing work while expanding to a volume equal to that of the low- pressure cylinder and half the high pressure. This method of working causes, however, an exceptional temperature range in the high-pressure cylinder.

Maker/Donor: Contributed by J. Warriner, Esq. / Patented by Mr. J. Milner
Date of creation: 1857. / 1853 (patent)
Object entry information: This design for a two-stage expansion engine was patented by Mr. J. Milner in 1853. The cylinders are side by side, with the valve chests between them, and the cranks at right angles. Reversal is effected by loose eccentrics, and a piston-valve which inter-changes the exhaust and steam passages. Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 119.
Object name: SECTIONAL MODEL OF THREE-CYLINDER ENGINE.
Maker/Donor: Presented by G. L. Fuller, Esq. / Mr. Fuller (patent)
Date of creation: 1893. / 1853 (patent)
Object entry information: This three-cylinder engine was patented by Mr. Fuller in 1853. It would now be described as a two-stage expansion engine with one high-pressure and two low-pressure cylinders. The cranks are equally spaced at 120 deg., this arrangement being adopted with the intention of obtaining uniform turning moment. In the model the central cylinder is the high-pressure one; by using two low-pressure cylinders a single cylinder of inconveniently large dimensions is avoided. Into the ports are fitted cylindrical plug-valves, by rotating which the distribution of the steam to the cylinders can be varied. To assist in following the action, the high-pressure steam ports and spaces are coloured red and the low-pressure black.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1893–173.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 120.
Object name: VERTICAL ENGINE (working). Maudslay Collection.
Maker/Donor: Made by Messrs. Maudslay, Sons and Field
Date of creation: 1900. / 1862 (International Exhibition)
Object entry information: This single-cylinder pedestal engine was made by Messrs. Maudslay, Sons and Field for driving their collection of models at the International Exhibition of 1862. The cylinder is 4 1/4 in. diam. by 4.5 in. stroke, and is provided with a jacket through which the exhaust steam passes on its way to the condenser. The guides are cylindrical bars, and the main crankshaft bearings are carried by the pedestal. The steam is distributed by an ordinary slide-valve, driven by a single eccentric, which also works the feed pump. The condenser and hot- well are arranged in the base, within which is also a vertical air-pump driven by an additional crank in the crankshaft. The speed is regulated by a belt- driven Watt governor, carried on the top of the cylinder casing and control- ling the steam supply by a disc throttle-valve. The feed delivery pipe is fitted with a weighted relief valve, so that when the feed pipe of the boiler is closed the water pumped can return to the hot-well.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1900–26.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 121.
Object name: MODEL OF HORIZONTAL STEAM ENGINE. (Scale 1: 6.)
Maker/Donor: Made by J. B. Jordan, Esq. / Mr. Jordan
Date of creation: 1865.
Object entry information: This form of high-pressure engine was designed by Mr. Jordan, and used in the Clunes Gold Mines, Australia, for driving stamps. It has a cast-iron bed, supporting the cylinder and guides, together with two bearings of the crankshaft. Two equal fly-wheels are provided and are intended to be used as travelling wheels in conveying the engine to its destination, a temporary forecarriage being arranged under the cylinder end for the journey.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1895–54.

Object entry information: This sectional model represents one of two engines, 8 in. diam. by 10 in. stroke and of 8 h.p., which were used at the Royal Albert Hall from 1871 till 1909 to drive two ventilating fans. They were constructed by Mr. J. Robertson under his patent of 1868. A connecting rod is dispensed with, as the cross-head actuates the crank- disc directly by sliding through a ball socketed eccentrically within it. This mechanism gives to the piston-rod and piston a helical motion which is made use of to distribute the steam. To this end, the piston is made so much longer

Catalogue number: 118.
Object name: DIAGRAM MODEL OF COMPOUND ENGINE. (Scale 1: 4.)
Maker/Donor: Contributed by J. Warriner, Esq. / Patented by Mr. J. Milner
Date of creation: 1857. / 1853 (patent)
Object entry information: This design for a two-stage expansion engine was patented by Mr. J. Milner in 1853. The cylinders are side by side, with the valve chests between them, and the cranks at right angles. Reversal is effected by loose eccentrics, and a piston-valve which inter-changes the exhaust and steam passages. The steam is first admitted into the smaller cylinder and is cut off at half stroke; it is then led to the larger cylinder whose piston is at the commence- ment of its stroke. While the piston is at the end of its stroke, this steam will have been doing work while expanding to a volume equal to that of the low- pressure cylinder and half the high pressure. This method of working causes, however, an exceptional temperature range in the high-pressure cylinder.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1857–20.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 119.
Object name: SECTIONAL MODEL OF THREE-CYLINDER ENGINE.
Maker/Donor: Presented by G. L. Fuller, Esq. / Mr. Fuller (patent)
Date of creation: 1893. / 1853 (patent)
Object entry information: This three-cylinder engine was patented by Mr. Fuller in 1853. It would now be described as a two-stage expansion engine with one high-pressure and two low-pressure cylinders. The cranks are equally spaced at 120 deg., this arrangement being adopted with the intention of obtaining uniform turning moment. In the model the central cylinder is the high-pressure one; by using two low-pressure cylinders a single cylinder of inconveniently large dimensions is avoided. Into the ports are fitted cylindrical plug-valves, by rotating which the distribution of the steam to the cylinders can be varied. To assist in following the action, the high-pressure steam ports and spaces are coloured red and the low-pressure black.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1893–173.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 120.
Object name: VERTICAL ENGINE (working). Maudslay Collection.
Maker/Donor: Made by Messrs. Maudslay, Sons and Field
Date of creation: 1900. / 1862 (International Exhibition)
Object entry information: This single-cylinder pedestal engine was made by Messrs. Maudslay, Sons and Field for driving their collection of models at the International Exhibition of 1862. The cylinder is 4 1/4 in. diam. by 4.5 in. stroke, and is provided with a jacket through which the exhaust steam passes on its way to the condenser. The guides are cylindrical bars, and the main crankshaft bearings are carried by the pedestal. The steam is distributed by an ordinary slide-valve, driven by a single eccentric, which also works the feed pump. The condenser and hot- well are arranged in the base, within which is also a vertical air-pump driven by an additional crank in the crankshaft. The speed is regulated by a belt- driven Watt governor, carried on the top of the cylinder casing and control- ling the steam supply by a disc throttle-valve. The feed delivery pipe is fitted with a weighted relief valve, so that when the feed pipe of the boiler is closed the water pumped can return to the hot-well.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1900–26.

Object entry information: This sectional model represents one of two engines, 8 in. diam. by 10 in. stroke and of 8 h.p., which were used at the Royal Albert Hall from 1871 till 1909 to drive two ventilating fans. Catalogue number: 123.
Object name: MODEL OF HORIZONTAL ENGINE. (Scale 1: 3.) Lent
Maker/Donor: by Killingworth W. Hedges, Esq.
Date of creation: 1913.
Object entry information: This model represents current practice in 1869 in horizontal engine construction by Messrs. Easton and Amos. It has a box girder bed with the cylinder and crankshaft brackets bolted to it. There are two guide bars in the vertical axial plane, the connecting rod having a long forked small end. The speed is controlled by a Porter governor (see No. 235).
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1913–495.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 124.
Object name: DRAWINGS OF DOUBLE-CYLINDER ENGINES. (Scale 1: 24.)
Maker/Donor: Presented by J. Bernays, Esq.
Date of creation: 1906.
Object entry information: This compact form of engine (see No. 113) was re-invented by Mr. Bernays in 1874 with a simple and efficient valve gear, but built only to a limited extent; it has, however, since been used for both stationary and marine engines (see No. 125). The arrangement consists of two vertical cylinders, which may be compounded, placed side by side with the crankshaft above or between them. The piston-rod ends are connected by links with the ends of the base of a triangular frame, the apex of which embraces the crankpin, while the middle point of the base is guided in a straight line. The valve gear consists of a single eccentric, the strap of which has two connecting pins forming the corners of the base of a similar triangle which is controlled in the same way as the other triangle; each of the pins drives one valve. One of the designs shown is for a compound mill engine having cylinders 30 in. and 45 in. diam. by 50 in. stroke, to indicate 500 h.p. at 45 r.p.m. with a steam pressure of 50 lb. per sq. in. It has a Meyer expansion valve on the high-pressure cylinder, and the air-pump is driven by a lever from the middle of the triangle base. The other design represents a blowing engine having two steam cylinders 30 in. diam. and two air cylinders 72 in. diam., the common stroke being 70 in. The air cylinders are placed vertically below the steam cylinders and there is very little framework. In both designs crosshead guides are dispensed with on account of the small obliquity of the connecting-rod links.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1906–109.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 125.
Object name: DOUBLE-CYLINDER ENGINE (working). Made by Messrs. John Musgrave and Sons, Ltd.
Maker/Donor: Messrs. John Musgrave and Sons, Ltd.
Date of creation: 1893.
Object entry information: This is a small example of an engine differing only slightly from the preceding (Nos. 113 and 126). Two cylinders, arranged side by side, have a common connecting-rod in the form of a triangle, the apex of which encloses the pin of the overhanging crank. The two other corners of the triangle are, by very short links, connected respectively with the two piston-rods, the crossheads of which slide in ordinary guides. From the middle of the top of the triangle two bridle-rods couple the connecting-rod to a stationary centre on the side of the framing, and so restrict the movement and close the chain. The valves are in the form of cylindrical slides, and receive their motion from a common eccentric. The example has 3 in. cylinders, with 4 in. stroke, and is intended to run at 300 r.p.m., when it will indicate about 3 h.p.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1893–176, 19,602.

Object entry information: This is a compact form of direct-acting engine in which a connecting-rod is dispensed with, the piston-rod being directly connected with the crankpin by a block sliding in a transverse slot formed in the crosshead. This arrangement is sometimes known as a "dog-crank," and it has been much used for feed pumps. The cylinder is 4 in. diam. by 4.5 in. stroke, and is placed vertically on a bedplate which also serves as the bottom cover. The crosshead is very wide, above the cylinder in bearings cast on the top cover. The crosshead is very wide, and is formed of two gunmetal bars bolted together with distance pieces between their ends, the latter also acting as slipper blocks, which slide on two round guide bars rising from the bedplate and tied together at the top. A steel block, made in halves, embraces the crankpin and fits in the crosshead slot, so that as the crank revolves the block slides along the slot through a distance equal to the stroke of the crank. The arrangement allows the engine to be very short, but it introduces large bending stresses in the piston-rod, which is, therefore, made of large diameter. Mechanically the arrangement is equivalent to a connecting-rod of infinite length, and the piston has a simple harmonic motion. An ordinary slide-valve is used, operated by a disc crank on one end of the shaft, and a fly-wheel is mounted on the other end of the shaft.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1913–304, S.M. 560.

Catalogue number: 128.
Object name: SAFETY STEAM MOTOR.
Maker/Donor: Lent by Messrs. Hathorn, Davey & Co.
Date of creation: 1888.
Object entry information: This combined arrangement of boiler and condensing steam engine was patented by Mr. H. Davey in 1884 and introduced as a domestic motor, since owing to the boiler working at atmospheric pressure no explosion is possible through neglect or unskilled attendance. The steam cylinder is double-acting, and is arranged vertically within the steam space of the boiler; the steam is distributed by a slide-valve driven by an eccentric on the crankshaft, and the supply is controlled by a throttle-valve connected with a centrifugal governor. The furnace, boiler, and surface condenser are all formed in one casting, and the firebox is crossed by a deep water pocket. The level of the water within the boiler is visible through a glass window in a feed box on the side, which contains a copper float that automatically admits water as required. The surface condenser is provided with vertical tubes, with the cooling water, which may be stored in the containing casing or in a detached tank, circulating outside them; it is cleared by an air pump of the vertical plunger type driven by an overhanging crankpin on the fly-wheel shaft. It is stated that the consumption of coke is about 6 lb. per h.p. per hour.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1888–182, 19,943.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 129.
Object name: THREE-CYLINDER ENGINE (working).
Maker/Donor: Lent by P. Brotherhood, Esq.
Date of creation: 1888.
Object entry information: This type of steam engine is designed for conditions requiring a high speed and great compactness in the mechanism, and is largely used for driving dynamos and fans, also the propellers of the Whitehead torpedo—in this latter case using compressed air. The three cylinders are single-acting and arranged at 120 deg. round the common crankpin, have spherical small ends, which work in a cup formed upon which fit pistons fitted with metallic packing, there being no piston-rods. The cylinders being single-acting, there is no reversal of stress in the connecting rods, so that slackness in the connecting-rod brasses does not cause a heavy knock, as would be the the case in a double-acting engine—a circumstance which is conducive to quiet working at high speeds. The crank chamber is closed and retains a quantity of lubricant—an arrangement which prevents the dust and grit from getting into the working parts, and also economises oil. The crank is of the overhanging type, with a counterbalance weight, and the pin drives a small crank-arm connected with the valve gear. Steam is distributed to the cylinders by three piston-valves driven by a crankpin, the valve motion for each cylinder being equivalent to that in an ordinary engine.
Object/Inventory number: N/A

Catalogue number: 130.
Object name: MODEL OF HORIZONTAL STEAM ENGINE (working). (Scale 1 : 4.)
Maker/Donor: Messers. R. Hornsby & Sons.
Date of creation: 1885.
Object entry information: This represents a high-pressure engine, with a steam-jacketed cylinder supported throughout its length on a cast-iron bed. The guides are cast with the bed and bored out, the crankpin is attached to an overhanging crankplate and the outer end of the crankshaft is carried by an independent bearing. The engine is fitted with a governor gear that automatically adjusts the degree of expansion to the work being done. On the crankshaft are three eccentrics, but one of these is solely used for working the feed pump. The others drive the main slide-valve and the "back cut-off" or expansion-valve. The travel of the expansion-valve is determined by the position of a block in a rocking link, and this position is adjusted by the governor. When the governor rises it rotates the sheave of a small eccentric connected with it, and by this means moves the block along the link; as an eccentric is a non-reversible means of transmitting motion it is here introduced to prevent pressure from the link interfering with the action of the governor. The cylinder is 12.25 in. diam. by 22 in. stroke ; when the engine is supplied with steam at 60 lb. pressure and is making 95 r.p.m., it indicates 50 h.p. ; the same design was followed for engines with cylinders up to 22 in. diam. by 40 in. stroke indicating 185 h.p.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1885–123, 19,274 and 19,366.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 131.
Object name: ARMINGTON–SIMS ENGINE.
Maker/Donor: Messers. Greenwood and Batley.
Date of creation: 1889.
Object entry information: This is an example of a high-speed horizontal engine of American design. The cylinder, which is 5 in. diam. by 7 in. stroke, is overhung and is finished externally by polished metal lagging covering the flanges as well as the usual non-conducting felt. The crank is formed with two counterbalanced discs, and there are also two fly-wheels, while the crankshaft has exceptionally long bearings ; the crank race is, moreover, enclosed by a cast-iron box, which retains any oil thrown off, and also carries the crankpin lubricator, these various arrangements being resorted to on account of the high speed employed. The slide valve is of the piston type, with the steam space in the middle, as was usual in the early long D valves ; it is driven, through a rocking shaft, by an eccentric of variable throw within one of the fly-wheels. The governor, which is arranged within this fly-wheel, consists of two heavy swinging levers pinned to opposite arms of the fly-wheel, and pulled inward by helical springs. When the levers swing outward, through centrifugal action, they turn the main eccentric and also an eccentric carrying it, moving them in opposite directions, so that the main eccentric is shifted along an approximately straight line, the cut-off being thereby altered while the lead remains nearly constant.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1888–236.

Object name: SECTIONAL MODELS OF HIGH-SPEED ENGINE AND DYNAMO (working). (Scale 1 : 4.)

Object entry information: This type of engine was patented by Mr. P. W. Willans in 1884 ; with subsequent modifications it was extensively adopted for the direct driving of dynamos. The engine is of the single-acting, two-stage expansion type with two high-pressure cylinders and two low-pressure ones, arranged with the high pressures above, and all acting on a two-throw crankshaft with the cranks 180 deg. apart. The guide or crosshead for the small end of each connecting rod is in the form of a trunk, working in a closed cylinder that acts as an air cushion ; by this arrangement, combined with single-acting cylinders, the pressures on the brasses of the crankpins and shaft are never reversed, so that slack bearings are permissible without any knock resulting, to which feature the high working speed found practicable is chiefly due. The steam distribution to each pair of tandem cylinders is effected by a long piston-valve, extending through a trunk which serves as the piston-rod of the two pistons whilst also acting internally as a valve by its passage through the

On the crankshaft are three eccentrics, but one of these is solely used for working the feed pump. The others drive the main slide-valve and the "back cut-off" or expansion-valve. The travel of the expansion-valve is determined by the position of a block in a rocking link, and this position is adjusted by the governor. When the governor rises it rotates the sheave of a small eccentric connected with it, and by this means moves the block along the link; as an eccentric is a non-reversible means of transmitting motion it is here introduced to prevent pressure from the link interfering with the action of the governor. The cylinder is 12.25 in. diam. by 22 in. stroke ; when the engine is supplied with steam at 60 lb. pressure and is making 95 r.p.m., it indicates 50 h.p. ; the same design was followed for engines with cylinders up to 22 in. diam. by 40 in. stroke indicating 185 h.p.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1885–123, 19,274 and 19,366.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 131.
Object name: ARMINGTON–SIMS ENGINE.
Maker/Donor: Messers. Greenwood and Batley.
Date of creation: 1889.
Object entry information: This is an example of a high-speed horizontal engine of American design. The cylinder, which is 5 in. diam. by 7 in. stroke, is overhung and is finished externally by polished metal lagging covering the flanges as well as the usual non-conducting felt. The crank is formed with two counterbalanced discs, and there are also two fly-wheels, while the crankshaft has exceptionally long bearings ; the crank race is, moreover, enclosed by a cast-iron box, which retains any oil thrown off, and also carries the crankpin lubricator, these various arrangements being resorted to on account of the high speed employed. The slide valve is of the piston type, with the steam space in the middle, as was usual in the early long D valves ; it is driven, through a rocking shaft, by an eccentric of variable throw within one of the fly-wheels. The governor, which is arranged within this fly-wheel, consists of two heavy swinging levers pinned to opposite arms of the fly-wheel, and pulled inward by helical springs. When the levers swing outward, through centrifugal action, they turn the main eccentric and also an eccentric carrying it, moving them in opposite directions, so that the main eccentric is shifted along an approximately straight line, the cut-off being thereby altered while the lead remains nearly constant.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1888–236.

Object name: SECTIONAL MODELS OF HIGH-SPEED ENGINE AND DYNAMO (working). (Scale 1 : 4.)
Maker/Donor: Received.
Date of creation: 1901.
Object entry information: This type of engine was patented by Mr. P. W. Willans in 1884 ; with subsequent modifications it was extensively adopted for the direct driving of dynamos. The engine is of the single-acting, two-stage expansion type with two high-pressure cylinders and two low-pressure ones, arranged with the high pressures above, and all acting on a two-throw crankshaft with the cranks 180 deg. apart. The guide or crosshead for the small end of each connecting rod is in the form of a trunk, working in a closed cylinder that acts as an air cushion ; by this arrangement, combined with single-acting cylinders, the pressures on the brasses of the crankpins and shaft are never reversed, so that slack bearings are permissible without any knock resulting, to which feature the high working speed found practicable is chiefly due. The steam distribution to each pair of tandem cylinders is effected by a long piston-valve, extending through a trunk which serves as the piston-rod of the two pistons whilst also acting internally as a valve by its passage through the

Catalogue number: 133.
Object name: SECTIONAL MODEL OF HIGH-SPEED ENGINE (working).
Maker/Donor: Mr. N. Chandler (patented by)
Date of creation: 1886-8 (patent date)
Object entry information: This represents a single-acting, inverted, two-stage expansion engine for directly driving a large fan for mine ventilation (see Pumps Section), or other purposes. The engine was patented by Mr. N. Chandler in 1886-8, and subsequently improved; the two cylinders are arranged tandem fashion, with the high pressure above, so that there is a single piston-rod acting downward upon a crankshaft below, while the steam distribution is performed by two piston-valves similarly arranged and driven by a single eccentric. The cylinders are cast on a frame which contains guides for the piston and valve-rods, and the bearings for the crankshaft; it also forms a closed chamber in which the oil is retained and distributed over the bearings by the motion of the revolving parts, access to it being, however, obtainable by side doors.
A special feature of this engine is the construction of the "sleeve" at the lower end of the valve, by which, while permitting the passage of the exhaust steam through itself, the valve can close the exhaust port, thus giving comparatively quietly the momentum of the moving parts and assist them on their return stroke. The action of the steam in the engine is as follows:—Boiler steam is admitted above the high-pressure piston, which then makes a down stroke; in the next up stroke this steam is allowed to pass to the under side of the high-pressure piston and into a receiver, from which, in the next down stroke, it is admitted to the top side of the low-pressure piston; from this, at about the completion of this down stroke, it is discharged into the exhaust pipe, or condenser, with which the lower side of the piston is in communication, except when the cushioning at the end of the stroke is taking place. Received 1902.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1902-130.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 134.
Object name: MODEL OF DOUBLE-ACTING STEAM ENGINE.
Maker/Donor: Lent by J. Cawley, Esq., 1921. (Engine introduced by Mr. G. Cawley)
Date of creation: 1921 (Lent date) / 1895 (Engine introduction)
Object entry information: This shows a form of self-contained reciprocating engine introduced by Mr. G. Cawley in 1895.
The piston is of exceptional length, being two single-acting pistons cast together; the connecting member contains a transverse slot in which works a block encircling the crankpin. The crank is of the bent type and, with the block, is got into position through the side of the cylinder by an opening that is closed by a cover which contains one of the crankshaft bearings. Steam is distributed by a rotating slide-valve attached to the inner end of the crankshaft. This example was designed to work suspended, and has its steam or compressed air supplied through a flexible pipe.
Drawing of double-acting steam engine. Lent by G. Cawley, Esq., 1895.
This serves to elucidate the model further.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1921-86. / Inv. 1895-51.

The horizontal engine represented was made by Messrs. Musgrave for driving a jute mill in Calcutta; its cylinder is 19 in. diam. by 36 in. stroke, and the fly-wheel, which is 12 ft. in diam., weighs 5.75 tons. The power is transmitted from the fly-wheel by eleven ropes 1.25 in. diam., which drive the line shafting of the various floors of the factory. The crankshaft neck is 7.5 in. diam. by 15 in. long, and its bearing is composed of four brasses which can be separately adjusted; the outer bearing of this shaft is, however, of the simple two-piece type. When supplied with steam at 80 lb. pressure and running at 80 r.p.m., the engine indicates 120 h.p.; if fitted with a condenser such an engine would economically exert 140 h.p.

title: Drawing of Cawleys double acting steam engine
description: Drawing of Cawleys double acting steam engine

Object entry information: The valve gear is of the “Corliss” type, and under the control of the governor; it alters the degree of expansion to meet variations in the load, without the intervention of any throttle-valve, and as usually set the speed does not vary more than 2.5 per cent. from no load to full load. The adjacent diagram shows how the point of “cut-off” changes with the slight alteration in the governor speeds. The original Corliss valve gear was invented in 1849 by Mr. G. H. Corliss; not being an engineer he experienced exceptional difficulty in getting his invention tried, but the results obtained with it ultimately led to its very extensive adoption; the first Corliss engine in Europe was that shown at the Paris Exhibition in 1867. The leading features of the arrangement are: the employment of separate steam and exhaust valves at each end of the cylinder, so that any alteration of the point at which steam is cut off can be made without interfering with the action of the exhaust valves; the valves are cylindrical, and each is capable of being separately adjusted. The two exhaust valves, which are at the bottom of the cylinder, are rocked by a single eccentric, while the two steam-valves at the top are rocked by another eccentric. The steam eccentric swings an arm provided with a cylindrical end, upon which are two hardened steel plates; as the arm swings, these plates engage with similar plates attached to flat levers that proceed from cranks on the spindles of the two steam-valves. As the arm reciprocates, the steam-valves are alternately opened, but, at certain points, determined by the speed of the governor, the lever of the steam-valve then opening slips off the corresponding driving plate; the valve then left free is rapidly turned into a closed position by the action of a helical spring. The spring is contained in a small cylinder provided with two air “dash-pots” by which the quick closing motion is quietly arrested; this sharp and automatically adjusted cut-off is now to be found in all modern “trip” gears. The governor shown is of the high speed loaded type, and has its sensitiveness adjustable by means of a spring which is contained within the central weight; it is driven by three cotton ropes, but further to reduce the risk of the engine running away through the governor stopping, an independent gear is fitted, so that if, after the engine has been started, the speed of the governor falls below a certain limit, a trigger releases a weighted lever which automatically stops the engine through its valve gear.

Object entry information: The valve gear is of the “Corliss” type, and under the control of the governor; it alters the degree of expansion to meet variations in the load, without the intervention of any throttle-valve, and as usually set the speed does not vary more than 2.5 per cent. from no load to full load. The adjacent diagram shows how the point of “cut-off” changes with the slight alteration in the governor speeds. The original Corliss valve gear was invented in 1849 by Mr. G. H. Corliss; not being an engineer he experienced exceptional difficulty in getting his invention tried, but the results obtained with it ultimately led to its very extensive adoption; the first Corliss engine in Europe was that shown at the Paris Exhibition in 1867. The leading features of the arrangement are: the employment of separate steam and exhaust valves at each end of the cylinder, so that any alteration of the point at which steam is cut off can be made without interfering with the action of the exhaust valves; the valves are cylindrical, and each is capable of being separately adjusted. The two exhaust valves, which are at the bottom of the cylinder, are rocked by a single eccentric, while the two steam-valves at the top are rocked by another eccentric. The steam eccentric swings an arm provided with a cylindrical end, upon which are two hardened steel plates; as the arm swings, these plates engage with similar plates attached to flat levers that proceed from cranks on the spindles of the two steam-valves. As the arm reciprocates, the steam-valves are alternately opened, but, at certain points, determined by the speed of the governor, the lever of the steam-valve then opening slips off the corresponding driving plate; the valve then left free is rapidly turned into a closed position by the action of a helical spring. The spring is contained in a small cylinder provided with two air “dash-pots” by which the quick closing motion is quietly arrested; this sharp and automatically adjusted cut-off is now to be found in all modern “trip” gears. The governor shown is of the high speed loaded type, and has its sensitiveness adjustable by means of a spring which is contained within the central weight; it is driven by three cotton ropes, but further to reduce the risk of the engine running away through the governor stopping, an independent gear is fitted, so that if, after the engine has been started, the speed of the governor falls below a certain limit, a trigger releases a weighted lever which automatically stops the engine through its valve gear.

Object name: MODEL OF HORIZONTAL TANDEM COMPOUND ENGINE (working). (Scale 1: 12.)
Maker/Donor: Made by Adam Gilbert, Esq.
Date of creation: Received 1910.
Object entry information: This represents a very common type of compound condensing mill engine having the two cylinders arranged in line and the piston-rods driving a single overhung crank. The cylinders are mounted on one bedplate, and the front cylinder is connected with the main crankshaft bearing by a girder frame in which the bored crosshead guides are formed. The shaft carries a grooved fly-wheel; a crank disc is fixed to its front end and its rear end is supported on a separate pedestal bearing. The high-pressure cylinder is fitted with double-beat inlet-valves actuated by the variable expansion trip gear patented by Dr. W. R. Proell in 1881. In this arrangement, a horizontal lever, oscillated by an eccentric, has suspended at each end a bell-crank lever; the vertical arms of the bell-cranks have notches at their lower ends, which, in their downward motion, catch upon and depress the ends of short pivoted levers which are connected with the valve spindles. The motion of the rocking lever brings the horizontal arm of the bell-cranks periodically into contact with a horizontal plate, the position of which is controlled by the governor; this causes the notches to slip off the valve levers and allows the valves to close sharply under the action of springs and dash-pots mounted above them. If the speed increases the plate will rise and the valves will close earlier in the stroke. The exhaust-valves are of the “Corliss” type (see No. 135). The low-pressure cylinder has Corliss inlet and exhaust-valves, and the inlet valves have a hand adjusted trip gear of the modified “Reynolds” type. A wrist plate, loose on the valve spindle, carries a spring catch, which engages with an arm on the valve spindle; the wrist plate is oscillated by an eccentric and, at a certain point of the motion, the catch is disengaged from the valve arm by a fixed roller, so releasing the valve, which closes under the action of a spring and dash-pot. The positions of the releasing rollers are adjusted by hand. One eccentric serves for all the inlet-valves and another for the exhaust-valves. Catalogue number: 137.
Object name: MODEL OF VERTICAL ENGINE WITH HACKWORTH'S VALVE GEAR (working). (Scale 1: 6.)
Maker/Donor: Made by Messrs. T. & C. J. Coates, from drawings supplied by the Brush Electrical Engineering Co., and Messrs. R. & W. Hawthorn, Leslie & Co.,
Date of creation: 1898.
Object entry information: Plate IV., No. 2. In its general arrangements and details this model represents one of the two-stage expansion engines supplied by the Brush Co. to the City Road electric light station. The cylinders are 13.25 in. and 23.5 in. diam. respectively by 13.5 in. stroke, and are both steam jacketed. When supplied with steam at 100 lb. pressure and delivering into a surface condenser the engine indicates 300 h.p. at 240 r.p.m. The fly-wheel is 7.5 ft. effective diam. and has 10 grooves for 1.25 in. diam. rope, by which a dynamo is driven. The model deviates from the actual engine in that it does not show the second valve chest to the high-pressure cylinder, the valve of which is driven by an eccentric on the crankshaft controlled by a governor contained within a small fly-wheel. The high-pressure slide-valves are of the double ported piston type, while the low-pressure valve is of the D-slide class; all have vertical balance cylinders above them. The exhaust-valve of the high-pressure cylinder and the single valve of the low-pressure are actuated by the arrangement of valve gear shown in the low-pressure portion of the model. Both of the valve motions represented were patented in 1859 by Mr. J. W. Hackworth, of Darlington; the details of that on the high-pressure cylinder were arranged by Mr. F. C. Marshall, while those of the low-pressure were devised by Mr. J. S. Raworth for an adjustable expansion arrangement only, reversal on electric lighting engines not being required. The Hackworth expansion and reversing gear consists of a single eccentric fixed to the shaft and opposite to the crank arm, from which the eccentric-rod proceeds in a direction approximately at right angles to the piston-rod. The end of the eccentric-rod is caused to move in a straight path, but one of adjustable inclination, while the valve-rod is attached to an intermediate point in the eccentric-rod. The motion directly derived from the eccentric gives the lead, which is constant, while that resulting from the sliding motion of the block in the inclined guide determines the cut-off and also the direction of running.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1898–47, 20,686.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 138.
Object name: MODEL OF UNDERTYPE ENGINE AND BOILER (working). (Scale 1: 8.)
Maker/Donor: Presented by W. L. Wightman, Esq.,
Date of creation: 1923.
Object entry information: This high-pressure two-stage expansion engine with boiler is a type that is self-contained, compact and only requires slight foundations, so that it is much used in factories, particularly abroad. The boiler is of the locomotive type arranged on a bedplate which at the fire-box end serves as a closed ashpit; at the front end the boiler rests on a saddle piece supported by a casting embodying the cylinder in one piece. The valves are of the ordinary locomotive type with eccentrics; usually the engine is not required to reverse, but if it were would be fitted with link motion. The governor is of the Hartnell high-speed type actuating a balanced piston-valve; there is an adjustment for altering slightly the normal speed. On the front of the high-pressure valve chest is an auxiliary valve to allow steam to pass direct to the low-pressure cylinder in order to be able to start in the event of the high-pressure crank stopping on a dead centre. The boiler feed pump is of the plunger type driven by an eccentric. At the scale given above the engine represents generally a maker's standard design having cylinders 8 in. and 14 in. diam. respectively by 16 in. stroke, which would develop at 140 lb. pressure and 135 r.p.m. 48 indicated h.p. In details, however, departures have been made to make the model suitable for working small machines.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1923–670.

Maker/Donor: Lent by Messrs. Robey & Co.
Object entry information: This represents a type of engine and boiler largely used in difficult situations owing to the fact that it is easily transported and needs practically no foundations. The boiler is of the locomotive type, the chief feature of which is the staying of the fire-box (not visible in the model). Instead of the roof stays being supported as usual on the front and the tube plates, they rest on angles riveted inside the outer shell, thus relieving the fire-box of crushing stress; in addition more room for cleaning the crown of the fire-box is given. The top and sides of the fire-box are each one steel plate, planed, drilled in position and riveted hydraulically. The fire-box is mounted on channels forming an ashpan, and at the smoke-box end of the boiler the support is a circular pedestal, made to act as a feed tank. The cylinder is bolted to steel flanged seatings riveted to the boiler and is tied to the crankshaft bearings, similarly supported with provision for expansion, by steel stay rods which support the spectacle plate. The valve gear consists of a single eccentric bolted to a slotted disc graduated so that the point of cut-off can be varied from 0.125 to 0.375 with constant lead, and, if necessary, moved over to reverse the direction of rotation. If the engine were required to be frequently reversed, a link motion would be fitted. The governor is of high-speed type controlling an equilibrium valve. Mechanical lubrication is adopted. At the scale indicated above, the model represents an engine with cylinder 12 in. diam. by 16 in. stroke; flywheel 66 in. diam. by 11 in. wide; the engine develops 30–45 h.p. at 120 r.p.m. A number of other sizes and classes of this engine, besides portable and undertype engines (see Power Transmission Section) are made.
