Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 140.
Object name: DRAWING OF WATT'S SEMI-ROTARY ENGINE. (Scale 1: 16.)
Maker/Donor: Prepared in the Museum.
Date of creation: 1897.
Object entry information: This is copied from Watt's patent specification of 1782; in the Watt Garret at Heathfield, however, there is an unfinished model of this engine, which was commenced in 1765 or 1766. The engine has a short horizontal cylinder with a radial piston which can swing through an arc of 240 deg. The lower sector of the cylinder is fitted with a stationary abutment block through which steam is admitted to either side of the piston alternately. Below the cylinders are valve boxes for the distribution of the steam, while beneath these is a jet condenser, and two air pumps which are driven by racks from a pinion on the vibrating shaft. A large spur wheel on this shaft has two racks gearing with it, and these move the rods of the two pit pumps that the engine was designed to work; by this latter arrangement the pump rods mutually counterbalance.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1897–122, 21,053.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 141.
Object name: DRAWING OF WATT'S ROTARY ENGINE, WITH CONDENSER. (Scale 1: 16.)
Maker/Donor: Prepared in the Museum.
Date of creation: 1897.
Object entry information: This is copied from the 1782 patent specification of James Watt, but there is no evidence that he ever constructed such an engine. The drawing shows a piston in the form of a closely-fitting radial arm projecting from an axial shaft in a cylinder. An abutment, arranged as a flap, is hinged, near a recess in the side of the cylinder, and swings while remaining in contact with the piston. Steam is admitted to the chamber on one side of the flap, and so causes an unbalanced pressure upon the radial arm. The arrangement has been re-invented several times, and has been worked out in a practical form (see No. 142).
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1897–122, 21,053.

Maker/Donor: Prepared in the Museum.
Object entry information: This is copied from Watt's patent specification of 1782; in the Watt Garret at Heathfield, however, there is an unfinished model of this engine, which was commenced in 1765 or 1766. The engine has a short horizontal cylinder with a radial piston which can swing through an arc of 240 deg. The lower sector of the cylinder is fitted with a stationary abutment block through which steam is admitted to either side of the piston alternately. Below the cylinders are valve boxes for the distribution of the steam, while beneath these is a jet condenser, and two air pumps which are driven by racks from a pinion on the vibrating shaft. A large spur wheel on this shaft has two racks gearing with it, and these move the rods of the two pit pumps that the engine was designed to work; by this latter arrangement the pump rods mutually counterbalance.

Catalogue number: 139.
Object name: MODEL OF SEMI-PORTABLE OVERTYPE ENGINE (working). (Scale 1: 8.)
Maker/Donor: Lent by Messrs. Robey & Co.
Date of creation: 1920.
Object entry information: This represents a type of engine and boiler largely used in difficult situations owing to the fact that it is easily transported and needs practically no foundations. The boiler is of the locomotive type, the chief feature of which is the staying of the fire-box (not visible in the model). Instead of the roof stays being supported as usual on the front and the tube plates, they rest on angles riveted inside the outer shell, thus relieving the fire-box of crushing stress; in addition more room for cleaning the crown of the fire-box is given. The top and sides of the fire-box are each one steel plate, planed, drilled in position and riveted hydraulically. The fire-box is mounted on channels forming an ashpan, and at the smoke-box end of the boiler the support is a circular pedestal, made to act as a feed tank. The cylinder is bolted to steel flanged seatings riveted to the boiler and is tied to the crankshaft bearings, similarly supported with provision for expansion, by steel stay rods which support the spectacle plate. The valve gear consists of a single eccentric bolted to a slotted disc graduated so that the point of cut-off can be varied from 0.125 to 0.375 with constant lead, and, if necessary, moved over to reverse the direction of rotation. If the engine were required to be frequently reversed, a link motion would be fitted. The governor is of high-speed type controlling an equilibrium valve. Mechanical lubrication is adopted. At the scale indicated above, the model represents an engine with cylinder 12 in. diam. by 16 in. stroke; flywheel 66 in. diam. by 11 in. wide; the engine develops 30–45 h.p. at 120 r.p.m. A number of other sizes and classes of this engine, besides portable and undertype engines (see Power Transmission Section) are made.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1920–63, S.M. 1,226.

Object entry information: port is on one side of the hinge, and the exhaust port on the other. The admission of steam is controlled by a slide valve, actuated by an eccentric on the flywheel shaft, so that the engine could work expansively, and the steam pressure resisting the lifting of the flap would also be greatly reduced, so diminishing the knock. The only point which, however, would always be a serious cause of trouble. The exhaust steam passes down to a jet condenser, provided with a supply of water from a containing tank, from which the injection is admitted through a regulating valve. The air pump which draws the air and water from the condenser and discharges them through a pipe passing out at the end of the tank, is a rotary machine constructed like the engine, driven by spur gearing from the flywheel shaft. Some efforts to prevent leakage have been made by forming grooves in the side of the revolving piston and filling them with soft packing.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 143.
Object name: MODEL OF A ROTARY ENGINE (working).
Maker/Donor: Presented by the Rev. Patrick Bell, LL.D.
Date of creation: 1868.
Object entry information: This engine shows one of the early attempts to obtain rotary motion from the pressure of steam without the intervention of a crank and connecting-rod; almost the same arrangement was proposed in 1838 by Lord Armstrong as a water motor, and an example subsequently constructed gave off 5 h.p. at 30 r.p.m., with an efficiency of 95 per cent. A metal disc is secured to a horizontal axis carried in bearings, and the lower half of the disc is enclosed by a chamber of circular section having its axis a semi-circle. One end of this chamber is closed and provided with a pipe through which steam enters, the exhaust taking place through the open end. The disc is provided with three holes, each fitted with a circular plate turning on an axis radial to the disc, and these plates when set at right angles to the disc become pistons in the lower enclosing chamber. Toothed gearing is arranged to rotate these pistons into the plane of the disc on leaving the cylinder and back again immediately after entering, locking levers retaining them in position during the intervals. The steam pressure upon these pistons forces the disc round, but the engine is non-expansive, and although some provision for packing has been made, the leakage must have been considerable and the wear and tear excessive.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1868–24, 19,371.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 144.
Object name: MODEL OF A DISC ENGINE (working).
Maker/Donor: Presented by R. B. Prosser, Esq.
Date of creation: 1893.
Object entry information: The disc engine was patented by Messrs. E. and J. Dakeyne in 1830, and subsequently improved by Messrs. W. Taylor and H. Davies, besides others. In 1841 Messrs. Ransomes and Sims showed at Liverpool a Dakeyne rotary engine of 5 h.p., the first portable engine on wheels. It drove a thrashing machine and was rendered self-propelling by pitch chains from the crankshaft to the travelling axle. A similar engine was applied with some success by Messrs. G. and J. Rennie to drive a screw propeller (see Marine Engineering Collection); more recently the arrangement has been extensively used as a water meter. The chamber, which acts as a cylinder, is enclosed laterally by a spherical zone and endwise by a pair of cones whose apexes come together. The piston is a circular disc fitting the interior of the zone round its edge, and having at its centre a ball which forms the joint on which it gyrates. From the ball, and perpendicular to the disc, projects a rod whose further end is socketed in a crank arm attached to the shaft to be driven. There is a fixed radial partition in the cylinder, and a corresponding slot in the disc permits of the requisite motion. The disc and partition divide the chamber into four spaces, two of which are expanding while the other two are contracting; steam is admitted into the former and discharged from the latter by ports formed through the spherical wall of the partition, and the disc itself, by its motion over them, performs the function of a valve. The engine may be reversed by interchanging the inlet and exhaust passages.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1893–172, 21,068.

The circumference of the drum is divided longitudinally by two slots, fitted with cylindrical packings, through which two flaps or blades extend radially to the circumference of the casing. The inner ends of the blades are free to turn on a stud fixed centrally with the casing, and the exposed surface of these blades between the drum and the casing form pistons upon which the steam acts, and so causes them to revolve and carry round the drum.

Catalogue number: 146.
Object name: MODELS OF ROTARY ENGINE.
Maker/Donor: Maudsley Collection. Patented by Joseph Maudsley (1852) and John Trotter (1805).
Date of creation: 1805/1852 (Patents)
Object entry information: These wooden models represent the rotary engine patented by Joseph Maudsley in 1852; the same thing had, however, been patented by John Trotter in 1805. The engine consists essentially of a rotating cylindrical chamber, within which rotates a smaller cylindrical chamber placed eccentrically so as to touch the first. The inner chamber has a slot at one point, through which projects a radial partition fixed to the outer chamber; the crescent-shaped space between the two chambers is thus divided into two parts, one of which is expanding while the other is contracting, as the chambers revolve. Steam being admitted through a port in the outer chamber causes an unbalanced pressure upon the partition, the opposite side of which is connected with the exhaust by a port in the inner chamber, and so drives the chambers round. One model has the two chambers surrounded by a concentric casing to which the steam is admitted, the exhaust being through the axis. The other model is double and has three concentric rings with radial partitions between them, forming two chambers in which two eccentric rings rotate; no steam ports are shown on this model.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1900–22.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 147.
Object name: TOWER’S ROTARY ENGINE WITH WORKING MODEL.
Maker/Donor: Lent by Messrs. Heenan and Froude. (Engine patented by Mr. Beauchamp Tower in 1879).
Date of creation: 1889 and 1894.
Object entry information: A complete 6 in. engine, together with a wooden model, are shown, which illustrate the mode of action of the engine patented by Mr. Beauchamp Tower in 1879, and now known as the “spherical” engine because the working chamber is a complete sphere. The mechanism is equivalent to a universal joint connecting two shafts inclined together at an angle of 135 deg. The cross-piece of the joint is filled in so as to form a circular piston, and the jaws or bows of the joint are filled in solid to the shape of a quarter of a sphere. The whole joint is enclosed in a spherical chamber, and it will be seen that the disc alternately approaches and recedes from the spherical segments to which it is attached, as the shafts rotate. Throughout each revolution there are two cavities simultaneously opening, and two closing—all four varying at the same mean rate, so that if steam is admitted into the enlarging cavities, and be permitted to exhaust from those that are closing, continuous rotation of the shafts is obtained. The rotation of the segments upon the surface of the sphere is utilised to distribute the steam—ports in the spherical surface being uncovered at the correct intervals by the moving segments. The chambers obtained in this engine are each equal to a quarter of the volume of the sphere, and in one revolution the total volume passed is equal to that of the sphere. As the only reciprocation is that due to the swing of the disc, the engine is suited for high speeds, and, for the power given off, is very compact.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1889–76, and Inv. 1894–275, 21,060.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 148.
Object name: ROTARY ENGINE (working).
Maker/Donor: Lent by Messrs. Fielding and Platt. (Patented by Mr. J. Fielding in 1885).
Date of creation: 1888.
Object entry information: The action of this engine, patented in 1885 by Mr. J. Fielding, depends upon the oscillating motion which the cross of a universal joint has relative to the containing jaws when the system is rotated. Two shafts are set at an angle of 165 deg. to each other and connected by a Hooke’s joint; one serves as a pivot, the power being taken from the other. Four curved pistons are arranged on the cross-piece, two pointing towards one shaft and two towards the other, and on each shaft or jaw are formed two curved steam cylinders in which the curved pistons work. The steam enters and leaves the base of each cylinder through ports in the shaft, which forms a cylindrical valve working in the bearing as a seating.
Object/Inventory number: N/A

Object entry information: On the revolution of the shafts the pistons reciprocate in their cylinders in much the same way as in an ordinary engine, and the valve arrangement is such that while each piston is receding from its cylinder the steam pressure is driving it, and during the in-stroke of each, its cylinder is in communica- tion with the exhaust. There are thus four single-acting cylinders making each a double stroke for one revolution of the driving-shaft. The engine has no dead centres, and has been run at 1,000 r.p.m.

Catalogue number: 149
Object name: RIGG’S REVOLVING ENGINE (working)
Maker/Donor: Mr. A. Rigg. Received 1892.
Date of creation: 1885
Object entry information: This machine, patented in 1885 by Mr. A. Rigg, will be found to resemble in its movements an oscillating cylinder engine held by its crankshaft, and performing its cycle by the revolution of the framing round the crankshaft and the cylinder round the crankpin. The varying chamber of a recipro- cating engine is thus obtained, while the inertia stresses due to the recipro- cating parts are almost eliminated. The engine has three single-acting cylinders, the long plunger pistons of which act outwardly upon three crankpins, projecting from the face of an overhanging fly-wheel. The closed end of each cylinder is formed into an eye, and fits upon a stud or trunnion fixed to the engine-bed. This stud is not on the same centre-line as the fly-wheel shaft, so that in a complete revolution each piston makes a double stroke, of a length equal to twice this eccentricity. The driving stud acts on a sliding block so that the eccentricity can be varied and the stroke of the engine is rendered adjustable. The engine is reversed by sliding the stud into line with the fly-wheel shaft and continuing the sliding so as to give the eccentricity on the opposite side. The passage of the working fluid to and from the cylinders takes place through the faces of the eyes at the cylinder ends, which are provided with ports. The fluid enters and leaves the engine by the block carrying the stationary stud, the face of the block forming a surface on which the nearest cylinder end revolves, and acting as a disc slide-valve for the three cylinders. An adjacent sectional drawing shows clearly the details of this arrangement. The engine can be worked by steam, air, or water, but the full advantage resulting from the variable stroke is only obtained when working with water, owing to the cylinder clearance increasing as the stroke is reduced. The ordinary speed of these engines is from 100 to 500 r.p.m. with water pressure of 750 lb. per sq. in. When steam or compressed air is used, as many as 2,000 r.p.m. have been obtained.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1892–74, 19,372

Object name: ROTARY ENGINE (working)
Maker/Donor: Made by the British Cycloidal Engine Syndicate, Ltd. Received 1911.
Date of creation: 1901, 1903, and 1907
Object entry information: This is a rotary steam engine of the form patented by Mr. J. F. Cooley in 1901, 1903, and 1907. Its construction depends upon the fact that if two ele- ments rotate in the same direction, about fixed centres, with a speed ratio of 3 : 2, then three points on the slower element, equidistant from its centre, will describe, relative to the faster element, one and the same two-lobed peritrochoidal curve known as a nephroid. If a piston of this form is made to revolve at the correct speed, in a suitably shaped revolving chamber, having the three describing points on it in contact with the piston, then the chamber will be divided into three expanding and contracting spaces which can be used as working cylinders. In the engine shown, the piston is mounted on a horizontal shaft and placed eccentrically inside a closed cylinder having a trefoil-shaped interior section with packing strips placed at the describing points. These strips, which have swivelling heads with two lines of contact, are the only parts in contact with the curved surface of the piston; they are held in contact by springs and have sufficient radial motion to render extreme accuracy of the piston form unnecessary. There are also other packing strips fitted in the cylinder ends and bearing against the flat ends of the piston. Pinions with 24 teeth are fitted to the shaft on each side of the piston, and these gear with internally toothed rings with 36 teeth fitted into holes in the cylinder end covers through which the shaft passes. Both cylinder and piston shaft run in roller bearings mounted in the end covers of an outer casing that surrounds the cylinder, and a ball thrust bearing is fitted to the tail end of the shaft. The cylinder has three longitudinal ports cut through it leading to the interior working spaces, and the casing, in which the inlet and exhaust passages are formed, fits closely round it. These passages are separated by pairs of adjustable packing strips, fitted in slots in the casing and bearing against the cylinder, and an intermediate strip provides for a period of expansion, admitting, cutting-off and

Object entry information: On the revolution of the shafts the pistons reciprocate in their cylinders in much the same way as in an ordinary engine, and the valve arrangement is such that while each piston is receding from its cylinder the steam pressure is driving it, and during the in-stroke of each, its cylinder is in communica- tion with the exhaust. There are thus four single-acting cylinders making each a double stroke for one revolution of the driving-shaft. The engine has no dead centres, and has been run at 1,000 r.p.m.

Object entry information: exhausting the steam as the ports pass the packing strips. The cylinder ends are made steam tight in the casing by cast-iron rings rotating with it and fitting between two non-rotating gunmetal rings, the outer one of which is adjusted by set-screws passing through the casing cover and pressing on a cast-iron backing ring. The longitudinal packings are pressed inward by springs and adjusted by external nuts. The bearings have short steel rollers of large diameter which are prevented from winding by closely-fitting side plates; the rollers run on hardened steel rings. Such engines could be made to reverse by providing the casing with two sets of inlet and exhaust ports, and suitable valves for bringing either set into use. This example has a steam inlet of 1·19 in. diam., and a piston 6 in. long; it was designed to develop 20 to 30 h.p.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 151.
Object name: PARSONS STEAM TURBINE AND HIGH SPEED DYNAMO.
Maker/Donor: Lent by the Hon. Sir Charles A. Parsons, K.C.B., F.R.S.
Date of creation: 1884. Received 1890.
Object entry information: This is the original steam turbine, made in 1884. It worked for several years driving the dynamo which gave off 5 electrical h.p. The motor consists of a series of parallel-flow turbines on the same shaft, the first being the supply for the second, and so on. By this arrangement the efficient action of a steam turbine is greatly reduced. To allow for the increased volume of the steam as its pressure falls in passing through the machines, the proportions of the turbines alter as the final one is approached, the passages being enlarged and the pitch of the blades increased. A set of guide blades, with its corresponding rotating ring, forming one element of a later turbine, is shown separately beside the machine. End thrust is obviated by employing two equal series of turbines on the same spindle on each side of the central steam inlet, the exhaust taking place from each end equally. By this arrangement also, glands are avoided as the slight leakage through the bearings under the exhaust pressure is easily collected and occasions no loss. To prevent vibration the bearings throughout are not quite rigidly fixed to the main castings, but are permitted a slight movement between clamping washers, the alternate washers fitting the casting and clearing the outside of the bearing, and *vice versa*. The lubrication of the bearings is effected by a current of oil continually circulated by a small screw pump formed on the main shaft. In its course the oil passes through the hollow shaft of the dynamo so that it shall assist in cooling the armature and commutator. The governing is performed by a cylindrical throttle-valve actuated by a leather diaphragm, on one side of which the air pressure is reduced by a kind of fan attached to the main shaft. The exhausting action of the fan is partially neutralised by an iron arm turning on a vertical axis, by the attraction of the field magnet, drawn round, against the action of a spring, into a position that causes its extremity nearly to close the entrance to the air-pipe. By this arrangement the opening of the throttle-valve is regulated by the centrifugal action of the fan and by the intensity of the magnetic field, the control being partly mechanical and partly electrical. The dynamo has a drum armature, but, owing to the high speed employed, only a few convolutions are required, which, being of large section, give a very low internal resistance. The commutator is built up of short gunmetal segments insulated with asbestos and dove-tailed into steel rings. The machine is shunt wound.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1890-59, S.M. 277.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 152.
Object name: DE LAVAL'S STEAM TURBINE.
Maker/Donor: Dr. C. Gustav P. de Laval.
Date of creation: Invented/Developed 1889. Received 1896.
Object entry information: This remarkable steam engine, invented and developed by Dr. C. Gustav P. de Laval, owes its success to the discovery by him, in 1889, of the fact that the velocity of the particles of an escaping jet of steam is increased by discharging through an expanding orifice, the conversion of the energy of the steam into momentum being so complete that, when applied to a form of Pelton wheel or impulse turbine (see No. 15), a high efficiency is obtained. Without the expanding orifice, a simple steam jet turbine is one of the earliest forms of steam engine (see No. 35), and very uneconomical, but by the use of many such turbines in series an efficient engine is also obtained (see No. 151).

Gustav P. de Laval, owes its success to the discovery by him, in 1889, of the fact that the velocity of the particles of an escaping jet of steam is increased by discharging through an expanding orifice, the conversion of the energy of the steam into momentum being so complete that, when applied to a form of Pelton wheel or impulse turbine (see No. 15), a high efficiency is obtained. title: Parsons' steam turbine generator, 1884
description: Parsons' original Steam Turbine generator, with spare guide ring and fan, by Clarke, Chapman, Parsons & Co.,1884
material: steel (metal); gunmetal; brass (copper, zinc alloy); cast iron; copper (metal)
object_name: engines; steam engines; generators; turbines; engines; steam engines; generators; turbines

Object entry information:
In the de Laval turbine, shown in section, the revolving wheel is built up of separate vanes that are clamped by side discs in a way that resists the severe centrifugal stress resulting from the immense velocity required, while at the same time permitting of well-finished and correctly shaped vanes being employed. The steam is directed, at an angle of 19 deg. with the plane of the wheel upon one side of it, through the expanding jet orifice, and after gliding round the concave faces of the vanes leaves the opposite face of the wheel with scarcely any dynamic energy remaining in it. The wheel is enclosed in a casing that communicates either here or with a condenser.
To obtain an efficient turbine of this class it is, however, necessary that the velocity of the vanes should be nearly half that of the fluid of the impelling jet (attaining 2,000 ft. per sec.) that special arrangements are necessary to render it possible. The wheel is fixed to the middle of a long, flexible shaft, one end of which is secured within a shaft carried in bearings, while the other end is carried in a long bearing having a spherical mounting; in this way the wheel is allowed to determine its own axis of rotation in somewhat the same way as does a spinning top. The speed of the shaft is so high, however, that it is unsuited to any ordinary machinery, and is accordingly reduced in one step by helical gearing in the ratio of 10 : 1, the countershaft then running at a speed suited for the direct driving of small dynamos; for slower machinery the reduction can be further carried out by belting.
This example gave off 5·37 brake h.p. at 3,000 r.p.m. of the belt pulley, when supplied with steam at 82·5 lb. pressure, and worked non-condensing.
A trial made in 1896 of a de Laval turbine for a New York central station, with a steam pressure of 147 lb. per sq. in. and a vacuum of 25·7 in., is recorded to have shown a water consumption of 17·3 lb. per brake h.p. per hour; the total power developed was 266 brake h.p. and the turbine disc made 9,000 r.p.m. The temperature of the inlet steam was 425 deg. C., and that of the discharge 40 deg. C.

Catalogue number: 154.
Object name: MODEL OF STEAM TURBINE (working). Made in the Museum, 1909.
Maker/Donor: Made in the Museum.
Date of creation: 1909.
Object entry information: This is a diagrammatic model illustrating the principle and arrangement of a steam turbine of the single-stage impulse type. It consists of a single wheel mounted on a shaft, having symmetrically shaped blades round its periphery with an entrance angle of 30 deg. The turbine is driven by steam issuing from two nozzles, placed tangentially at opposite ends of a diameter, and making an angle of 20 deg. with the plane of the wheel. In the model the nozzles are cylindrical, as the exhaust pressure is much greater than one-half of the initial pressure, but in an actual machine using steam at ordinary pressure, a diverging nozzle is necessary in order to utilise efficiently the energy of the steam (see No. 152).
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1909-481.
Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 155.
Object name: PARSONS STEAM TURBINE (working). Made from drawings prepared in the Museum, 1907.
Maker/Donor: Made from drawings prepared in the Museum.
Date of creation: 1907.
Object entry information: This type of compound turbine was introduced and patented by the Hon. Sir Charles A. Parsons in 1884 (see No. 151). The drawing shows a longitudinal section of a later and improved turbine for driving a dynamo having an output of 75 k.w., and the model represents a portion of the high-pressure end of it, showing the drum, casing, and blades.
The turbine consists of a shaft or drum of varying diameter having fixed to it a number of rows of blades or vanes, which alternate with similar rows set in the opposite direction and fixed to a surrounding casing. The action differs from that of the impulse type of turbine (see Nos. 152 and 157), in that the steam expands in the moving rows as well as in the fixed rows, so that there is a continuous fall of pressure throughout the annular channel of increasing area formed by the blade spaces. In order to utilise the energy of the steam efficiently and to keep the velocities low, the number of blade rows must be large. The first drum of the series, however, must be small on account of the full circumferential admission necessary and the small radial clearance allowable, but by increasing the diameter of the drum towards the exhaust end, the number of blade rows is decreased and the end blades shortened. The steam is directed, at an angle of 19 deg. with the plane of the wheel upon one side of it, through the expanding jet orifice, and after gliding round the concave faces of the vanes leaves the opposite face of the wheel with scarcely any dynamic energy remaining in it. The wheel is enclosed in a casing that communicates either here or with a condenser.
To obtain an efficient turbine of this class it is, however, necessary that the velocity of the vanes should be nearly half that of the fluid of the impelling jet (attaining 2,000 ft. per sec.) that special arrangements are necessary to render it possible. The wheel is fixed to the middle of a long, flexible shaft, one end of which is secured within a shaft carried in bearings, while the other end is carried in a long bearing having a spherical mounting; in this way the wheel is allowed to determine its own axis of rotation in somewhat the same way as does a spinning top. The speed of the shaft is so high, however, that it is unsuited to any ordinary machinery, and is accordingly reduced in one step by helical gearing in the ratio of 10 : 1, the countershaft then running at a speed suited for the direct driving of small dynamos; for slower machinery the reduction can be further carried out by belting.
This example gave off 5·37 brake h.p. at 3,000 r.p.m. of the belt pulley, when supplied with steam at 82·5 lb. pressure, and worked non-condensing.
A trial made in 1896 of a de Laval turbine for a New York central station, with a steam pressure of 147 lb. per sq. in. and a vacuum of 25·7 in., is recorded to have shown a water consumption of 17·3 lb. per brake h.p. per hour; the total power developed was 266 brake h.p. and the turbine disc made 9,000 r.p.m. The temperature of the inlet steam was 425 deg. C., and that of the discharge 40 deg. C.

Object name: MODEL OF STEAM TURBINE (working). Made in the Museum, 1909.
Maker/Donor: Made in the Museum.
Date of creation: 1909.
Object entry information: This is a diagrammatic model illustrating the principle and arrangement of a steam turbine of the single-stage impulse type. It consists of a single wheel mounted on a shaft, having symmetrically shaped blades round its periphery with an entrance angle of 30 deg. The turbine is driven by steam issuing from two nozzles, placed tangentially at opposite ends of a diameter, and making an angle of 20 deg. with the plane of the wheel. In the model the nozzles are cylindrical, as the exhaust pressure is much greater than one-half of the initial pressure, but in an actual machine using steam at ordinary pressure, a diverging nozzle is necessary in order to utilise efficiently the energy of the steam (see No. 152).

Object entry information: This type of compound turbine was introduced and patented by the Hon. Sir Charles A. Parsons in 1884 (see No. 151). The drawing shows a longitudinal section of a later and improved turbine for driving a dynamo having an output of 75 k.w., and the model represents a portion of the high-pressure end of it, showing the drum, casing, and blades.
The turbine consists of a shaft or drum of varying diameter having fixed to it a number of rows of blades or vanes, which alternate with similar rows set in the opposite direction and fixed to a surrounding casing. The action differs from that of the impulse type of turbine (see Nos. 152 and 157), in that the steam expands in the moving rows as well as in the fixed rows, so that there is a continuous fall of pressure throughout the annular channel of increasing area formed by the blade spaces. In order to utilise the energy of the steam efficiently and to keep the velocities low, the number of blade rows must be large. The first drum of the series, however, must be small on account of the full circumferential admission necessary and the small radial clearance allowable, but by increasing the diameter of the drum towards the exhaust end, the number of blade rows is decreased and the end blades shortened. Object/Inventory number: N/A
title: Diagrammatic model of Simple Impulse Steam Turbine
description: Diagrammatic model of Simple Impulse Steam Turbine, arranged for working by compressed air

Object entry information:
one end and the resulting axial thrust, which in the early machines was obviated by making the turbine double ended, is balanced by drums formed on the shaft at the high-pressure end, corresponding in diameter to the several blade drums and having the same steam pressures acting upon them through passages in the casing. This reduces the length of the machine and increases its efficiency. The blades increase in size from the high-pressure end downward and also the axial clearances, which are nowhere less than 0.125 in. The blades are made of a special bronze, drawn in strips and cut to length; they are mounted in grooves turned in the drums and in the casing, with distance pieces between them, and the whole caulked tight. The grooves in the drum are slightly undercut or serrated. The shaft, where it passes out of the casing, and also the balance drums, are kept steam tight by labyrinth stuffing boxes or packings. These consist of a series of projecting collars turned on the shaft or drum alternating with a similar series of rings fixed in the surrounding casing and almost in contact with them on one face but with a large clearance on the other; this causes alternate throttling and expansion of the steam and prevents appreciable leakage. The shaft stuffing boxes are connected so that steam and not air leaks into the vacuum end. The shaft bearings are quite outside the turbine casing and are made slightly elastic by surrounding the brasses with a series of concentric sleeves fitting easily into one another, oil being supplied by a pump. Axial adjustment is provided for by a small thrust block at the end of the shaft. The steam is admitted through a double-beat valve actuated by a piston above it; its movement is controlled by a slide valve attached to one end of a lever the fulcrum of which is caused to oscillate by means of another lever and a cam driven by a worm on the shaft; the other end of the valve lever is controlled by a solenoid or by a centrifugal governor. The effect is that the steam is admitted in a series of puffs increasing in duration with the load until the flow becomes continuous. A runaway valve is fitted which cuts off the steam should the controlling apparatus fail.
In this machine there are three diameters of drum, 48 rows of moving blades, and an equal number of fixed blades varying in length from 0.5 in. to 1.75 in. The shaft runs at 4,140 r.p.m., giving a minimum blade speed of 100 ft. per sec. When using saturated steam of 140 lb. pressure and a vacuum of 27 in., it uses about 29 lb. per k.w. hour. A larger machine, however, developing 3,200 k.w. and using superheated steam, has shown a consumption of 14.1 lb. per k.w. hour.

Object name: MODEL OF STEAM TURBINE (working).
Maker/Donor: Made in the Museum.
Date of creation: 1909.
Object entry information: This is a working model illustrating the principle and arrangement of the compound reaction turbine of the Parsons type (see Nos. 151 and 155). It consists of a revolving drum upon which are mounted two rings of curved blades; two rings of similar blades are fixed to the casing and alternate with them, and the steam passes from the inlet end between the fixed and moving sets of blades alternately, while expanding. This arrangement of turbines in series reduces the steam and blade velocities, approximately inversely as the square of the number of rings of moving blades. In the model the casing is made of glass so that the blades may be seen.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1909-35.

Object name: MODEL OF CURTIS STEAM TURBINE (working). (Scale 1: 6.)
Maker/Donor: Made from drawings prepared in the Museum.

Object entry information: This type of steam turbine was patented by Mr. C. G. Curtis in 1896 and subsequently developed. The model represents a turbine for driving a dynamo of 500 k.w. output, made by the General Electric Co., U.S.A., in 1904.
The turbine is of the impulse type, in which the steam is wholly expanded in diverging nozzles and then has its kinetic energy absorbed by the blades of revolving wheels. In order, however, to reduce the peripheral speed of the wheels to a practical value, two methods are simultaneously employed; firstly, the steam is expanded in two stages by two sets of nozzles, and secondly, each wheel has three sets of blades with intermediate fixed guide blades which redirect the steam, after passing through one set, on to the succeeding sets. This combined method gives a large reduction in the peripheral speed with a small number of wheels and blades.
The turbine has a vertical shaft with bearings at the top and bottom, the whole revolving load being carried by a water-jacketed, adjustable footstep bearing which is supplied with oil under pressure. The turbine casing consists of three parts, one above the other, a diaphragm being placed between

title: Diagrammatic working model of Parsons type steam turbine
description: Diagrammatic working model of Parsons type steam turbine
object_name: model; steam turbine; model; steam turbine
place: South Kensington, Kensington and Chelsea, London, Greater London, England, United Kingdom

Object entry information: the two upper parts dividing the interior into two chambers in each of which the wheel revolves. The lower casing forms a pedestal containing one of the triple wheel-exhaust outlet. The shaft is fitted with stuffing- boxes where it passes through the casings and diaphragm. The first-stage nozzles and guide blades are fitted in the roof of the top chamber, and the number is twelve, and is supported by a removable door which is adjustable. The second-stage diaphragm and are forty the guide blades occupy the circumference and are fixed to the walls of the second casing, in number to allow for the increased volume of steam. The second-stage regulation is effected by a nozzle governor which closes or opens some of the first-stage nozzles; the second-stage nozzles are regulated by a large ring-valve acting similarly, but operated by hand. The wheels are each built up of three steel discs, bolted together, and the blades are cut around the rim by special shaping machines; the passages thus formed are of constant width, but the depth, and also the blade angles, increase in accord- ance with the decreasing velocity of the steam. The guide blades are cut in the same way, in segments, and bolted to the casings. The dynamo is placed vertically above the turbine and directly coupled to it. The turbine is designed for a steam pressure of 150 lb. per sq. in., and a vacuum of 28 in.; it runs at 1,800 rev. per min. and develops 670 electrical h.p. It uses about 12 lb. of saturated steam per h.p. hour, at full load, but with high superheat as low as 10 lb. Machines of this type have been built to develop more than twenty times the above power.

Object name: MODEL OF RATEAU STEAM TURBINE (working). (Scale 1: 4.)
Maker/Donor: Messrs. Fraser and Chalmers, Ltd.
Date of creation: 1908.
Object entry information: This model, which is partly sectioned, represents a steam turbine of the form patented by Prof. A. C. E. Rateau in 1896, and subsequently developed. It is arranged for direct connection with a dynamo having an output of 600 k.w. The turbine is of the compound or multi-stage impulse type, and consists of 14 simple turbines arranged in series in separate chambers, and with a common shaft. Each stage has a set of nozzles, in which the steam is expanded through a fraction of the total pressure drop, and a wheel which absorbs the kinetic energy thus generated; the steam enters at the high-pressure end of the series and passes successively through all the stages to the condenser. The steam velocity ranges from about 750 ft. per sec. at the first wheel to about 1,100 ft. per sec. at the last. The turbine is formed with a cylindrical casing of varying diameter, made in halves and divided by intermediate diaphragms into 14 chambers; this casing is closed and supported at each end by a cover, the upper half of which is separate, while the lower half forms part of a casting containing the shaft- bearing. The shaft is of large diameter at the middle, and is stepped towards each end to form the wheel seats; it is carried in a long fixed bearing at each end, the bushes being of cast iron, lined with white metal. A small thrust bearing is provided to keep the wheels in position and to take up any unbalanced axial pressure. The steam enters at the front of the central casing, through stop and regulating valves, and is led to the four first-stage nozzles that are fitted in the end cover. The nozzles for the succeeding stages are fitted into notches cut in the edges of the diaphragms, and they increase in circumferential length until at the exhaust end they occupy nearly the whole periphery. They are also placed in angular advance of one another so as to follow the helical course of the steam. The nozzles are built up of nickel steel plate for the first eight stages, and of brass for the other six. The first four wheels are single mild steel discs, riveted to flanges formed on hubs keyed to the shaft; the other ten wheels are formed of two slightly dished nickel steel discs, riveted one on each side of the hub flange, and also riveted together at the outer edge. The wheel blades are stamped from nickel steel plate and are of cylindrical shape with equal entrance and exit angles; they are formed with forked lower ends that are placed astride of the wheel discs and secured by two rivets. The outer ends are covered by a shrouding band secured by riveted projections on the blade ends; the steam entrance edges of the blades and nozzles are ground sharp. The wheels are balanced and tested before being placed in position. The diaphragms extend inward to the shaft, and are bushed with antifriction metal, which is grooved internally and fits closely over the wheel hubs. Where the shaft passes through the end covers stuffing-boxes are provided; these are double, and comprise an inner labyrinth packing formed with interlocking grooved bushes fitted to the shaft and cover, and running with small clearances; and an outer packing
Object/Inventory number: N/A
title: Model (scale 1:6) 1/4 sectioned of Curtis Steam turbine
description: Model (scale 1:6), 1/4 sectioned, of Curtis Steam turbine, 500 K.W. output, and 2 segments of casing, each with 2 rows of nozzles. (Wheels, blading and nozzles made in Science Museum)
place: London, Greater London, England, United Kingdom

Object entry information: consisting of a pair of segmental cast-iron rings, fitted between end-plates, and held in contact with the shaft by circumferential helical springs. The spaces between the packings at each end are connected together by a passage through the casing, so that steam leaking past the high-pressure packing enters, instead of air, at the vacuum end. The turbine shaft is connected with the dynamo shaft by means of a flexible coupling. This consists of two flanges, having projecting bosses that keep them some distance apart, keyed to the shaft ends; these are drilled near the circumference to take 80 steel driving pins 0.3 in. diam. The pins are held in place by cover plates, and overstraining is prevented by stops, bolted to the bosses, which limit the relative motion. The bearings are supplied with forced lubrication and cooled by circulating water. Regulation is effected by means of a throttle-valve, actuated by an oil relay, controlled by a centrifugal governor, driven by a worm and worm wheel from the turbine shaft. A large overload capacity is provided for by a by-pass that admits high-pressure steam directly to the fifth set of nozzles. The turbine wheels range from 22.92 in. to 34.12 in. mean diameter; the axial clearance between the wheels and the casing is 0.12 in., while the radial clearance varies from 0.12 in. to 0.17 in. The turbine represented is designed for a steam pressure of 160 lb. per sq. in., and a vacuum of 28 in.; it runs at 3,000 rev. per min., and develops 800 h.p. When tested at full load it used 11.9 lb. of steam per brake h.p. hour, measured at the turbine coupling. A sectional drawing (scale 1: 10) of the complete turbine is shown.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 159.
Object name: WESTINGHOUSE STEAM TURBINE.
Maker/Donor: Lent by the British Westinghouse Electric and Manufacturing Co., Ltd.
Date of creation: 1908.
Object entry information: This is a full-sized section showing the blading arrangement of a 4,000 k.w. steam turbine of the double-flow combined type patented by Mr. G. Westinghouse in 1902–5. The steam enters at the centre of the casing and flows towards both ends. It passes from an annular steam chest to a double set of nozzles in which the first expansion is carried out from the boiler pressure to about 45 lb. per sq. in.; it is then delivered on to the blades of a double impulse wheel, with intermediate guide blade, without further change of pressure. The remainder of the expansion is carried out by 20 pairs of fixed and rotating blades, of increasing length, of the ordinary Parsons form. This construction, while sacrificing some efficiency at the high-pressure end, considerably shortens the turbine, obviates the use of balance drums, enables a drum of uniform diameter to be used, and requires no high-pressure packing. The complete drum is about 56 in. diam. and is made of rolled weldless steel; it is mounted on three discs which are secured to a central shaft. The nozzles are formed of bent metal strips set in grooves in the sides of the circumferential slots which contain them. The high-pressure blades are made of drop-forged steel, formed with shroud pieces and dovetail roots which are set in slightly dovetailed grooves in the drum, and caulked tight with distance pieces in the usual manner; the longer ones are tied together, near their outer ends, by a wire of comma-shaped section passed through similar holes and with its tail turned over between the blades.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1908–27.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 160.
Object name: MODEL OF TURBO-ALTERNATOR. (Scale 1: 12.)
Maker/Donor: Made by Messrs. C. A. Parsons & Co.
Date of creation: 1909.
Object entry information: This model represents a design for a large turbo-alternator for an economical output of 10,000 k.w., with a steam consumption of 13 lb. per k.w. hour, but capable of being overloaded to 20,000 k.w. The turbine is of the ordinary Parsons type (see No. 151); the low-pressure end bearing is fixed to the alternator bedplate, while the high-pressure end is mounted on a separate one, upon which it can slide. The steam valves are mounted on the front of the lower half of the casing, so that the upper half may be removed without disturbing them. Oil is supplied to the bearings by a pump and returned to the oil-tank, which is placed under the turbine. The overload is provided for by a valve that admits high-pressure steam to an intermediate point along the turbine. The alternator is of the stationary armature type, and is entirely enclosed by a casing, through which a cooling current of air is forced. The exciting dynamo is mounted on the end of the bed. (15816)
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1909–4, S.M. 276.

Object name: SECTIONAL DRAWING OF 6,000 K.W. STEAM TURBINE. (Scale 1: 12.)
Maker/Donor: Presented by Messrs. C. A. Parsons & Co.
Object entry information: This drawing shows the internal construction of one of eight steam turbines which were built by Messrs. C. A. Parsons & Co., in 1909-10, for the Chelsea Power Station of the London Underground Electric Railways Co. at Lots Road (see adjacent prints). These large turbines are now made with two separate casings, each with its own shaft and rotor, the shafts being in line and connected together by a flexible claw coupling. This system enables each part of the turbine to have a short stiff shaft, reduces the size of the individual castings, and minimises the risk of distortion of the casings. The high-pressure portion has a solid steel shaft and drum with two diameters and 39 rows of moving blades; 50 per cent. overload is provided for by an automatic by-pass which admits steam at the thirteenth row of blades. The steam passes from the high-pressure casing, through a pipe, to the far end of the low-pressure casing, and flows through it in the reverse direction, exhausting at the centre of the machine. The low-pressure rotor is a parallel cylindrical drum mounted on two spiders on a solid shaft; it has 18 rows of moving blades, those in the last four rows being 12 in. long. Each shaft has its own thrust and adjusting block, and the bearings are of cast iron lined with white metal. The turbine is governed on the gust principle through a steam actuated relay, and there is a runaway valve that shuts off the steam if a certain speed is exceeded. The turbines run at 1,000 rev. per min., and, with steam at a pressure of 185 lb. per sq. in., a superheat of 140 deg. F., and a vacuum of 28 in., have shown a steam consumption, of 14 lb. per k.w. hour. The high-pressure part develops about 40 per cent. of the full power.

Catalogue number: 162.
Object name: SECTIONAL DRAWING OF 500 K.W. COMBINED STEAM TURBINE. (Scale 1: 4.)
Maker/Donor: Presented by Messrs. C. A. Parsons & Co.
Date of creation: 1912.
Object entry information: This drawing shows the internal construction of the form of steam turbine in which the high-pressure steam is first expanded in nozzles and passed through a compound impulse wheel of the Curtis type (see No. 157) and then further expanded through a series of rows of blades of the ordinary Parsons reaction type. This form was introduced about 1902 (see No. 159), and is much favoured on the Continent; it reduces considerably the length of the machine, and relieves the main casing of the influence of very short high-pressure blades, and of the high pressure and temperature. The turbine has a solid forged steel rotor carrying 30 rows of reaction blading, while at the high-pressure end a large disc, which carries two rows of impulse blades, is bolted on. The nozzles are attached to a cast steel steam chest bolted to the main casing. The steam thrust is balanced by leading steam from the middle of the casing to the large end of the low-pressure drum. The shaft runs in brass bearings surrounded by sleeves fitted in cylindrical cast-iron housings, which are themselves mounted in the main bearing casings. A thrust and adjusting block is placed at the end of the shaft and is adjusted by sliding the bearing cap.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1912–14.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 163.
Object name: PRINT OF GEARED TURBINE FOR ROLLING MILL.
Maker/Donor: Presented by Messrs. C. A. Parsons & Co.
Date of creation: 1912.
Object entry information: This shows a Parsons steam turbine of 750 h.p. constructed in 1910 for driving a rolling mill at the Calderbank Iron and Steel Works, Lanarkshire. The turbine is of the mixed pressure type, and is capable of using either exhaust steam at 16 lb. pressure from other engines, or high-pressure steam at 60 lb. per sq. in. from the boilers. An automatic arrangement permits the entrance of the live steam when the exhaust supply is insufficient. The turbine runs at 2,000 rev. per min., and drives the mill through double helical gearing; the reduction is made in two steps, the first giving 375 r.p.m. and the second the required 70 r.p.m. for the mill. A fly-wheel 23 ft. diam. and weighing 90 tons is mounted between the gearing and the mill shaft.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1912–20.

Object name: SECTIONAL DRAWING OF 500 K.W. COMBINED STEAM TURBINE. (Scale 1: 4.)
Maker/Donor: Presented by Messrs. C. A. Parsons & Co.
Object entry information: This drawing shows the internal construction of the form of steam turbine in which the high-pressure steam is first expanded in nozzles and passed through a compound impulse wheel of the Curtis type (see No. 157) and then further expanded through a series of rows of blades of the ordinary Parsons reaction type. This form was introduced about 1902 (see No. 159), and is much favoured on the Continent; it reduces considerably the length of the machine, and relieves the main casing of the influence of very short high-pressure blades, and of the high pressure and temperature. The turbine has a solid forged steel rotor carrying 30 rows of reaction blading, while at the high-pressure end a large disc, which carries two rows of impulse blades, is bolted on. The nozzles are attached to a cast steel steam chest bolted to the main casing. The steam thrust is balanced by leading steam from the middle of the casing to the large end of the low-pressure drum. The shaft runs in brass bearings surrounded by sleeves fitted in cylindrical cast-iron housings, which are themselves mounted in the main bearing casings. A thrust and adjusting block is placed at the end of the shaft and is adjusted by sliding the bearing cap.

Catalogue number: 161.
Object name: SECTIONAL DRAWING OF 6,000 K.W. STEAM TURBINE. (Scale 1: 12.)
Maker/Donor: Presented by Messrs. C. A. Parsons & Co.
Date of creation: 1912.
Object entry information: This drawing shows the internal construction of one of eight steam turbines which were built by Messrs. C. A. Parsons & Co., in 1909-10, for the Chelsea Power Station of the London Underground Electric Railways Co. at Lots Road (see adjacent prints). These large turbines are now made with two separate casings, each with its own shaft and rotor, the shafts being in line and connected together by a flexible claw coupling. This system enables each part of the turbine to have a short stiff shaft, reduces the size of the individual castings, and minimises the risk of distortion of the casings. The high-pressure portion has a solid steel shaft and drum with two diameters and 39 rows of moving blades; 50 per cent. overload is provided for by an automatic by-pass which admits steam at the thirteenth row of blades. The steam passes from the high-pressure casing, through a pipe, to the far end of the low-pressure casing, and flows through it in the reverse direction, exhausting at the centre of the machine. The low-pressure rotor is a parallel cylindrical drum mounted on two spiders on a solid shaft; it has 18 rows of moving blades, those in the last four rows being 12 in. long. Each shaft has its own thrust and adjusting block, and the bearings are of cast iron lined with white metal. The turbine is governed on the gust principle through a steam actuated relay, and there is a runaway valve that shuts off the steam if a certain speed is exceeded. The turbines run at 1,000 rev. per min., and, with steam at a pressure of 185 lb. per sq. in., a superheat of 140 deg. F., and a vacuum of 28 in., have shown a steam consumption, of 14 lb. per k.w. hour. The high-pressure part develops about 40 per cent. of the full power.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1912–15 to 17.

Catalogue number: 163.
Object name: PRINT OF GEARED TURBINE FOR ROLLING MILL.
Maker/Donor: Presented by Messrs. C. A. Parsons & Co.
Date of creation: 1912.
Object entry information: This shows a Parsons steam turbine of 750 h.p. constructed in 1910 for driving a rolling mill at the Calderbank Iron and Steel Works, Lanarkshire. The turbine is of the mixed pressure type, and is capable of using either exhaust steam at 16 lb. pressure from other engines, or high-pressure steam at 60 lb. per sq. in. from the boilers. An automatic arrangement permits the entrance of the live steam when the exhaust supply is insufficient. The turbine runs at 2,000 rev. per min., and drives the mill through double helical gearing; the reduction is made in two steps, the first giving 375 r.p.m. and the second the required 70 r.p.m. for the mill. A fly-wheel 23 ft. diam. and weighing 90 tons is mounted between the gearing and the mill shaft.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1912–20.

title: Collotype, mixed pressure turbine fitted to rolling mill
description: Collotype, mixed pressure turbine fitted to rolling mill, Calderbank, N.B.

Object entry information:
steel drum with three diameters, and has 64 rows of moving blades varying in length from 2.75 in. to 6.5 in. Balance drums are provided at the high-pressure end, and the bladed portion is nearly 12 ft. long and 65 in. maximum diam. Loads exceeding 20,000 k.w. are provided for by a by-pass-valve, which admits steam directly to the twentieth row of blades. The steam passes from the high-pressure casing through two pipes, 30 in. diam., to a central chamber surrounding the low-pressure turbine, which is double ended. The low-pressure rotor is a cylinder, 14.5 ft. long, mounted on a central spider, and two expansion diaphragms on each side of the casing; it has 24 rows of moving blades 2.75 in. to 19 in. long. The condenser, which has a cooling surface of 39,600 sq. ft., is suspended below the low-pressure casing, but a large proportion of the weight is borne by spring supports beneath it. Very complete governing gear is fitted, comprising a relay-operated main-valve, an emergency stop-valve, and an automatic overload bypass-valve. The turbine shaft is connected with the alternator shaft by a flexible claw coupling.
The turbine runs at 750 rev. per min., and uses steam at a pressure of 200 lb. per sq. in., superheated 200° F., and a vacuum of 29 in. The guaranteed steam consumption at 20,000 k.w. was 11.25 lb. per k.w. hour, which is equivalent to 8.1 lb. per shaft h.p. hour. The overall dimensions of the complete machine are 76 ft. long, 18 ft. wide, and 30 ft. high, but 20 ft. of the latter is below the floor level.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 167.
Object name: PRINTS OF BRUSH-LJUNGSTRÖM STEAM TURBINE.
Maker/Donor: Lent by the Brush Electrical Engineering Co.
Date of creation: 1915.
Object entry information: These prints show improvements in the steam turbine patented by Mr. Birger Ljungström in 1906. His is a radial flow reaction turbine, but instead of a system of fixed and moving blades, both sets of blades revolve in opposite directions and power is taken off both shafts, consequently for the same relative speed, the shafts need only revolve at half the speed of the older systems. This idea was suggested in 1879 but it was reserved for Mr. Ljungström to overcome the mechanical difficulties involved.
The turbine consists of a series of concentric blade rings, mounted on two discs, each turbine rotor being fixed to short hollow extension shafts, so that each disc is overhung from the end of its alternator shaft. The blade rings interchange, the blades being set in opposite directions; the flow of the steam is reversed in direction.
Steam of high pressure and super-heat supplied through two vertical pipes enters the blade system at the centre and expands radially outwards. Between the inner and outer pair of discs by-pass steam is admitted to the blading for overloads. On entering from the last blade ring the steam passes through a diffuser comprising a number of converging channels in which the residual steam velocity is re-converted into pressure and the vacuum at the blade edges is thus slightly increased above that maintained in the condenser. Labyrinth packing prevents the escape of steam where the shafts pass through the side discs, and also up the back of the running discs. The axial pressure of the steam tending to force the blade discs apart, is balanced by the labyrinth discs. An essential feature of the design is the use of conical expansion rings of dumb-bell section between all connected parts subjected to temperature variations, enabling them to expand and contract freely without distortion.
In this machine there are 38 rows of blade rings (see No. 229). It is fitted with a centrifugal governor which is connected to the same vertical shaft which drives the geared pump supplying oil under pressure to the bearings. In each alternator shaft is an emergency governor adjusted to come into action at a speed approximately 10 per cent. above the running speed of the turbine.
The turbines of 1,000 k.w. run at 3,000 rev. per min. with a steam pressure of 162 lb. per sq. in. and a superheat of 310 deg. F. The steam consumption is 11.55 lb. per k.w. hour, or 8 lb. per brake h.p. hour. An efficiency of 73.6 per cent. is claimed.
(See "Engineering" XCIII, 482.)
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1915-25.

Object entry information: The chief feature of the turbine which, as can be seen by the attached section, is of the axial flow type, is the multiple exhaust. The advantages of this are: large outputs can be obtained on relatively small mean diameters; the overall length and consequently the weight can be reduced; and a higher limit of speed is possible. The turbine is of 15,000 k.w. capacity at 1,500 rev. per min.

Catalogue number: 169.
Object name: DIAGRAM OF HEAT LOSSES IN STEAM ENGINES.
Maker/Donor: Presented by A. E. A. Edwards, Esq.
Date of creation: 1921.
Object entry information: This was prepared by the donor with the aim of showing graphically how great are the heat losses in steam engines. The data for the boiler house losses, minus recovery through the economiser, the radiation losses and the losses to condenser are based on common knowledge. The balance remaining for power is calculated from published figures of electricity supply undertakings and from figures in the Report of the Coal Conservation Sub-Committee of the Reconstruction Committee, 1917. The percentage distribution of the heat rejected by the steam engine showing what can be recovered for heating and domestic hot water services is based on data obtained in the donor's own practice. (See Proc. Soc. Eng. XI., No. 5.)
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1921-432.

Maker/Donor: Watt Collection,
Object entry information: This shows a complete timber framing for a beam engine and represents the practice of Boulton and Watt about 1795. Object name: MODEL OF MARINE ENGINE FRAME.
Maker/Donor: Watt Collection,
Date of creation: 1876.
Object entry information: This is a model in wood and metal of a massive iron framing for an oscillating cylinder engine. It is of much later construction than the other Watt models.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1876–1248, S.M. 822.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 172.
Object name: EXPERIMENTAL BEAMS.
Maker/Donor: Watt Collection,
Date of creation: 1876.
Object entry information: These models were probably made by Watt when designing beams for his steam engines, as there is evidence that at first the engine beams gave trouble through their insufficient strength and rigidity. The smaller beams have parallel top and bottom booms, with diagonal timber struts inclined at 60 deg.; in one case the tie bolts are inclined, and run axially through the timber struts, while in the other vertical iron tie bolts are used. In the latter case the model has been loaded to destruction. The two larger beams consist each of a lower timber beam with a built-up truss above, the chief difference between them being that in one all the members are in duplicate. They have gudgeons and hooks or staples attached by which their strengths could be experimentally determined. From their trussing it is evident that these beams were designed for single-acting engines.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1876–1246, S.M. 818 to 820.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 173.
Object name: MODEL OF BEAM AND CONNECTING-RODS.
Maker/Donor: Watt Collection,
Date of creation: 1876.
Object entry information: In this model the horizontal lever, which probably represents an engine beam, is, by two connecting rods, coupled to two beams working in a vertical plane, at right angles to the main beam; universal joints at each end of the connecting-rods give the requisite freedom.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1876–1252, S.M. 814.

title: Model of beam and two connecting rods
description: Model of Beam and two connecting rods with universal motion at their upper ends and connected to transverse hinged links at their lower ends, possibly by James Watt, c.1785.

Catalogue number: N/A (Continues description of previous entry, likely 174)
Object name: N/A (Continues description of previous entry, likely Sun and Planet Gear)
Maker/Donor: Watt (Implied)
Object entry information: who, it has been stated, obtained his information through one of Watt’s workmen; Watt, instead of contesting the patent, decided to adopt other mechanism. This and the four succeeding models show some of these mechanisms which he patented in 1781; of these, however, only the sun and planet gear came into use. It is an epicyclic gear consisting of a "sun" wheel keyed on the end of the fly-wheel shaft and a "planet" wheel bolted to the connecting-rod end and held in gear with the sun wheel by a link loose on their centres, as in the model, or by a pin in the centre of the planet wheel moving in an annular slot. When both wheels are of the same diameter the fly-wheel makes twice the number of revolutions that it would if actuated by a crank and connecting-rod, the extra revolution being due to the fact that the planet wheel, although going round in a circle, does not revolve on its own axis. In some of Watt’s engines the diameter of the planet wheel was less than that of the sun wheel, and in this way shaft speeds were obtained only about 50 per cent. greater than would have been the case with a simple crank.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 175.
Object name: MODEL OF A LADDER CONNECTING-ROD.
Maker/Donor: Watt
Date of creation: 1871 (Collection)
Object entry information: This model shows another of the mechanisms schemed by James Watt about 1781 as an equivalent for the crank. The end of the connecting-rod is made in the form of a rack or ladder, the rungs of which are capable of acting on either side of a pinion fixed on the fly-wheel shaft of the engine. The connecting-rod is guided by a roller at the lower end, which works in a large opening of special form in a fixed guide plate which keeps the rack in gear with the pinion on the fly-wheel shaft. The arrangement somewhat resembles the mangle-wheel motion reversed.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1876–1238, S.M. 856.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 176.
Object name: MODEL OF A LADDER CONNECTING-ROD.
Maker/Donor: Watt
Date of creation: 1871 (Collection)
Object entry information: This shows a mechanism similar to that of the adjoining model; it was schemed about the same time and for the same reason. It shows a connecting-rod with a rack at the end composed of rungs capable of acting on either side of a pinion fixed on the shaft of the engine. The teeth being kept in gear during a portion of each stroke by two fixed pins or rollers outside the rack, while on turning the dead centres, projecting pins, one at each end on opposite sides of the rack, are guided by the curved edges of plates fixed to the framing.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1876–1238a, S.M. 855.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 177.
Object name: MODELS OF INTERNALLY GEARED CONNECTING-RODS.
Maker/Donor: Watt
Date of creation: 1871 (Collection)
Object entry information: These models show another of the mechanisms patented in 1781 by James Watt as an equivalent of the crank. The connecting-rod end is formed into a large internal spur wheel which gears with a spur wheel on the fly-wheel shaft, the teeth being kept in gear by means of a roller at the lower end of the connecting-rod which works on a fixed oval-shaped guide block below the shaft.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1876–1239, and 1876–1240, S.M. 857.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 178.
Object name: MODEL OF A CROWN CAM MOTION ADAPTED TO A WINDING GEAR.
Maker/Donor: Watt
Date of creation: 1876 (Collection)
Object entry information: This shows another of the mechanisms patented in 1781 by James Watt as an equivalent of the crank. A connecting rod from the engine beam rocks an equal-armed lever having two conical rollers mounted on it, one at either end. The centre on which the lever moves is close to a vertical shaft on which are mounted a crown cam of considerable throw and a heavy fly-wheel. By the reciprocation of the engine beam, the conical rollers are caused to press upwards alternately against the edge of the crown cam and through the inclined action cause it to rotate. The fly-wheel is for the purpose of carrying the cam over its dead centres. A spur pinion on the fly-wheel shaft gears into a large spur wheel formed on the winding drum.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1876–1265, S.M. 854.
title: Model of Sun and Planet Gearing
description: Model of sun and planet gearing, made by James Watt ,1782-1784, demonstrating the action designed to produce a rotative motion. Preserved by James Watt & Co.

Catalogue number: 180.
Object name: DISCONNECTING CRANKS. Watt Collection, 1876.
Maker/Donor: N/A
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: The arrangement consists of two discs facing one another, one of which carries the crankpin and the other is secured to the shafting. Connection between the discs is made by three hinged tongues attached to the crankplate, and capable of being dropped into three notches in the driving disc, springs retaining these tongues in the closed or open position. An unfinished specimen of this gear is also shown.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1876–1262, S.M. 817.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 181.
Object name: CYLINDER DRAIN AND RELIEF VALVE. Lent by H. P. Holt, Esq., 1879.
Maker/Donor: H. P. Holt, Esq.
Date of creation: 1878
Object entry information: This arrangement of valve, patented by Mr. Holt in 1878, combines in one fitting the drainage and relief safety valves for both ends of an engine cylinder. Pipes from the two ends enter the casing shown, and the discharged water from the cylinder is carried off by a central pipe. In the casing is a valve for each end of the cylinder, and each of these valves consists of a central disc or drain valve, and also of a double-seated annular valve outside, which is the relief valve; these annular valves are kept on their seats by springs. The action is such that, when steam is in one end of the cylinder, its pressure opens the drain valve of the other end or exhaust side, while, at any time, the central or relief portion of the valve will open should the pressure, through priming, exceed the limit determined by the springs.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1879–7.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 182.
Object name: DRAWING OF AN INTERMEDIATE RECEIVER. Lent by E. A. Cowper, Esq., 1887.
Maker/Donor: E. A. Cowper, Esq.
Date of creation: 1857
Object entry information: This is a steam-jacketed vessel, commonly called “Cowper’s hot-pot,” for receiving the steam after it has been used and expanded in the high-pressure cylinder of a compound engine, and before it passes to the low-pressure cylinder: then, when the cranks have moved 90 deg., the steam passes out to the low-pressure cylinder, and in doing so is obliged to pass outside a lining and in close contact with the hot steam-jacketed vessel, thus becoming somewhat warmed up; it is then used and expanded in the low-pressure cylinder, thus allowing of a large amount of expansion and consequent economy. The cranks are placed at 90 deg., and the steam is cut off before half stroke in the low-pressure cylinder so that a second charge of steam is not allowed to enter it in the middle of the stroke. The receiver was first introduced in 1857, and the internal lining was added in 1862.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1887–80.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 183.
Object name: MODEL PISTON. Watt Collection, 1876.
Maker/Donor: N/A
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: This piston was intended possibly for a working model of an atmospheric beam engine. The staple at the top would enable the piston to be attached to the beam by means of a chain. A piston of this description can be seen in the working model No. 52.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1876–1489. S.M. 1053.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 184.
Object name: PISTON OF ATMOSPHERIC ENGINE. Presented by Messrs. J. & J. Charlesworth, Ltd., 1920.
Maker/Donor: Messrs. J. & J. Charlesworth, Ltd.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: This piston and accessories formed part of an atmospheric type pumping engine at Newmarket Silkstone Colliery, Stanery, near Wakefield, locally known as “Old Sarah,” the date of erection of which is not known. The engine was working up to August, 1917, pumping water from a depth of 330 ft. in two lifts, at an average speed of 5 strokes per minute. It was dismantled in 1918.
Object/Inventory number: N/A

title: Holt's patent cylinder drain and relief valve
description: Cylinder drain and relief valve by Percy Holt, 1879

Object name: DRAWING OF AN INTERMEDIATE RECEIVER. Lent by E. A. Cowper, Esq., 1887.
Maker/Donor: E. A. Cowper, Esq.
Object entry information: This is a steam-jacketed vessel, commonly called “Cowper’s hot-pot,” for receiving the steam after it has been used and expanded in the high-pressure cylinder of a compound engine, and before it passes to the low-pressure cylinder: then, when the cranks have moved 90 deg., the steam passes out to the low-pressure cylinder, and in doing so is obliged to pass outside a lining and in close contact with the hot steam-jacketed vessel, thus becoming somewhat warmed up; it is then used and expanded in the low-pressure cylinder, thus allowing of a large amount of expansion and consequent economy. The cranks are placed at 90 deg., and the steam is cut off before half stroke in the low-pressure cylinder so that a second charge of steam is not allowed to enter it in the middle of the stroke. The receiver was first introduced in 1857, and the internal lining was added in 1862.

Object name: DRAWING OF CROWN CAM WINDING GEAR. (Scale 1: 36.) Received 1920.
Maker/Donor: N/A

Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1920–96.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 180.
Object name: DISCONNECTING CRANKS. Watt Collection, 1876.
Maker/Donor: N/A
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: The arrangement consists of two discs facing one another, one of which carries the crankpin and the other is secured to the shafting. Connection between the discs is made by three hinged tongues attached to the crankplate, and capable of being dropped into three notches in the driving disc, springs retaining these tongues in the closed or open position. An unfinished specimen of this gear is also shown.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1876–1262, S.M. 817.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 181.
Object name: CYLINDER DRAIN AND RELIEF VALVE. Lent by H. P. Holt, Esq., 1879.
Maker/Donor: H. P. Holt, Esq.
Date of creation: 1878
Object entry information: This arrangement of valve, patented by Mr. Holt in 1878, combines in one fitting the drainage and relief safety valves for both ends of an engine cylinder. Pipes from the two ends enter the casing shown, and the discharged water from the cylinder is carried off by a central pipe. In the casing is a valve for each end of the cylinder, and each of these valves consists of a central disc or drain valve, and also of a double-seated annular valve outside, which is the relief valve; these annular valves are kept on their seats by springs. The action is such that, when steam is in one end of the cylinder, its pressure opens the drain valve of the other end or exhaust side, while, at any time, the central or relief portion of the valve will open should the pressure, through priming, exceed the limit determined by the springs.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1879–7.

description: Piston, probably for a model of an Atmospheric Engine

Object entry information: The piston is of cellular construction with circumfer-ential space for the packing of spun yarn, compressed by a junk ring and six cotter bolts. The portions preserved of this piston with junk ring and its rod; the piston rod, cap and cotters; and the forged iron chains connecting the piston rod to the beam. The piston is 54*25 in. diam. and had a stroke of 5 ft.
