Object entry information: of a screw which alters the width of the notch in the plunger head; increasing the width decreases the stroke of the plunger. No packings are used on the plungers and valves. The pumps are mounted on a base plate which is supported above the cover of an oil-containing chamber, so that the whole mechanism can be lifted out with the cover. The oil chamber is filled through an opening in the cover fitted with a strainer; this opening is closed by a cap which also covers the ends of the oil induction pipes. The pump suction pipes are provided with strainers, and the oil chamber is fitted with a transparent slot to show the oil level. The pump is driven by a worm wheel and a horizontal shaft fitted in the lower part of the oil chamber.
Each pump delivers from 0 to 0.2 c.c. of oil per stroke, and makes 10 effective strokes per min. The driving shaft is geared to run at either 250 or 500 rev. per min.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1912–57, S.M. 539.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 275.
Object name: OIL STRAINER.
Maker/Donor: Presented by Messrs. Auto-Klean Strainers, Ltd.
Date of creation: 1924.
Object entry information: This shows a form of strainer for lubricating or fuel oil, patented by Mr. F. C. Fulle in 1919, and is intended to replace strainers which are dependent for their action on gauze or perforated metal. The oil or other fluid is passed through a series of fine slots in the wall of a cylindrical cartridge formed by a pile of circular metal discs mounted on a central spindle and interleaved by thin washers, the thickness of which is a measure of the fineness of the straining required. The dirt suspended in the liquid is intercepted by the edges of the discs, which in course of time become coated. To clear off the dirt the handle at the end of the strainer is given a quarter turn, which revolves the discs against a series of stationary cleaning blades which are slightly thinner than the distance between the slots. The cleaning edge of the blades is set obliquely to the periphery of the cartridge face. The blades therefore have a wedging action on the dirt, carrying it from the inside to the outside of the slot, and clear of the cartridge face. The dirt settles to the bottom of the sump provided which may be cleaned out by removing the screwed plug. The base, coupling bolts and tubular body can be removed, fully exposing the cartridge if required for inspection purposes.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1924–350.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 276.
Object name: LOCK NUT.
Maker/Donor: Presented by D. Halpin, Esq.
Date of creation: 1885.
Object entry information: This nut, which is about double the ordinary length, is given a certain amount of elasticity by having a saw-cut made parallel to its axis, and extending about half way down. The cut portion is then closed in so that, when screwed on, the bolt has to expand the inner end of the nut against the elasticity of the material, and in this way any shaking is prevented.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1885–206.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 277.
Object name: LOCK NUT.
Maker/Donor: Presented by T. K. Mellor, Esq.
Date of creation: 1884.
Object entry information: In this nut-locking arrangement, patented by Mr. Mellor in 1884, two longitudinal grooves are cut through the thread of the bolt, and two inclined holes are drilled through the nut from its side to its thread; a piece of wire is passed through the nut and along one of the holes can be forced along the groove in the bolt, and then bent so as to retain itself in position, while also acting as a key between the nut and bolt. The holes in the nut are 90 deg. apart, and the grooves in the bolt being opposite, there are four points in each turn in which the nut can be locked.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1884–210.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 278.
Object name: LOCKING WASHER.
Maker/Donor: Lent by Messrs. J. H. Ladd & Co.
Date of creation: 1888.
Object entry information: This is a spring washer, patented in 1886 by Mr. H. A. Harvey. It consists of a cylindrical steel washer, cut through radially in one place, and then bent to form a helical section, so that the sharp ends of the metal tend to prevent rotation of the nut. The upper face of the washer has a central conical projection, while the middle portion of the nut face is correspondingly recessed, so that in screwing home the nut, the washer, in addition to being flattened, is also closed upon the thread of the bolt and thus caused to grip it.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1888–334.

Maker/Donor: Lent by W. Armstrong, Esq., 1889.
Object entry information: This arrangement of locked nut was patented by Mr. Armstrong in 1887. An ordinary hexagonal nut is used, but the outer end of the bolt is reduced to a square section and fitted with a washer having a square hole in its centre and provided with two lugs which are bent down to hold the nut. When the nut is screwed home, this washer, or cap, is slipped on and retained by a split pin beyond it.

Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: This arrangement was patented by Mr. S. Bayliss in 1887. The nut is forged with an annular projection or lip which, by caulking, can be embedded in the metal of the bolt.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1888-335.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 281.
Object name: LOCK NUT AND WASHER.
Maker/Donor: Lent by The Patent Rivet Co., 1889.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: The device here adopted for preventing the slacking back of the nut was patented by Mr. J. K. Hargrave in 1888, and is a combination of a special nut and washer. The lower face of the nut is formed with a step and a helical surface, and the upper face of the washer is similarly constructed, the pitches of the helical grooves being greater than that of the thread of the bolt. When being screwed on, the nut rotates the washer by the direct contact of the steps, but afterwards, should the nut attempt to unscrew, and provided that the washer does not rotate with it, the bolt is tightened up by the resulting differential screw action. The washer is made hexagonal, in order that both nut and washer may be unscrewed together by a spanner, while to prevent the accidental rotation of the washer its lower face is made concave, so that the corners shall bite into the metal fish-plate.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1889-100.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 282.
Object name: LOCK NUT.
Maker/Donor: Lent by Messrs Ibbotson Bros. & Co., 1888.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: Two forms of this nut are shown, but the action is the same in both cases. The nut is similar to that of Halpin, but has two saw-cuts instead of one. This form of lock nut has been extensively adopted for permanent way, but to prevent the formation of rust in the saw-cuts it has been found well to fill them up with thick grease.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1888-333.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 283.
Object name: HELICOID LOCK NUT.
Maker/Donor: Presented by The Helicoid Locknut Co., 1899.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: These specimens show the construction and method of manufacture of an elastic nut patented by Mr. F. Mottershall in 1892. The nut consists of a short length of a closely wound helix which is tapped with a thread of slightly less pitch than that of the bolt it is to fit, so that screwing the nut on to the bolt causes the helix to lengthen and thus give a continuous grip for the purpose of preventing slacking back by vibration. The nuts are made from a mild steel bar of trapezoidal section, which is wound, while cold, as a left-hand thread upon a central mandrel in a coiling machine resembling a lathe. The distortion of the bar in winding alters the section of the steel; the mandrel is, however, so rotated that a close coil is obtained; the metal is easily released by slightly reversing the twist. This tube is then cut by circular saws into lengths sufficient for single nuts, which are tapped with a thread of slightly smaller diameter and finer pitch than the standard bolt. If the square or hexagonal shape is required the nuts are passed through a shearing press which, in two stages, remove segments so as to leave the faces required; the chamfering and finishing are performed in a subsequent operation.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1899-123.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 284.
Object name: “TURRET” LOCK NUT.
Maker/Donor: Presented by Messrs. Vickers, Sons & Maxim, Ltd., 1909.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: This is a specimen, 1½ in. diam., of an improved form of the "castle" lock nut, patented by Messrs. J. S. Conradi, E. Tilston, and P. W. Masson in 1908. The nut has a cylindrical extension which has six radial holes drilled in it, while the end of the bolt has one or two slots cut across it. A split pin passed through the holes and slot prevents the nut from turning. The thread is removed from the upper part of the nut as far down as the bottom of the slots.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1909-119.

This form of lock nut has been extensively adopted for permanent way, but to prevent the formation of rust in the saw-cuts it has been found well to fill them up with thick grease.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1888-333.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 283.
Object name: HELICOID LOCK NUT.
Maker/Donor: Presented by The Helicoid Locknut Co., 1899.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: These specimens show the construction and method of manufacture of an elastic nut patented by Mr. F. Mottershall in 1892. The nut consists of a short length of a closely wound helix which is tapped with a thread of slightly less pitch than that of the bolt it is to fit, so that screwing the nut on to the bolt causes the helix to lengthen and thus give a continuous grip for the purpose of preventing slacking back by vibration. The nuts are made from a mild steel bar of trapezoidal section, which is wound, while cold, as a left-hand thread upon a central mandrel in a coiling machine resembling a lathe. The distortion of the bar in winding alters the section of the steel; the mandrel is, however, so rotated that a close coil is obtained; the metal is easily released by slightly reversing the twist. This tube is then cut by circular saws into lengths sufficient for single nuts, which are tapped with a thread of slightly smaller diameter and finer pitch than the standard bolt. If the square or hexagonal shape is required the nuts are passed through a shearing press which, in two stages, remove segments so as to leave the faces required; the chamfering and finishing are performed in a subsequent operation.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1899-123.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 284.
Object name: “TURRET” LOCK NUT.
Maker/Donor: Presented by Messrs. Vickers, Sons & Maxim, Ltd., 1909.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: This is a specimen, 1½ in. diam., of an improved form of the "castle" lock nut, patented by Messrs. J. S. Conradi, E. Tilston, and P. W. Masson in 1908. The nut has a cylindrical extension which has six radial holes drilled in it, while the end of the bolt has one or two slots cut across it. A split pin passed through the holes and slot prevents the nut from turning. The thread is removed from the upper part of the nut as far down as the bottom of the slots.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1909-119.

Object name: BOLT AND LOCKED NUT.
Maker/Donor: Lent by W. Armstrong, Esq., 1889.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: This arrangement of locked nut was patented by Mr. Armstrong in 1887. An ordinary hexagonal nut is used, but the outer end of the bolt is reduced to a square section and fitted with a washer having a square hole in its centre and provided with two lugs which are bent down to hold the nut. When the nut is screwed home, this washer, or cap, is slipped on and retained by a split pin beyond it.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1889-99.

Object entry information: This arrangement was patented by Mr. S. Bayliss in 1887. The nut is forged with an annular projection or lip which, by caulking, can be embedded in the metal of the bolt.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1888-335.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 281.
Object name: LOCK NUT AND WASHER.
Maker/Donor: Lent by The Patent Rivet Co., 1889.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: The device here adopted for preventing the slacking back of the nut was patented by Mr. J. K. Hargrave in 1888, and is a combination of a special nut and washer. The lower face of the nut is formed with a step and a helical surface, and the upper face of the washer is similarly constructed, the pitches of the helical grooves being greater than that of the thread of the bolt. When being screwed on, the nut rotates the washer by the direct contact of the steps, but afterwards, should the nut attempt to unscrew, and provided that the washer does not rotate with it, the bolt is tightened up by the resulting differential screw action. The washer is made hexagonal, in order that both nut and washer may be unscrewed together by a spanner, while to prevent the accidental rotation of the washer its lower face is made concave, so that the corners shall bite into the metal fish-plate.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1889-100.

title: Turret lock-nut
description: Turret lock-nut, Conrade Tilston's & Masson's patent 1908, and turned bolt, example 1" diam.

Maker/Donor: Presented by The Bevan Lock-Nut Co., Ltd.
Object entry information: These are specimens of the roller clutch type of lock nut containing improvements patented by Mr. W. R. Bevan in 1908. The nut has a longitudinal slot cut inside it, deeper at one edge than the other. A grooved roller lies in this slot and is pressed towards the narrow end by a flat spring, so that when the nut is screwed on to the bolt the roller frees itself, but should the nut tend to unscrew, the roller jams itself between the bolt thread and the back of the slot, preventing further relative motion. A hardened plate is inserted in the slot behind the roller, and the nut is recessed at the top and bottom for the reception of lipped washers that hold the roller and springs in place; the ends of the rollers are turned smaller for this purpose. In order to release the nut, a pin or wire nail is inserted through a hole in the top washer. One of the specimens shown, which are for bolts of 1 in. diam., has two rollers fitted so that it cannot move in either direction until a releasing pin is placed between the rollers to hold them out of engagement with the bolt.

Object entry information: These are specimens of the roller clutch type of lock nut containing improvements patented by Mr. W. R. Bevan in 1908. The nut has a longitudinal slot cut inside it, deeper at one edge than the other. A grooved roller lies in this slot and is pressed towards the narrow end by a flat spring, so that when the nut is screwed on to the bolt the roller frees itself, but should the nut tend to unscrew, the roller jams itself between the bolt thread and the back of the slot, preventing further relative motion. Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 286.
Object name: LOCK NUT AND BOLT.
Maker/Donor: Presented by The Automatic Lock Nut Co., Ltd.
Date of creation: 1909.
Object entry information: This form of lock nut was patented by Mr. A. E. Terry in 1908. It locks itself on its bolt by means of a helical wire spring which is fitted in a recess formed in the upper part of the nut and is coiled round the thread. One end of the coil is secured in a hole in the nut while the other end is normally free. The nut may be easily screwed on, because the coil tends to unwind and thus frees the bolt, but, should the nut tend to unscrew, the coil will wind itself and securely grip the bolt thread. The lock is released by the insertion of a pin, through a hole, so as to push back the free end of the coil and prevent it from closing on the bolt. A complete bolt and nut, 1 in. diam., are shown, and also a sectioned nut with its coil.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1909-120.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 287.
Object name: SPRING-LOCK WASHERS.
Maker/Donor: Presented by the Harvey Spring-Lock Washer Co., Ltd.
Date of creation: 1912.
Object entry information: These are washers designed to prevent nuts slacking back under vibration. They are made by the method patented in 1910 by Mr. J. M. Lambie, Mr. C. R. Wrigley, and Mr. J. Lambie. The blank is first sheared circumferentially in two places, thereby stretching the metal. The resulting segments are then sheared radially, thus forming when bent four tongues, the sharp edges of which tend to bite and prevent rotation of the nut. The washers are of spring steel hardened in oil and can be used repeatedly. A number of sizes from 0.25 in. to 1.25 in. diam. galvanised by electro deposition are shown, but black washers are obtainable.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1912-137.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 288.
Object name: RICHARDS'S LOCK NUT.
Maker/Donor: Presented by Blanton Patents Syndicate, Ltd.
Date of creation: 1912.
Object entry information: This method of locking a nut, by means of spring teeth engaging with the thread of the bolt, was patented in 1910 by Mr. D. Richards. In the angle of the nut a slotted hole accommodates a steel spindle with three hardened and backed-off teeth matching the threads. A coiled spring tends to rotate the spindle and make the teeth dig into the bolt thread when unscrewing. To retain the spindle in the free position there is a lever on it, with a stop on its underside catching on a burr on the nut. All sizes from 0.125 in. diam. upwards, with or without the releasing lever, are made. The size shown is 1 in. diam.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1912-138.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 289.
Object name: LOCK NUTS.
Maker/Donor: Presented by Messrs. Vislok, Ltd.
Date of creation: 1919.
Object entry information: This lock nut, known as the "Vislok," is in two inseparable parts capable of relative rotation, patented in 1910 by Mr. W. C. Peters. The upper part of the nut has a conical seating in the underside of the nut and tails into the undercut edge of the upper part. A line is stamped across the junction of the parts and the whole nut tapped as usual. In screwing on to the bolt, a spanner rotates both parts together in line. To lock the nut, the top half is rotated relative to the lower. Not only does this give the wedging action of ordinary double nuts, but it introduces also a radial pressure due to the wedging of the dovetail; it is claimed that this renders the nut immovable. The thread is not damaged and the nut can be used repeatedly.
Object/Inventory number: N/A

Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1912-137.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 288.
Object name: RICHARDS'S LOCK NUT.
Maker/Donor: Presented by Blanton Patents Syndicate, Ltd.
Date of creation: 1912.
Object entry information: This method of locking a nut, by means of spring teeth engaging with the thread of the bolt, was patented in 1910 by Mr. D. Richards. In the angle of the nut a slotted hole accommodates a steel spindle with three hardened and backed-off teeth matching the threads. A coiled spring tends to rotate the spindle and make the teeth dig into the bolt thread when unscrewing. To retain the spindle in the free position there is a lever on it, with a stop on its underside catching on a burr on the nut. All sizes from 0.125 in. diam. upwards, with or without the releasing lever, are made. The size shown is 1 in. diam.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1912-138.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 289.
Object name: LOCK NUTS.
Maker/Donor: Presented by Messrs. Vislok, Ltd.
Date of creation: 1919.
Object entry information: This lock nut, known as the "Vislok," is in two inseparable parts capable of relative rotation, patented in 1910 by Mr. W. C. Peters. The upper part of the nut has a conical seating in the underside of the nut and tails into the undercut edge of the upper part. A line is stamped across the junction of the parts and the whole nut tapped as usual. In screwing on to the bolt, a spanner rotates both parts together in line. To lock the nut, the top half is rotated relative to the lower. Not only does this give the wedging action of ordinary double nuts, but it introduces also a radial pressure due to the wedging of the dovetail; it is claimed that this renders the nut immovable. The thread is not damaged and the nut can be used repeatedly.
Object/Inventory number: N/A
title: Lamrig spring-lock washers
description: Lamrig (Lambie and Wrigleys patent 1910) spring-lock washers galvanised by electrodeposition viz:- 1 - 1 1/4" diam; and 1 - 1/4" diam.

Maker/Donor: Presented by Blanton Patents Syndicate, Ltd.
Object entry information: This method of locking a nut, by means of spring teeth engaging with the thread of the bolt, was patented in 1910 by Mr. D. Richards. Raw_Response:
Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 285.
Object name: LOCK NUTS.
Maker/Donor: Presented by The Bevan Lock-Nut Co., Ltd.
Date of creation: 1909.
Object entry information: These are specimens of the roller clutch type of lock nut containing improvements patented by Mr. W. R. Bevan in 1908. The nut has a longitudinal slot cut inside it, deeper at one edge than the other. A grooved roller lies in this slot and is pressed towards the narrow end by a flat spring, so that when the nut is screwed on to the bolt the roller frees itself, but should the nut tend to unscrew, the roller jams itself between the bolt thread and the back of the slot, preventing further relative motion. A hardened plate is inserted in the slot behind the roller, and the nut is recessed at the top and bottom for the reception of lipped washers that hold the roller and springs in place; the ends of the rollers are turned smaller for this purpose. In order to release the nut, a pin or wire nail is inserted through a hole in the top washer. One of the specimens shown, which are for bolts of 1 in. diam., has two rollers fitted so that it cannot move in either direction until a releasing pin is placed between the rollers to hold them out of engagement with the bolt.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1909-124 to 126.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 286.
Object name: LOCK NUT AND BOLT.
Maker/Donor: Presented by The Automatic Lock Nut Co., Ltd.
Date of creation: 1909.
Object entry information: This form of lock nut was patented by Mr. A. E. Terry in 1908. It locks itself on its bolt by means of a helical wire spring which is fitted in a recess formed in the upper part of the nut and is coiled round the thread. One end of the coil is secured in a hole in the nut while the other end is normally free. The nut may be easily screwed on, because the coil tends to unwind and thus frees the bolt, but, should the nut tend to unscrew, the coil will wind itself and securely grip the bolt thread. The lock is released by the insertion of a pin, through a hole, so as to push back the free end of the coil and prevent it from closing on the bolt. A complete bolt and nut, 1 in. diam., are shown, and also a sectioned nut with its coil.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1909-120.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 287.
Object name: SPRING-LOCK WASHERS.
Maker/Donor: Presented by the Harvey Spring-Lock Washer Co., Ltd.
Date of creation: 1912.
Object entry information: These are washers designed to prevent nuts slacking back under vibration. They are made by the method patented in 1910 by Mr. J. M. Lambie, Mr. C. R. Wrigley, and Mr. J. Lambie. The blank is first sheared circumferentially in two places, thereby stretching the metal. The resulting segments are then sheared radially, thus forming when bent four tongues, the sharp edges of which tend to bite and prevent rotation of the nut. The washers are of spring steel hardened in oil and can be used repeatedly. A number of sizes from 0.25 in. to 1.25 in. diam. galvanised by electro deposition are shown, but black washers are obtainable.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1912-137.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 290.
Object name: LOCK NUT.
Maker/Donor: Presented by Messrs. Lock-Nuts, Ltd.
Date of creation: 1921.
Object entry information: This lock-nut, known as the "Otter," is on the roller clutch principle. A hole is bored in the nut tangential to the diameter, and in this is inserted a spring bolt at the end of which is a roller pawl of the same outline as the thread. The bolt is held up to its work by a dovetailed slide covering the hole. The nut can be screwed up, but until the slide is raised and the bolt released, the nut cannot be unscrewed, nor, it is claimed, can it slack back. The example shown is for a 1 in. diam. bolt.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1921-553.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 291.
Object name: LOCK WASHER.
Maker/Donor: Presented by The Palnut Co., Ltd.
Date of creation: 1921.
Object entry information: This lock washer, known as the "Palnut," is a substitute for a second nut. It consists of a steel stamping, the centre portion of which is cut into a number of spring fingers which fit into the thread of the bolt. The outer edges of the washer are turned up to correspond with the hexagon nut which it is intended to lock. After the nut has been screwed down, the washer is run down the thread, and finally a quarter turn is given to it. This, it is claimed, effectually locks the nut. The example shown is applied to a bolt and nut 1 in. diam.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1921-554.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 292.
Object name: PIPE JOINTS.
Maker/Donor: Lent by Messrs. Stewarts & Lloyds, Ltd.
Date of creation: 1914.
Object entry information: These actual sections represent different forms of making joints in steel tubing suitable for steam; they are all for a diameter of 4 in. *Wrought Steel Welded-on Flange Joint.*—Wrought steel flanges are welded on to the ends of the tubes, faced over, and the joint made by corrugated copper insertion. *No. 1 Loose Flange Joint.*—The tube ends are flanged outwards half an inch and between these packing is inserted. The joint is drawn together by two cast-steel flanges loose on the tubes and made with spigot and faucet to cover the joint. *"Albion" Loose Flange Joint.*—Collars half an inch square are welded on to the ends of the tubes, faced over and the joint made by insertion drawn up by cast-steel loose collars one of which has a spigot to cover the packing. *"Vulcan" Loose Flange Expansion Joint.*—This was patented in 1912 by Mr. J. G. Stewart and the firm. The end of one tube is expanded to allow the other tube to be inserted 3 in. The tube is expanded half an inch more at the mouth for a length of 1 in. and into this recess packing is caulked. This is tightened by two loose cast-steel flanges, one of which fits the externally expanded part of the tube and the other bears on the packing in the recess.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1914-226 to 229.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 293.
Object name: ROCKWOOD PRESSED STEEL UNIONS.
Maker/Donor: Presented by The Crosby Valve and Engineering Co., Ltd.
Date of creation: 1920.
Object entry information: These are examples of the pipe union patented by the Rockwood Sprinkler Co., in 1914. The unions are made of pressed steel and are fitted with spherical faced bronze seats which are ground together to form a tight joint. They are designed for working pressures up to 500 lb. per sq. in. and are specially suited for air pressure mains. The joint consists of two steel liners and a steel nut, all of which are pressed into shape hydraulically. The nut has prominent external ribs which take the standard spanner and also permit the joint to be tightened up by a hammer and bar in positions where a spanner could not be used. The liners are also ribbed to assist them on the ends of the pipes to be joined in place so that they are immovable. The bronze seats are pressed into place so that they are across its thread so that a screw of the nut has grooves cut across its thread so that paraffin may be introduced to loosen it if necessary. The nut and liners are sherardized after the threads are cut, and so made rust proof.
Object/Inventory number: N/A

The nut has prominent external ribs which take the standard spanner and also permit the joint to be tightened up by a hammer and bar in positions where a spanner could not be used. The liners are also ribbed to assist them on the ends of the pipes to be joined in place so that they are immovable. The bronze seats are pressed into place so that they are across its thread so that a screw of the nut has grooves cut across its thread so that paraffin may be introduced to loosen it if necessary. The nut and liners are sherardized after the threads are cut, and so made rust proof.
Object/Inventory number: N/A

Object entry information: For use with superheated steam, hot gases and chemicals the unions are made with steel seats; they have been used successfully with temperatures up to 700° C. Two examples are shown, one being sectioned to show the construction.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 294.
Object name: VICTAULIC PIPE JOINTS.
Maker/Donor: The Victory Pipe Joint Co., Ltd.
Date of creation: 1921.
Object entry information: The victaulic joint is really a development from the hydraulic U-packing. The leak-proof ring is in effect two oppositely-placed rubber U-washers made in one piece, with the important feature that the inturned lips are made to grip the pipe ends radially. The joint was patented in 1919 by Mr. E. Tribe and developed by him and Dr. H. S. Hele-Shaw. Two forms of joint are illustrated by examples and drawings; in the pipe shown for low pressures and vacuum, the pipes being buried or anchored, the leak-proof ring and its malleable iron housing is simply slipped over adjacent ends of the pipes. The pipe shown is 3.5 in. outside diam. In the "A," or floating joint for high pressures and pipes free to move, the leak-proof ring is similar, but the ends of the pipe are grooved circumferentially. The housing is in halves and the leak-proof ring fits into these grooves, where it is retained on endways and retained by set screws. This pipe is 2 in. internal diam. There are other applications of the ring, e.g., in gland packing. It is claimed for this joint that it takes up very little space and thus saves freight, &c.; that it is as easily assembled or dismantled quickly without requiring skilled labour; that it is flexible to 3 deg. in any direction without leakage; that it permits expansion because the ends of the pipe do not butt; that it is not affected by vibration or subsidence; and that it is not greater in prime cost than the ordinary flanged joint.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1921-660 & 661.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 295.
Object name: EXPANSION JOINT.
Maker/Donor: Messrs. T. B. Bilton & Sons, Ltd.
Date of creation: 1924.
Object entry information: This expansion joint has no gland or stuffing-box and can be used in inaccessible positions where it would be impracticable to use the ordinary packed joint, or difficult to employ the usual expedients of bends in the pipe. The joint consists of a bored gunmetal body and an accurately fitted inner gunmetal sleeve, the end of which is tapered; this tapered portion expands under the pressure, and ensures tightness. Safety bolts are fitted through the lugs on the flanges to prevent accidental blowing out. The joint exhibited is suitable for a steam pipe 2.5 in. internal diam.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1924-235.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 296.
Object name: WATT'S ENGINE COUNTER.
Maker/Donor: James Brown, Esq.
Date of creation: 1861.
Object entry information: When Messrs. Boulton and Watt were introducing their improved steam-engine for pumping in the Cornish mines, payment in many cases was made by the pumping work performed. This work was recorded by a counter, fixed on the engine beam, and constructed to register the number of strokes performed. It is stated that the mine owners objected to the readings of these instruments, on the ground that they counted the short strokes of the engine equally with the complete ones. The apparatus consists of a locked box containing a pendulum which, by a reversed escapement, drives a series of counting wheels; indexses on the spindles of these wheels register the number of oscillations on a series of dials advancing in powers of ten.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1861-43. S.M. 860.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 297.
Object name: REVOLUTION COUNTER.
Maker/Donor: the Institution of Civil Engineers.
Date of creation: 1868.
Object entry information: This is an old form of revolution counter. The gearing consists of a worm and worm-wheel, together with a train of spur-wheels for reducing the speed, and three dials over which four indexses move continuously but not all in the same direction, so that the reading is difficult, particularly at high speeds.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1868-211.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 299.
Object name: FIVE-FIGURE REVOLUTION COUNTER.
Maker/Donor: Contributed by R. Roberts, Esq.
Date of creation: 1858.
Object entry information: This instrument, invented by Mr. Roberts, consists of five wheels, each marked with the ten numerals on the edge; all but the first wheel run loose on the horizontal shaft of the counter. On one side of each wheel is a ten-pointed recess, and on the opposite side of the wheel is an eccentric boss; on each boss is a loose ring from which projects downward a tail that prevents its rotation, while from the face of the ring project three teeth, which engage in the recesses in the adjacent wheel. The result of this connection is that each wheel is driven at one-tenth of the speed of the wheel driving it, so that read along a horizontal line the revolutions are indicated in a very convenient form for reading; the advance of each wheel is, however, continuous, so that the trouble of half figures is not avoided.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1858–10.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 300.
Object name: REVOLUTION COUNTER.
Maker/Donor: Contributed by R. Roberts, Esq.
Date of creation: 1862.
Object entry information: This counter indicates by the use of two concentric revolving dials geared together by an epicyclic train. The dials are on a central fixed stud, which also carries a double-ended pointer. The larger dial has a toothed edge and is driven by a worm from the shaft whose revolutions are to be counted; the ratio of the gearing is 1:100, so the dial counts up to 100 rev. The dial carries thirty-nine teeth fixed to the stud, and also into a wheel of forty teeth secured to the back of the inner dial. By this means the inner dial, which reads up to 4,000, is rotated at 1-40th of the speed of the outer one.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1862–16.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 301.
Object name: ELECTRICAL COUNTER.
Maker/Donor: Wheatstone Collection.
Date of creation: 1884.
Object entry information: This instrument, patented by Sir C. Wheatstone in 1858, consists of two dials over which pointers are moved by gearing from a step-by-step propulsion actuated by an electro-magnet. The poles of the latter are adjacent, and between them oscillates a magnetised needle carrying the arbor of a ratchet wheel of fifteen teeth, which engages with a fixed pawl and is thus slowly turned by the currents received; this motion is recorded by a counter.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1884–206.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 302.
Object name: HAND REVOLUTION COUNTER.
Maker/Donor: Made by The Connecticut Cutlery Co. Received 1914.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: This is an early form of counter, the driving spindle of which is held, by hand, in contact with the end of the shaft of which the revolutions are to be counted. The mechanism is contained in a circular brass case having the driving spindle projecting from one edge, while a handle is attached to the opposite point of the circumference. Inside the casing a worm on the spindle drives a worm-wheel to the axis of which an index is attached; this index moves over a dial having 100 divisions, each representing one revolution of the driving spindle. A second index is driven intermittently by a pin on the worm-wheel at one-tenth the speed of the first, so that it registers hundreds of revolutions up to a total of 1,000 rev.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1914–287.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 303.
Object name: REVOLUTION COUNTER.
Maker/Donor: Lent by R. Applegarth, Esq.
Date of creation: 1879.
Object entry information: This is a pocket counter, patented by Mr. A. Sainte in 1877, provided with fittings by which it will readily connect with any revolving shaft, if the end be accessible. When this is not the case a small wooden roller, the circumference of which is one-tenth of a yard, is slipped on the counter, and employed to measure the circumferential velocity of the shaft, pulley, or belt. A small plumb-bob is also included which can be used as a seconds pendulum for giving the time. The instrument is provided with a handle so that it can be pressed.
Object/Inventory number: N/A
title: Revolution Counter
description: Revolution Counter

Maker/Donor: Contributed by R. Roberts, Esq.
Object entry information: This instrument, invented by Mr. Roberts, consists of five wheels, each marked with the ten numerals on the edge; all but the first wheel run loose on the horizontal shaft of the counter. On one side of each wheel is a ten-pointed recess, and on the opposite side of the wheel is an eccentric boss; on each boss is a loose ring from which projects downward a tail that prevents its rotation, while from the face of the ring project three teeth, which engage in the recesses in the adjacent wheel. The result of this connection is that each wheel is driven at one-tenth of the speed of the wheel driving it, so that read along a horizontal line the revolutions are indicated in a very convenient form for reading; the advance of each wheel is, however, continuous, so that the trouble of half figures is not avoided.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 300.
Object name: REVOLUTION COUNTER.
Maker/Donor: Contributed by R. Roberts, Esq.
Date of creation: 1862.
Object entry information: This counter indicates by the use of two concentric revolving dials geared together by an epicyclic train. The dials are on a central fixed stud, which also carries a double-ended pointer. The larger dial has a toothed edge and is driven by a worm from the shaft whose revolutions are to be counted; the ratio of the gearing is 1:100, so the dial counts up to 100 rev. The dial carries thirty-nine teeth fixed to the stud, and also into a wheel of forty teeth secured to the back of the inner dial. By this means the inner dial, which reads up to 4,000, is rotated at 1-40th of the speed of the outer one.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1862–16.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 301.
Object name: ELECTRICAL COUNTER.
Maker/Donor: Wheatstone Collection.
Date of creation: 1884.
Object entry information: This instrument, patented by Sir C. Wheatstone in 1858, consists of two dials over which pointers are moved by gearing from a step-by-step propulsion actuated by an electro-magnet. The poles of the latter are adjacent, and between them oscillates a magnetised needle carrying the arbor of a ratchet wheel of fifteen teeth, which engages with a fixed pawl and is thus slowly turned by the currents received; this motion is recorded by a counter.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1884–206.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 302.
Object name: HAND REVOLUTION COUNTER.
Maker/Donor: Made by The Connecticut Cutlery Co. Received 1914.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: This is an early form of counter, the driving spindle of which is held, by hand, in contact with the end of the shaft of which the revolutions are to be counted. The mechanism is contained in a circular brass case having the driving spindle projecting from one edge, while a handle is attached to the opposite point of the circumference. Inside the casing a worm on the spindle drives a worm-wheel to the axis of which an index is attached; this index moves over a dial having 100 divisions, each representing one revolution of the driving spindle. A second index is driven intermittently by a pin on the worm-wheel at one-tenth the speed of the first, so that it registers hundreds of revolutions up to a total of 1,000 rev.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1914–287.

title: Small Hand revolution Counter

Object entry information: against the revolving shaft, and the motion obtained drives a single worm that gears into a lower worm-wheel of 100 teeth, having a graduated disc. On the spindle of this wheel is a pinion of ten teeth gearing into a wheel of 100 teeth, the disc of which is also graduated, the total ratio being such that one revolution of the worm-wheel is made corresponds with 1,000 rev. on the shaft. The arm carrying the worm-wheel is hinged, so that the whole counter can be thrown out of action without removing it from the shaft, or the gear can be disengaged for bringing the dials to zero.

Catalogue number: 304.
Object name: COUNTER.
Maker/Donor: Contributed by W. Smith, Esq.
Date of creation: 1876.
Object entry information: This is a counter invented by Mr. J. Norton. It is actuated by a reciprocating motion and the index and number dials move intermittently, so that there is no uncertainty through the display of half figures. The operating lever has a pawl mounted upon it that drives a ratchet wheel on the spindle of the index, showing figures through holes in the front plate, which carry the reading to units and tens. There are also six small rotating numbered dials. The first of these has on its spindle a ratchet wheel driven by a single tooth on the pawl actuated by a snail-cam on the index spindle, while a snail-cam on the index spindle drives intermittently a wheel of ten teeth on the second, and so on throughout the series. Light springs, engaging with secondary toothed wheels on the spindles, hold them stationary between the movements.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1876–1449.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 305.
Object name: SIX-FIGURE COUNTER.
Maker/Donor: Lent by Messrs. Schäffer & Budenberg.
Date of creation: 1888.
Object entry information: This is an instrument arranged for counting either reciprocating motions or revolutions; it contains a vibrating lever, to which motion may be given direct, and also a crank by which the lever may be vibrated when it is desired to count revolutions. A toothed wheel on the spindle of the dial containing the unit figures is driven by the lever, by means of a movement very similar to the escapement of a clock reversed. Another wheel on the same spindle, having one tooth on its edge, drives intermittently a wheel with ten teeth on the spindle of the tens dial, and so on throughout the series.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1888–264.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 306.
Object name: REVOLUTION COUNTER.
Maker/Donor: Lent by Messrs. W. H. Bailey and Co.
Date of creation: 1888.
Object entry information: This is an instrument for counting the number of revolutions made by an engine, etc. An external lever is actuated by some reciprocating part, and by means of a pawl works a ratchet wheel on the spindle of the central index, which records units and tens on the principal dial. Six smaller dials give the higher multiples of tens up to tens of millions, the hands of these being driven from the central spindle.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1888–362.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 307.
Object name: REVOLUTION COUNTER.
Maker/Donor: Presented by Messrs. Harding, Rhodes & Co., Ltd.
Date of creation: 1919.
Object entry information: This is a six-figure revolution counter of the form patented by Messrs. T. R. and T. W. Harding in 1881; it is intended for counting the revolutions of general machinery, the drive being taken directly from a revolving shaft. The counting mechanism is similar to that of the larger counter (see No. 307A), but the arrangement for driving the first numbered drum is different. The main shaft upon which the drums are mounted passes right through the casing, and may be driven from either end. At the right-hand end of this shaft an eccentric is fitted, the strap of which takes the form of a ring having attached to it an arm projecting downwards and guided between two pins, so that, while the nine-toothed pinion is carried round in a circular path, it cannot rotate on its axis. The pinion gears with an internally toothed ring on the first numbered drum, and as the shaft revolves once the drum makes one-tenth of a turn in the same direction. The counter is fitted in a circular casing, the numbers being formed in indelible black on white porcelain faced drums and brought close up to the glass front.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1919–402, S.M. 1238 & 1239.

Catalogue number: 305.
Object name: SIX-FIGURE COUNTER.
Maker/Donor: Lent by Messrs. Schäffer & Budenberg.
Date of creation: 1888.
Object entry information: This is an instrument arranged for counting either reciprocating motions or revolutions; it contains a vibrating lever, to which motion may be given direct, and also a crank by which the lever may be vibrated when it is desired to count revolutions. A toothed wheel on the spindle of the dial containing the unit figures is driven by the lever, by means of a movement very similar to the escapement of a clock reversed. Another wheel on the same spindle, having one tooth on its edge, drives intermittently a wheel with ten teeth on the spindle of the tens dial, and so on throughout the series.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1888–264.

Six smaller dials give the higher multiples of tens up to tens of millions, the hands of these being driven from the central spindle.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1888–362.

Catalogue number: 304.
Object name: COUNTER.
Maker/Donor: Contributed by W. Smith, Esq.
Date of creation: 1876.
Object entry information: This is a counter invented by Mr. J. Norton. Light springs, engaging with secondary toothed wheels on the spindles, hold them stationary between the movements.

Object entry information: The figures are placed on the peripheries of wheels, and the movement of the unit figure wheel is effected, as in Watt's and many other counters, by a reversed escapement; a crankpin engaging with a slotted lever secured to the pallets imparts the necessary reciprocating motion to the latter. A single tooth attached to the axis of the first wheel drives, intermittently, a wheel with ten projecting teeth, and so on throughout the series. Each of the figured wheels is locked during the intervals between the step movements by a projecting rim, on the preceding driving wheel, passing between the overhanging teeth.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 309.
Object name: RECIPROCATING COUNTER.
Maker/Donor: Made by Messrs. Schäffer & Budenberg.
Date of creation: Received 1914.
Object entry information: This is a six-figure counter, actuated by a reciprocating lever, for registering the number of revolutions of an engine. The number dials are placed side by side on parallel spindles, and are numbered on their faces. Beneath each dial, and fixed to its spindle, are two toothed wheels and a finger; one of the wheels has 10 saw-shaped teeth, and the other is similar, but has one tooth cut away. The driving lever is pivoted on the base of the counter, and its shorter arm engages with the 10-tooth wheel on the first spindle and moves it one-tenth of a revolution on each forward stroke. On the completion of one revolution of the units dial, the finger on its spindle engages with the 10-tooth wheel on the second spindle and rotates it one-tenth of a revolution, and so on throughout the series. The dials are held stationary between movements by spring pawls engaging with the 10-toothed wheels. The dials may be set to zero by a sliding bar carrying six hook-shaped springs that engage with the nine-toothed wheels and pull them round until the missing tooth prevents further movement.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1914–286.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 310.
Object name: COMBINED REVOLUTION COUNTER AND STOP WATCH.
Maker/Donor: N/A
Date of creation: Received 1914.
Object entry information: This is a hand revolution counter combined with a stop watch, and it is so arranged that counter and watch are started and stopped simultaneously. It was patented by Mr. J. Jaquet in 1893. The four-figure counter is of the Harding type (see Nos. 307 and 307A), and its driving spindle projects from one side of the casing. The motion of the machine is transmitted to the spindle through an extension bar with a triangular pointed outer end, while its inner end is provided with a slot that engages with a pin passing through the spindle. When the counter is at rest this driving pin is covered by a sliding sleeve, held up by a spring, and this sleeve must be depressed by the extension bar before the counter mechanism can operate. The sleeve also works a catch which normally holds the balance wheel of the watch stationary, but releases it when the sleeve is depressed, so that the counter and watch start recording together, and stop together when the pressure on the extension bar is released. The watch reads to one-fifth of a second, and is fitted with the usual zero setter.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1914–288.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 311.
Object name: SPEED INDICATOR.
Maker/Donor: Lent by H. Faija, Esq.
Date of creation: 1876.
Object entry information: This "motometer," patented by Mr. A. Barlow in 1875, is designed to show on a dial the speed of a revolving shaft, in rev. per min.; it differs from most appliances of the class in that it is a combination of a clock and a counter, and gives a result that has been averaged over a definite interval. The speed is shown by a pointer, carried loosely on a sleeve, which forms part of a clutch and is driven from a clock train at the rate of one turn per min. The clutch is released momentarily by ratchet gearing, driven from the shaft whose speed is to be observed, and so arranged that the clockwork steadily moves the pointer sleeve while the shaft makes 1200 rev. and then releases it, so that the distance thus travelled by the pointer is greater the lower the speed of the shaft. The pointer and sleeves are, by spiral springs, continually tending to fly back to the starting position when released, and the pointer is also fitted with a brake which retains it over its last reading till it is momentarily released, to permit of its moving into the fresh position should the speed have altered during the last interval. In another and more obvious form of the instrument, the shaft drives the clutch and pointer, while the clockwork releases the clutch at intervals of one minute, the pointer being, however, retained at its last reading as above until the end of the fresh minute.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1876–1442 to 1443.

The pointer and sleeves are, by spiral springs, continually tending to fly back to the starting position when released, and the pointer is also fitted with a brake which retains it over its last reading till it is momentarily released, to permit of its moving into the fresh position should the speed have altered during the last interval. In another and more obvious form of the instrument, the shaft drives the clutch and pointer, while the clockwork releases the clutch at intervals of one minute, the pointer being, however, retained at its last reading as above until the end of the fresh minute.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1876–1442 to 1443.
title: Schaeffer and Budenberg Reciprocating Counter
description: Schaeffer and Budenberg Reciprocating Counter

Object name: COMBINED REVOLUTION COUNTER AND STOP WATCH.
Object entry information: This is a hand revolution counter combined with a stop watch, and it is so arranged that counter and watch are started and stopped simultaneously. It was patented by Mr. J. Jaquet in 1893. The four-figure counter is of the Harding type (see Nos. 307 and 307A), and its driving spindle projects from one side of the casing. The motion of the machine is transmitted to the spindle through an extension bar with a triangular pointed outer end, while its inner end is provided with a slot that engages with a pin passing through the spindle. When the counter is at rest this driving pin is covered by a sliding sleeve, held up by a spring, and this sleeve must be depressed by the extension bar before the counter mechanism can operate. The sleeve also works a catch which normally holds the balance wheel of the watch stationary, but releases it when the sleeve is depressed, so that the counter and watch start recording together, and stop together when the pressure on the extension bar is released. The watch reads to one-fifth of a second, and is fitted with the usual zero setter.

Catalogue number: N/A
Object name: N/A
Maker/Donor: N/A
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: The figures are placed on the peripheries of wheels, and the movement of the unit figure wheel is effected, as in Watt's and many other counters, by a reversed escapement; a crankpin engaging with a slotted lever secured to the pallets imparts the necessary reciprocating motion to the latter. A single tooth attached to the axis of the first wheel drives, intermittently, a wheel with ten projecting teeth, and so on throughout the series. Each of the figured wheels is locked during the intervals between the step movements by a projecting rim, on the preceding driving wheel, passing between the overhanging teeth.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1888–257.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 309.
Object name: RECIPROCATING COUNTER.
Maker/Donor: Made by Messrs. Schäffer & Budenberg.
Date of creation: Received 1914.
Object entry information: This is a six-figure counter, actuated by a reciprocating lever, for registering the number of revolutions of an engine. The number dials are placed side by side on parallel spindles, and are numbered on their faces. Beneath each dial, and fixed to its spindle, are two toothed wheels and a finger; one of the wheels has 10 saw-shaped teeth, and the other is similar, but has one tooth cut away. The driving lever is pivoted on the base of the counter, and its shorter arm engages with the 10-tooth wheel on the first spindle and moves it one-tenth of a revolution on each forward stroke. On the completion of one revolution of the units dial, the finger on its spindle engages with the 10-tooth wheel on the second spindle and rotates it one-tenth of a revolution, and so on throughout the series. The dials are held stationary between movements by spring pawls engaging with the 10-toothed wheels. The dials may be set to zero by a sliding bar carrying six hook-shaped springs that engage with the nine-toothed wheels and pull them round until the missing tooth prevents further movement.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1914–286.

title: No.2092 Barlows motometer & watercolour sketch.
description: No.2092 Barlow's patent 'motometer' speed indicator & watercolour sketch.

Maker/Donor: Made by Messrs. Buss, Sombart & Co.
Object entry information: This is an instrument for indicating the speed of a rotating shaft, patented by the makers in 1877. The mechanism consists of a centrifugal governor, connected, by levers and gearing, to a pointer which moves over a graduated dial. The governor is of the special cosine form patented by Mr. E. Buss in 1876; it is placed with its axis horizontal, and its sliding sleeve is controlled by a weighted lever, outside the casing, which gives a load increasing with the displacement. The governor consists of two semi-cylindrical weights, pivoted by their axes at points some distance from the axis of the shaft. Arms on these weights are directly connected with swivelling bolts attached to the casing, and bears upon a guide plate, which is in contact with rollers mounted on the controlling lever. This form of governor possesses the feature that the pressure on the sleeve is dependent only upon the angular velocity of the shaft, and not upon the position of the parts, so that the pointer will always indicate correctly in spite of any wear that may take place; it is also very stable, a large range of speed being covered between its extreme positions. The driving shaft is carried in a long bearing, upon the outside of which the driving pulley runs, so that no belt pressure is transmitted to the axis of the shaft. The dial is mounted on the top of the casing. The axis of the controlling lever carries another lever which is connected, by a vertical rod, with a shorter lever placed upon the axis of a toothed sector behind the dial, and the sector gears with a pinion on the axis of the pointer; by this arrangement the divisions on the dial are made more uniform.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 313.
Object name: SPEED INDICATOR.
Maker/Donor: Lent by Messrs. Elliott Bros., 1888.
Date of creation: 1888.
Object entry information: This form of speed of revolution indicator was patented in 1881 by Mr. D. Young. It consists of a small centrifugal governor, loaded by a helical spring and enclosed in a case. When the spring is compressed owing to the centrifugal tendency of the governor balls, the speed of rotation is indicated in rev. per min. by a finger connected with the spring by levers and toothed gearing, by which it is moved over a suitably graduated dial.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1888–256.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 314.
Object name: HEDGES'S VORTEX SPEED INDICATOR.
Maker/Donor: N/A
Date of creation: Received 1890.
Object entry information: This instrument closely resembles the velocimeter of Mr. J. Ramsbottom, in which a closed glass tube filled with oil is rotated on its vertical axis, and the resulting depression of the oil, varying as the square of the speed, is measured on a graduated scale (see Railway Locomotive Section). Mr. Killingworth Hedges' instrument, patented in 1885, is an improvement, in that the depression of the parabolic cavity is directly proportional to the speed, so that the graduations of the scale are uniform and the range of the instrument is greatly increased. The difference in the size of the tube being less than the proportion of the tube being filled with liquid. When in use the diameter of the parabolic air cavity at the top is less than the diameter of the tube, and varies with the speed in such a manner that the vertex of the paraboloid sinks proportionately with the increase in the speed. A sliding sighting bar is attached to the case to assist in accurately determining the position of the vertex, the reading being taken on the fixed scale.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1890–147.

Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1915–560 & 561.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 312.
Object name: TACHOMETER.
Maker/Donor: Made by Messrs. Buss, Sombart & Co.
Date of creation: Received 1909.
Object entry information: This is an instrument for indicating the speed of a rotating shaft, patented by the makers in 1877. The mechanism consists of a centrifugal governor, connected, by levers and gearing, to a pointer which moves over a graduated dial. The governor is of the special cosine form patented by Mr. E. Buss in 1876; it is placed with its axis horizontal, and its sliding sleeve is controlled by a weighted lever, outside the casing, which gives a load increasing with the displacement. The governor consists of two semi-cylindrical weights, pivoted by their axes at points some distance from the axis of the shaft. Arms on these weights are directly connected with swivelling bolts attached to the casing, and bears upon a guide plate, which is in contact with rollers mounted on the controlling lever. This form of governor possesses the feature that the pressure on the sleeve is dependent only upon the angular velocity of the shaft, and not upon the position of the parts, so that the pointer will always indicate correctly in spite of any wear that may take place; it is also very stable, a large range of speed being covered between its extreme positions. The driving shaft is carried in a long bearing, upon the outside of which the driving pulley runs, so that no belt pressure is transmitted to the axis of the shaft. The dial is mounted on the top of the casing. The axis of the controlling lever carries another lever which is connected, by a vertical rod, with a shorter lever placed upon the axis of a toothed sector behind the dial, and the sector gears with a pinion on the axis of the pointer; by this arrangement the divisions on the dial are made more uniform.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1909–93.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 313.
Object name: SPEED INDICATOR.
Maker/Donor: Lent by Messrs. Elliott Bros., 1888.
Date of creation: 1888.
Object entry information: This form of speed of revolution indicator was patented in 1881 by Mr. D. Young. It consists of a small centrifugal governor, loaded by a helical spring and enclosed in a case. When the spring is compressed owing to the centrifugal tendency of the governor balls, the speed of rotation is indicated in rev. per min. by a finger connected with the spring by levers and toothed gearing, by which it is moved over a suitably graduated dial.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1888–256.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 314.
Object name: HEDGES'S VORTEX SPEED INDICATOR.
Maker/Donor: N/A
Date of creation: Received 1890.
Object entry information: This instrument closely resembles the velocimeter of Mr. J. Ramsbottom, in which a closed glass tube filled with oil is rotated on its vertical axis, and the resulting depression of the oil, varying as the square of the speed, is measured on a graduated scale (see Railway Locomotive Section). Mr. Killingworth Hedges' instrument, patented in 1885, is an improvement, in that the depression of the parabolic cavity is directly proportional to the speed, so that the graduations of the scale are uniform and the range of the instrument is greatly increased. The difference in the size of the tube being less than the proportion of the tube being filled with liquid. When in use the diameter of the parabolic air cavity at the top is less than the diameter of the tube, and varies with the speed in such a manner that the vertex of the paraboloid sinks proportionately with the increase in the speed. A sliding sighting bar is attached to the case to assist in accurately determining the position of the vertex, the reading being taken on the fixed scale.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1890–147.

Catalogue number: 317.
Object name: CROSS PENDULUM TACHOMETER.
Maker/Donor: Presented by Messrs. The Budenberg Gauge Co., Ltd.
Date of creation: 1921.
Object entry information: This instrument indicates directly on a dial, in rev. per min., the speed at which an engine shaft, etc., to which it is connected by a belt drive, is running. The acting mechanism is of the Buss-Sombart governor type, patented in 1877 (see No. 312), and consists of a spring-loaded pendulum having four cylindrical weights mounted on two rectangular frames, and working on pivots, formed on the revolving spindle. The position assumed by the governor weights under centrifugal action is transmitted to the index pointer by means of two connecting links attached to a movable sleeve inside the tachometer spindle. To damp out oscillations of the pointer when subjected to sudden speed fluctuations, the pointer spindle is fitted with a large gear wheel engaging with a shaft carrying a "fly" consisting of a four-armed air vane. The pulley spindle is geared to the tacho-meter spindle in the ratio of 2 : 1, thus obviating inconvenient pulley sizes. The working parts are lubricated by two wick-feed oil-cups. The tachometer is graduated from 600 to 2,400 rev. per min. This example has a glass dial to show the internal parts, and this is supplemented by a sectional illustration.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1921-730.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 318.
Object name: RECORDING GYROMETER AND COUNTER.
Maker/Donor: Lent by Sir W. H. Bailey & Co., Ltd.
Date of creation: 1919.
Object entry information: This is a combined instrument which indicates the speed of a rotating shaft, counts the number of revolutions, and also makes a permanent record of these quantities on a daily chart. The mechanism is contained within a substantial cast-iron casing, through the side of which the driving spindle projects. The gyrometer, or speed indicator, placed in the lower part of the casing, consists of a centrifugal governor of special form which is very sensitive to changes of speed and at the same time steady. The running parts are of hardened steel and the shafts run in ball bearings. The drive is taken from the rotating shaft to the driving spindle by means of a special tape band, and the range of speed is from 200 to 800 rev. per min. The counter is mounted above the gyrometer and an index moving over a large dial counts from 0 to 1,000 rev.; four small dials carry the readings up to ten millions. On top of the casing a projecting vertical spindle carries a drum which is rotated once in 24 hours by clockwork. A chart is wrapped round the drum and its upper part is ruled with horizontal lines corresponding to the speeds on the gyrometer dial, and with vertical lines showing hours and quarter hours. A pen, moving vertically in unison with the gyrometer needle, draws a line on the chart showing the variation of speed with time. On the lower part of the chart is a ruled space, across which a second vertically moving pen is traversed up and down once for every 10,000 rev. recorded by the counter, thus giving a diagram showing the relation between revolutions and time. A glass-fronted cover encloses the recording mechanism.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1919-399, S.M. I,245.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 319.
Object name: WATT'S STEAM ENGINE INDICATOR. Plate VI., No. 3.
Maker/Donor: Lent by E. A. Cowper, Esq.
Date of creation: 1796.
Object entry information: This instrument was introduced by Boulton & Watt in 1796 for the purpose of assisting them in adjusting the valves of a steam engine. In working it there is a diagram of the pressures throughout the stroke of an engine working expansively, but this is clearly the result of calculation. The instrument may have been developed from an apparatus of a pencil to the piston rod and a sheet of paper moved trans-versely to it—features attributed to John Southern, one of Watt's staff—the instrument became a recorder of the pressure existing in the cylinder at every point of the stroke, and gave a diagram from which the work done during the stroke was easily determined.

Catalogue number: 319.
Object name: WATT'S STEAM ENGINE INDICATOR. Plate VI., No. 3.
Maker/Donor: Lent by E. A. Cowper, Esq.
Date of creation: 1796.
Object entry information: This instrument was introduced by Boulton & Watt in 1796 for the purpose of assisting them in adjusting the valves of a steam engine. In working it there is a diagram of the pressures throughout the stroke of an engine working expansively, but this is clearly the result of calculation. The instrument may have been developed from an apparatus of a pencil to the piston rod and a sheet of paper moved trans-versely to it—features attributed to John Southern, one of Watt's staff—the instrument became a recorder of the pressure existing in the cylinder at every point of the stroke, and gave a diagram from which the work done during the stroke was easily determined.
Object/Inventory number: N/A

Object entry information: The instrument was kept secret, and was entrusted only to the staff of the firm; that exhibited belonged to the agent in Manchester, while the diagram was taken in 1840 by Prof. E. Cowper. The indicator is of brass. It has a vertical brass cylinder 1.13 in. diam. (1 sq. in. area), fitted with a piston, the upper extremity of the rod of which is provided with a pencil. The connection with the top of the indicator cylinder by a helical spring, so that any variation in the pressure below the piston will lengthen or shorten this spring, and thus cause the height of the piston to be a measure of the pressure below it. The lower end of the indicator cylinder is placed in communication with one end of the engine cylinder, so as to measure the varying pressure during the stroke. The motion of the paper was usually obtained from a cord on the spindle rod of the parallel motion, the return movement being given either by a string connected with a helical spring or by hand. Owing to the loose connection between the indicator and the cylinder made throughout by tape, paper sockets and plugs, the cylinder lubricators and several of which are also fitted in this way, screwing being adopted later when higher pressures came into use.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 321.
Object name: MCNAUGHT INDICATORS. Received 1897.
Maker/Donor: Messrs. Chadburn Bros. (based on the form introduced by Mr. J. McNaught)
Date of creation: about 1825–30
Object entry information: These three examples of early indicators, made by Messrs. Chadburn Bros., are of the improved form introduced by Mr. J. McNaught about 1825–30, in which by the substitution of a drum in place of the flat board for carrying the paper, serious practical difficulties were avoided. The largest one has a cylinder 0.5 sq. in. area with a travel of 4 in., while the drum is 2.2 in. diam., so that a diagram about 4 in. by 6 in. could be obtained. It has a combined piston and clip attachment for the metallic paper, and the marking point is connected with the piston by an arm having an adjustable spring hinge, to give uniform pressure. The scale of the spring is 10 lb. to 1 in., but the piston rod is extended upwards, so that additional pressure can be applied by means of another spring contained in a removable cap when higher pressures are being used, the combined resistance being 30 lb. to 1 in. There is in the box an independent bracket with a guide pulley, in addition to the pulley on the instrument; the weight complete with case is 12.5 lb. The smallest specimen has a cylinder of 0.25 sq. in. area with a stroke of 2.5 in., while its drum is 1.5 in. diam., is fitted with the now usual spring clip for securing the drum paper. A diagram about 2.5 in. by 6 in. could be obtained, and the spring has a scale of 10 lb. to 1 in., but there is an additional spring in a cap for use on high pressure engines. The other example has a drum 1.9 in. diam. for the paper, arranged outside and concentric with the cylinder. The piston has a travel of 3 in., and the diagram would be about 3 in. by 5 in. The piston rod has a crosshead passing through a guide slot and provided with a spring-hinged arm carrying the marking point and reaching downwards to the drum.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1897-60 to 62. S.M., 1061 to 1063.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 322.
Object name: MCNAUGHT’S INDICATOR. Presented by Professor H. J. Spooner, 1922.
Maker/Donor: Presented by Professor H. J. Spooner. Original maker: Mr. John McNaught.
Date of creation: about 1825
Object entry information: This is an example of the indicator introduced by Mr. John McNaught of Glasgow about 1825 and made by him subsequently to that date (see No. 321). The drum has clips to hold on the paper but in earlier examples cement was used for the purpose. The pencil is on a hinged arm attached to the piston rod and projecting horizontally so as to command the drum. Four springs are provided; corresponding to 5, 10, 15 and 30 lb. per in. The cylinder is 0.25 sq. in. area with a travel of 3.5 in. while the drum is 1.5 in. diam. so that a diagram about 2 in. by 4.5 in. could be obtained.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1922-488.

Catalogue number: 321.
Object name: MCNAUGHT INDICATORS. Received 1897.
Maker/Donor: Messrs. Chadburn Bros. (based on the form introduced by Mr. J. McNaught)
Date of creation: about 1825–30
Object entry information: These three examples of early indicators, made by Messrs. Chadburn Bros., are of the improved form introduced by Mr. J. McNaught about 1825–30, in which by the substitution of a drum in place of the flat board for carrying the paper, serious practical difficulties were avoided. The largest one has a cylinder 0.5 sq. in. area with a travel of 4 in., while the drum is 2.2 in. diam., so that a diagram about 4 in. by 6 in. could be obtained. It has a combined piston and clip attachment for the metallic paper, and the marking point is connected with the piston by an arm having an adjustable spring hinge, to give uniform pressure. The scale of the spring is 10 lb. to 1 in., but the piston rod is extended upwards, so that additional pressure can be applied by means of another spring contained in a removable cap when higher pressures are being used, the combined resistance being 30 lb. to 1 in. There is in the box an independent bracket with a guide pulley, in addition to the pulley on the instrument; the weight complete with case is 12.5 lb. The smallest specimen has a cylinder of 0.25 sq. in. area with a stroke of 2.5 in., while its drum is 1.5 in. diam., is fitted with the now usual spring clip for securing the drum paper. A diagram about 2.5 in. by 6 in. could be obtained, and the spring has a scale of 10 lb. to 1 in., but there is an additional spring in a cap for use on high pressure engines. The other example has a drum 1.9 in. diam. for the paper, arranged outside and concentric with the cylinder. The piston has a travel of 3 in., and the diagram would be about 3 in. by 5 in. The piston rod has a crosshead passing through a guide slot and provided with a spring-hinged arm carrying the marking point and reaching downwards to the drum.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1897-60 to 62. S.M., 1061 to 1063.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 322.
Object name: MCNAUGHT’S INDICATOR. Presented by Professor H. J. Spooner, 1922.
Maker/Donor: Presented by Professor H. J. Spooner. Original maker: Mr. John McNaught.
Date of creation: about 1825
Object entry information: This is an example of the indicator introduced by Mr. John McNaught of Glasgow about 1825 and made by him subsequently to that date (see No. 321). The drum has clips to hold on the paper but in earlier examples cement was used for the purpose. The pencil is on a hinged arm attached to the piston rod and projecting horizontally so as to command the drum. Four springs are provided; corresponding to 5, 10, 15 and 30 lb. per in. The cylinder is 0.25 sq. in. area with a travel of 3.5 in. while the drum is 1.5 in. diam. so that a diagram about 2 in. by 4.5 in. could be obtained.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1922-488.

title: McNaught's Steam Engine Indicator.
description: McNaught's Steam Engine Indicator.

Maker/Donor: Presented by A. G. Scholes, Esq.
Object entry information: This is a modification of the McNaught indicator (see No. 321) made and used by Mr. G. Scholes for many years while in the employ of James Watt & Co. The improvements in detail due to Mr. Scholes consist in fitting two light steel rods working on short links which hold the pencil out of contact with the card " until the desired moment; and in addition, a helical spring on the pencil holder to give a predetermined pressure. There are two springs corresponding to 12 lb. and 20 lb. per in. respectively; the scale is graduated to suit 12 lb. on one side and 20 lb. on the other. The cylinder is of gunmetal; it has an area of 0.5 sq. in. with a travel of 3.5 in. The drum is 2 in. diam., and a diagram of about 3 in. by 5 in. can be obtained.
