The valve is intended for maintaining a reduced pressure of from 5 lb. to 50 lb. with initial pressures up to 300 lb. per sq. in., but the initial pressure must be from 10 to 15 lb. higher than the reduced pressure.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1910-64, S.M. 667.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 398.
Object name: REDUCING VALVE.
Maker/Donor: Presented by Messrs. W. H. Bailey & Co., 1903.
Date of creation: 1903
Object entry information: The arrangement of this appliance, for automatically reducing the pressure of steam or other fluid to some lower but constant pressure, was patented in 1896 by Mr. J. M. Foster. The valve itself is of the double-beat equilibrium type, but, to overcome the difficulties arising from the variation in temperature of the stem connecting the two discs, the face of the upper one is nearly flat, while the lower one has a very acute chamfer. Above the valve box, but cast with it, is a circular dish separated by a flexible metallic diaphragm from a similar dish above it which is open to the atmosphere, while the spindle of the valve extends upward and is attached to a cap in the centre of this diaphragm. Above the top dish are two horizontal tie-rods, connected by crossheads, which control two helical springs under compression, and these, by short vertical levers, press upon a pair of toggle plates, which thereby exert a downward thrust upon the diaphragm and valve spindle. The boiler steam enters the space between the two valves, and rushes to the reduced pressure pipe beyond; some, however, passes through a vertical communicating orifice to the under side of the diaphragm, which is thereby thrust upward and carrying the valve with it reduces the supply of steam, and consequently lowers the pressure below the diaphragm. In this way the valve finds and maintains a position in which the pressure of the reduced steam on the diaphragm balances the effort exerted by the external helical springs. By the introduction of the toggle plates the rise in the reduced pressure, which would result from the increased compression of the springs when the valve is fully opened, is prevented by the alteration that at the same time takes place in the angle of the toggle joint.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1903-48, 29,807.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 399.
Object name: FUSIBLE PLUGS.
Maker/Donor: Lent by Messrs. Allan, Harrison & Co., 1862.
Date of creation: 1862
Object entry information: Fusible plugs have long been used as an additional safety appliance to steam boilers. This example is in the form of a valve, cottered down. The seating of the valve carries the plug well above the furnace crown, and the valve or cap is drilled with a number of holes, each of which is plugged with a fusible alloy. The cotter permits the valve to be easily replaced when necessary, the plug, however, being inserted from the water side.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1862-13.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 400.
Object name: COPPER CAP FUSIBLE PLUGS.
Maker/Donor: Lent by Messrs. W. H. Bailey & Co., 1888.
Date of creation: 1888
Object entry information: This plug consists of a socket screwed for fixing to the furnace crown and provided above with a nut. It was patented in 1885 by Sir W. H. Bailey. Fusible metal, in the form of a thick disc, covered above with a thin copper cap, is secured to the socket by the nut as shown in the adjacent drawing. The copper cap is intended to protect the fusible alloy from any chemical action of the water and to insure a sudden and complete release of the plug. A sectional drawing to elucidate the construction is shown.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1888-274 to 275. Inv. 1888-276.

Object entry information: The main valve is a single mushroom valve, with a flat face, held on its seat by a helical spring, and lifted by a differential piston placed below it. The upper side of the piston is in communication with the reduced steam, while the lower side is open to the high-pressure steam through a passage which is controlled by the regulator valve. The regulator is placed above the main valve, and its stem is held by a spring in contact with the diaphragm, upon the under side of which the reduced pressure acts. The upper side of the diaphragm is acted upon by a helical spring, the pressure of which can be adjusted to give the desired reduction. When steam is admitted, it passes through the regulator to the lower piston, which raises the valve high enough to give the required pressure at the outlet. title: Framed Sectional Drawing
description: Framed Sectional Drawing, full size, of Bailey's Copper Cap Fusible Plug No.46186

Maker/Donor: Lent by the National Boiler and General Insurance Co.
Object entry information: In this construction, patented in 1888 by Mr. H. Hiller, the fusible alloy is used to secure a core into a readily removable plug screwed into a gunmetal seating, which is screwed into the furnace crown. The plug is provided with a bevelled edge similar to that of a valve, so as to ensure a tight joint, and the core carries a flange, which protects the fusible metal from the direct action of the fire, and prevents its gradual escape. The exterior of the core and the interior of the plug are grooved so that the core is retained in position against the pressure of the steam by the shearing resistance of the fusible alloy. A complete plug, fixed in a portion of a furnace crown, together with one in section, are shown; these are renewable from the water side. A similar plug is made renewable from the furnace side. The section shows the modification necessary when the plug is made renewable from the furnace side.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 402.
Object name: FUSIBLE PLUG.
Maker/Donor: Presented by the Vulcan Boiler and General Insurance Co., Ltd.
Date of creation: 1906.
Object entry information: This safety device for the furnaces of internally fired boilers was patented in 1904 by Mr. C. Bullock, and is of the pattern approved by the Vulcan Co. It consists of a serrated copper cone embedded in an annulus of fusible alloy screwed into the body of the plug. This alloy is protected from non-conducting incrustation, etc., by a cavity therein; this serves also as a conductor of heat. When the alloy is melted the cone is not blown out, but after dropping a short distance, it is stopped by internal ribs, thus leaving a passage for steam. The size shown is the largest made and is suitable for Lancashire and large Cornish boilers; it is inserted from the water side of the furnace. A pattern for locomotive boilers, inserted from the fire side, is also made.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1906–30.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 403.
Object name: WATER GAUGE AND SECTIONAL DRAWING.
Maker/Donor: Lent by Messrs. Llewellyns and James.
Date of creation: 1888.
Object entry information: This gauge, for showing the level of water in a steam boiler by means of a glass tube, is of the form patented by Messrs. J. L. Llewellyn, J. L. Nelson and A. F. Landerhohn in 1885. Instead of the ordinary cocks, it is fitted with valves which automatically close and prevent the escape of steam and water in case of a glass tube breaking. The gauge consists of two fittings attached to the boiler front and having the glass tube held between them in stuffing-boxes. Each fitting has an internal cylindrical chamber in line with the tube, and in each of these is placed a valve which, when seated, closes the passage leading to the tube. The valve has a long spindle passing out of the chamber through a stuffing-box and provided with a handle; the spindle carries a piston not quite as large as the chamber, so that steam and water can pass round it, but should the tube break, the rush of fluid will act upon the piston and close the valve. A collar on the valve spindle serves as a valve to keep the valve spindle steamtight when the valve is open, as is the case when the glass tube is intact. The steam pressure holds the valve to its seat. An overflow valve is fitted to the lower chamber. A sectional drawing shows the construction.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1888–272 and 273.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 404.
Object name: WATER GAUGE. Plate IX., No. 3.
Maker/Donor: Lent by Messrs. Dewrance & Co.
Date of creation: 1910.
Object entry information: This is a water gauge embodying several improvements in detail, patented by Messrs. J. Dewrance and G. H. Wall between 1888 and 1904. The gauge glass is held at each end by a special form of asbestos and rubber packing, held in loose glands which are enclosed and tightened up by screwed covers. The glands are prevented from rotating so that the asbestos being caulked by which communication is established with the steam and water spaces and overflow, are asbestos-packed (see No. 399), the asbestos being caulked into grooves surrounding the passages; they are so formed that it is impossible for the steam to blow them out. The stems are drawn off when the latter are un-screwed. The three plug cocks, for the steam to blow them out. The stems are drawn off when the latter are un-screwed and pass through stuffing-boxes; nuts on the ends draw them tight against the packing.
Object/Inventory number: N/A

title: Nelson Landerhohns patent 1885 self closing boiler water gauge
description: Nelson Landerhohns patent 1885 self closing boiler water gauge, No.61 on mahogany stand 272

Object entry information: Automatic valves are provided to prevent the escape of steam and water in case of a tube breaking. The one at the lower end is a simple ball valve which normally leaves a clear passage, but which would be forced up against its seat by a sudden rush of water. The ball can be easily removed through the front plug hole. The upper valve consists of a conical valve, held on its seat by the steam pressure; and having a passage through it leading to an orifice in the side of a cylindrical stem. A bent spring has one end opposite the orifice and is of sufficient strength to resist ordinary blowing through, but if the glass tube breaks the steam pressure would overcome the spring and force it over so as to close the orifice. The valve is lifted out through the top plug hole when cleaning out the upper passage. A protecting screen of plate glass 0.5 in. thick is placed round the tube in order to minimise the danger resulting from a burst.

Catalogue number: 405.
Object name: REFLEX WATER GAUGE.
Maker/Donor: Lent by Messrs. S. Dixon & Son, Ltd.
Date of creation: 1920.
Object entry information: The chief feature of this boiler gauge, which takes the place of the ordinary gauge glass, is that it has a device to render the water level easily visible. The gauge is a brass frame with a glazed front while at the back is a glass ground with five vertical flutes forming prisms, as patented in 1890 by Mr. R. Klinger. The property of this is that light passing through the space filled with steam is reflected and appears silvery white, while that passing through the water is absorbed and appears black. The gauge is made in a number of sizes and for different pressures; that shown is size 7 for pressures up to 150 lb.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1920–105, S.M. 1,320.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 406.
Object name: BOILER GAUGE FITTINGS.
Maker/Donor: Lent by Messrs. S. Dixon & Son, Ltd.
Date of creation: 1920.
Object entry information: This is a boiler gauge glass protector combined with a water level reflector of registered design known as the "Simplex." The protector consists of three strips of plate glass 0.4 in. thick, held in grooves in two brass plates to form a box which can be readily slipped on to the gauge glass. The upper plate has a hole to fit round the stuffing-box nut, while the lower plate is recessed to rest on the corresponding nut below. The reflector is a slightly convex plate on which are enamelled alternate white and black bars inclined at an angle of about 20° to the horizontal; this slips into grooves behind the gauge glass. Seen through the steam space the bars appear to be distorted helically, while seen through the water space the bars appear to reverse hand; thus the water level is quite apparent even in dark surroundings. The protector meets the requirements of the Factory and Workshop Act, 1901, one clause of which requires the provision of protection for the gauge glass of boilers to guard against accident in case of breakage of the gauge glass. The protector is made in lengths from 8 in. to 20 in. in the clear; the size shown is 11 in.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1920–104, S.M. 1,321.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 407.
Object name: GAUGE GLASS ILLUMINATOR.
Maker/Donor: Presented by Messrs. Ronald Trist & Co., Ltd.
Date of creation: 1924.
Object entry information: This attachment for a boiler water gauge is used to overcome the difficulty frequently experienced in a bad light of reading the level of the water, and is a modification of the familiar gauge glass with the red stripe painted on the back, the object being to use the glass, where it is filled with water, as a lens. It consists of an ordinary incandescent electric lamp mounted on a double-jointed arm furnished with a wing nut, and secured to an adaptable bracket. The lamp has a metal cover with a slot in the side and a hole in the top. A flat strip of metal or screen, painted red, is clipped on to the gauge glass, and the lamp and screen are so adjusted that the light is focussed by the glass over the length filled by water, but does not appreciably illuminate the screen above that level. The height of the water is clearly represented by a bright strip of light on the screen. The fitting can be applied to existing boiler gauges as shown.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1924–322.

title: Dewrance and Wall's patent
description: Dewrance and Wall's patent, 1888-1904, automatic protected boiler water gauge, Catalogue No.44, on mahogany stand

Maker/Donor: Lent by Messrs. S. Dixon & Son, Ltd.
Object entry information: The chief feature of this boiler gauge, which takes the place of the ordinary gauge glass, is that it has a device to render the water level easily visible. The gauge is a brass frame with a glazed front while at the back is a glass ground with five vertical flutes forming prisms, as patented in 1890 by Mr. R. Klinger. The property of this is that light passing through the space filled with steam is reflected and appears silvery white, while that passing through the water is absorbed and appears black. The gauge is made in a number of sizes and for different pressures; that shown is size 7 for pressures up to 150 lb.

Maker/Donor: N/A
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: Automatic valves are provided to prevent the escape of steam and water in case of a tube breaking. The one at the lower end is a simple ball valve which normally leaves a clear passage, but which would be forced up against its seat by a sudden rush of water. The ball can be easily removed through the front plug hole. The upper valve consists of a conical valve, held on its seat by the steam pressure; and having a passage through it leading to an orifice in the side of a cylindrical stem. A bent spring has one end opposite the orifice and is of sufficient strength to resist ordinary blowing through, but if the glass tube breaks the steam pressure would overcome the spring and force it over so as to close the orifice. The valve is lifted out through the top plug hole when cleaning out the upper passage. A protecting screen of plate glass 0.5 in. thick is placed round the tube in order to minimise the danger resulting from a burst.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1910–56, 19,267.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 406.
Object name: BOILER GAUGE FITTINGS.
Maker/Donor: Lent by Messrs. S. Dixon & Son, Ltd.
Date of creation: 1920.
Object entry information: This is a boiler gauge glass protector combined with a water level reflector of registered design known as the "Simplex." The protector consists of three strips of plate glass 0.4 in. thick, held in grooves in two brass plates to form a box which can be readily slipped on to the gauge glass. The upper plate has a hole to fit round the stuffing-box nut, while the lower plate is recessed to rest on the corresponding nut below. The reflector is a slightly convex plate on which are enamelled alternate white and black bars inclined at an angle of about 20° to the horizontal; this slips into grooves behind the gauge glass. Seen through the steam space the bars appear to be distorted helically, while seen through the water space the bars appear to reverse hand; thus the water level is quite apparent even in dark surroundings. The protector meets the requirements of the Factory and Workshop Act, 1901, one clause of which requires the provision of protection for the gauge glass of boilers to guard against accident in case of breakage of the gauge glass. The protector is made in lengths from 8 in. to 20 in. in the clear; the size shown is 11 in.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1920–104, S.M. 1,321.

title: "Screenlight" Gauge Glass Illuminator
description: "Screenlight" Gauge Glass Illuminator, patents pending, fitting on Dewrance Boiler Water Gauge

Object entry information: A rocking beam with segmental ends is connected by a pitch chain at one end with the piston rod of a vertical brass cylinder 1.95 in. diam. (i.e., 3 sq. in. area), and at the other end with a helical spring. Connection between the condenser or other vessel, in which the degree of vacuum is to be measured, and the under side of the piston is made by means of a pipe. When a cock in the pipe is opened, the pressure of the atmosphere forces down the piston against the pull of the spring. The vacuum is indicated by a pointer fixed to the beam at its axis. This pointer is long compared with the beam and gives open readings on a scale which is graduated in inches of mercury.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 409.
Object name: PRESSURE GAUGE.
Maker/Donor: Messrs. Watney, Combe, Reid & Co.
Date of creation: 1899.
Object entry information: This steam gauge was attached to the cylinder jacket of a rotative beam engine supplied by Messrs. Boulton, Watt & Co., in 1808, to Messrs. Reid's brewery, Clerkenwell, where the boiler pressure was 5 lb. above atmosphere. This gauge represents the arrangement in general use till about 1850, when the continual increase in pressure led to the adoption of dial gauges. The apparatus consists of an inverted siphon pipe of wrought iron, one extremity of which was provided with a flange for attachment to the cylinder jacket or to the steam pipe, while the other was fitted with a socket which supported a glass tube that protected a light rod terminating in a cork disc. The siphon was half filled with mercury, so that when the steam pressure increased it caused the mercury to rise in the outer leg and so lift the rod within the glass tube, thus indicating the pressure, usually upon a scale placed behind the tube. The tube was closed at the top, but was so fitted as not to seal the end of the siphon.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1899–98, S.M. 1,055.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 410.
Object name: VACUUM GAUGE.
Maker/Donor: Messrs. Watney, Combe, Reid & Co.
Date of creation: 1899.
Object entry information: This gauge, for indicating the degree of exhaustion of the condenser, was fitted to the same engine as the pressure gauge No. 409. Connection with the condenser being made by a considerable length of copper pipe. From this pipe a wrought-iron extension piece, 0.375 in. external diameter, passed up through a small reservoir to the top of the closed end of a vertical barometer tube. The reservoir was open to the atmosphere, and was filled with mercury, so that the pressure within the condenser fell the mercury was forced up the barometer tube by the atmospheric pressure. The whole instrument is constructed within an iron casting mounted on wood; near the upper end of the exposed portion of the tube is a graduated scale for reading the difference between the pressure of the atmosphere and that within the condenser; this is given in inches of mercury, the graduations being so reduced that the reservoir correction is allowed for.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1899–99, S.M. 1,056.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 411.
Object name: DIAPHRAGM PRESSURE GAUGE.
Maker/Donor: P. A. Newton, Esq.
Date of creation: 1918.
Object entry information: This is a gauge in which the pressure is measured by the deflection of a flat diaphragm, the deflection being magnified, and the pressure indicated by a column of fluid in a glass tube leading from the diaphragm chamber. It was patented by Mr. J. Webster in 1853. The instrument consists of a cast-iron chamber 3 in. diam., made in two parts, bolted together with a thin steel plate between them. Steam or other fluid is admitted to the lower part of the chamber, below the diaphragm, while the upper part communicates with a glass tube 0.2 in. diam. mounted in a brass casing, on the face of which the pressure scale is engraved. The fluid contained in the upper chamber is partly expelled when the other suitable fluid, contained in the upper chamber is partly expelled when the pressure deflects the diaphragm and rises in the tube, the motion being magnified in the ratio of the diameter of the chamber and tube. The instrument must be calibrated from a standard gauge, when using the same fluid as that for which it is to be used, as allowance has to be made for the expansion of the measuring fluid when using the gauge for steam pressures. The scale covers a range from o to 200 lb. per sq. in., and the space between the scale divisions diminishes as the pressure increases.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1918–221, S.M. 1242.

Object name: PRESSURE GAUGE.
Maker/Donor: Messrs. Watney, Combe, Reid & Co.
Date of creation: 1899.
Object entry information: This steam gauge was attached to the cylinder jacket of a rotative beam engine supplied by Messrs. Boulton, Watt & Co., in 1808, to Messrs. Reid's brewery, Clerkenwell, where the boiler pressure was 5 lb. above atmosphere. This gauge represents the arrangement in general use till about 1850, when the continual increase in pressure led to the adoption of dial gauges. The apparatus consists of an inverted siphon pipe of wrought iron, one extremity of which was provided with a flange for attachment to the cylinder jacket or to the steam pipe, while the other was fitted with a socket which supported a glass tube that protected a light rod terminating in a cork disc. The siphon was half filled with mercury, so that when the steam pressure increased it caused the mercury to rise in the outer leg and so lift the rod within the glass tube, thus indicating the pressure, usually upon a scale placed behind the tube. The tube was closed at the top, but was so fitted as not to seal the end of the siphon.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1899–98, S.M. 1,055.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 410.
Object name: VACUUM GAUGE.
Maker/Donor: Messrs. Watney, Combe, Reid & Co.
Date of creation: 1899.
Object entry information: This gauge, for indicating the degree of exhaustion of the condenser, was fitted to the same engine as the pressure gauge No. 409. Connection with the condenser being made by a considerable length of copper pipe. From this pipe a wrought-iron extension piece, 0.375 in. external diameter, passed up through a small reservoir to the top of the closed end of a vertical barometer tube. The reservoir was open to the atmosphere, and was filled with mercury, so that the pressure within the condenser fell the mercury was forced up the barometer tube by the atmospheric pressure. The whole instrument is constructed within an iron casting mounted on wood; near the upper end of the exposed portion of the tube is a graduated scale for reading the difference between the pressure of the atmosphere and that within the condenser; this is given in inches of mercury, the graduations being so reduced that the reservoir correction is allowed for.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1899–99, S.M. 1,056.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 411.
Object name: DIAPHRAGM PRESSURE GAUGE.
Maker/Donor: P. A. Newton, Esq.
Date of creation: 1918.
Object entry information: This is a gauge in which the pressure is measured by the deflection of a flat diaphragm, the deflection being magnified, and the pressure indicated by a column of fluid in a glass tube leading from the diaphragm chamber. It was patented by Mr. J. Webster in 1853. The instrument consists of a cast-iron chamber 3 in. diam., made in two parts, bolted together with a thin steel plate between them. Steam or other fluid is admitted to the lower part of the chamber, below the diaphragm, while the upper part communicates with a glass tube 0.2 in. diam. mounted in a brass casing, on the face of which the pressure scale is engraved. The fluid contained in the upper chamber is partly expelled when the other suitable fluid, contained in the upper chamber is partly expelled when the pressure deflects the diaphragm and rises in the tube, the motion being magnified in the ratio of the diameter of the chamber and tube. The instrument must be calibrated from a standard gauge, when using the same fluid as that for which it is to be used, as allowance has to be made for the expansion of the measuring fluid when using the gauge for steam pressures. The scale covers a range from o to 200 lb. per sq. in., and the space between the scale divisions diminishes as the pressure increases.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1918–221, S.M. 1242.

Object entry information: A rocking beam with segmental ends is connected by a pitch chain at one end with the piston rod of a vertical brass cylinder 1.95 in. diam. (i.e., 3 sq. in. area), and at the other end with a helical spring. Connection between the condenser or other vessel, in which the degree of vacuum is to be measured, and the under side of the piston is made by means of a pipe. When a cock in the pipe is opened, the pressure of the atmosphere forces down the piston against the pull of the spring. The vacuum is indicated by a pointer fixed to the beam at its axis. This pointer is long compared with the beam and gives open readings on a scale which is graduated in inches of mercury.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1876–1260, 19,636 and S.M. 833.

Maker/Donor: Messrs. Mather & Platt, 1889.
Object entry information: This is a portion of a mercurial gauge patented in 1856 by Messrs. C. Mather and C. Millward. The range of the scale is only 4 in. in length, but the range is up to 100 lb. pressure. That this is due to the use of a long mercurial stand-pipe of much smaller diameter than that of the glass tube. Steam admitted to the top tube forces the mercury up, and then through the fine vertical stand-pipe that enters the tube at the bottom, overflows were introduced by which the gauge could be placed in communication with the condenser when required.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 413
Object name: PRESSURE GAUGE.
Maker/Donor: Messrs. Smith Bros. and Co., 1902.
Date of creation: 1902
Object entry information: As boiler pressures increased, the mercury gauge originally used became very inconvenient, owing to the height of the column required; hence locomotive drivers were unprovided with any means of telling the steam pressure; in a few instances a form of thermometric gauge was adopted, but the usual practice was to rely upon the indications derived from the spring-loaded safety valve. Mr. Sydney Smith, of Nottingham, was one of the earliest to produce a convenient form of mechanical pressure gauge, and this he patented in 1847, while in the same year he submitted it to George Stephenson, who at once had it tried on one of the boilers at his Tapton colliery. The gauge consisted of a diaphragm of vulcanised india-rubber held at its circumference between flanges which connected the two halves of a spherical chamber. The lower half of the chamber was in communication with the boiler, and the upper half supported a rod, so connecting it with the centre of the diaphragm that it indicated in a greatly magnified manner the amount of bulging which the pressure was occasioning. In 1854 Mr. Smith patented an improved form of this gauge, and the example shown, which was made about 1860 and was in use for 40 years, is of this later type. The diaphragm is still of vulcanised rubber, but it is loaded or reinforced by a close volute spring wound with such a camber that at the working pressure it is approximately flat. To the centre of the spring is secured a vertically guided rack gearing into a pinion on the index spindle, as shown in the attached sectional drawing.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1902-141 & 189.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 414
Object name: PRESSURE GAUGES.
Maker/Donor: Messrs. J. Dewrance and Co., 1862.
Date of creation: 1862
Object entry information: The form of pressure gauge shown was introduced in 1849 by Mons. E. Bourdon, who discovered the action upon which it relies while attempting to remove, by the application of internal pressure, the flattening caused in a pipe by bending it into a coil. When a fluid pressure was applied the pipe slightly straightened, and by fitting the free end with a pointer, found that reliable readings of the pressure were thus obtainable. This action depends on the fact that the product of the curvatures of a surface in planes at right angles is constant, so that if one radius of curvature is diminished, as by the elliptical section becoming more nearly circular, the other radius increases. The gauge consists of a thin curved tube of elliptical section, with one end fixed in a block to which the admission pipe is attached, while the other end is free; this end is closed and connected by multiplying gear with the index. In one of the forms shown, a link from the end of the tube is connected with a short extension of the index finger, which is pivoted near the edge of the dial. In the other the link is connected with a pivoted lever having a toothed sector that gears with a pinion on the axis of the index, which is mounted centrally so that the scale may extend round the whole circumference of the dial.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1862-110.

Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1887-112.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 418.
Object name: STEAM PRESSURE GAUGE.
Maker/Donor: Presented by Messrs. The Budenberg Gauge Co., Ltd.
Date of creation: 1921.
Object entry information: This is a modern steam pressure gauge of the Bourdon type. The Bourdon tube is of bronze, of elliptical cross-section bent into a circular shape, and the movement of the free end is communicated to the pointer as usual by toothed quadrant and pinion. The whole of the working parts of the gauge are, for greater accuracy, built up on the central boss and are independent of the case. The gauge is suitable for pressures up to 300 lb. per sq. in.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1921-725.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 419.
Object name: STEAM PRESSURE GAUGE.
Maker/Donor: Presented by Messrs. The Budenberg Gauge Co., Ltd.
Date of creation: 1921.
Object entry information: This is a modern gauge of the diaphragm type. The diaphragm is of thin steel held between flanges and is corrugated to increase its sensitiveness. The upward movement of the diaphragm due to the steam pressure is transmitted to the index spindle by means of a connecting link attached to a toothed segment gearing with the central pinion, an extension of which carries the pointer on the dial. A copper hair-spring, attached to the pinion at one end and to the frame at the other, serves to take up backlash between the teeth of the quadrant and pinion. The gauge is graduated for pressures up to 200 lb. per sq. in.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1921-724.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 420.
Object name: PRESSURE AND VACUUM GAUGE.
Maker/Donor: Presented by Messrs. The Budenberg Gauge Co., Ltd.
Date of creation: 1921.
Object entry information: This is a compound gauge on the Bourdon principle (see No. 414) for indicating both pressure and vacuum. When steam under pressure is admitted to the Bourdon tube it tends to uncoil, the free end moving outwards or away from the boss; if, however, the pressure of the steam is below the atmosphere, the free end of the tube moves inwards. The tube is connected to the pointer by the usual toothed quadrant and pinion. A hard copper hair-spring is provided to eliminate backlash. The gauge is graduated from atmospheric pressure in lb. per sq. in., and below atmosphere in inches of mercury to 30 in. vacuum.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1921-726.

Catalogue number: 421.
Object name: PRESSURE GAUGE WITH STEEL BOURDON TUBE.
Maker/Donor: Presented by Messrs. The Budenberg Gauge Co., Ltd.
Date of creation: 1921.
Object entry information: This is the Bourdon type, and as it is intended for high pressures steel is used for the tube. It reads to 1,500 lb. per sq. in.

Catalogue number: 417.
Object name: PRESSURE GAUGE.
Maker/Donor: Lent by Messrs. G. Salter & Co.
Date of creation: 1887.
Object entry information: This modification of the Bourdon gauge was patented by Mr. G. Salter in 1879. The free end of the flattened pressure tube is provided with a pin, which fits in a radial slot very near to the centre of the index, so that the slight movement of this pin is directly magnified by the long index arm.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1887-112.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 418.
Object name: STEAM PRESSURE GAUGE.
Maker/Donor: Presented by Messrs. The Budenberg Gauge Co., Ltd.
Date of creation: 1921.
Object entry information: This is a modern steam pressure gauge of the Bourdon type. The Bourdon tube is of bronze, of elliptical cross-section bent into a circular shape, and the movement of the free end is communicated to the pointer as usual by toothed quadrant and pinion. The whole of the working parts of the gauge are, for greater accuracy, built up on the central boss and are independent of the case. The gauge is suitable for pressures up to 300 lb. per sq. in.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1921-725.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 419.
Object name: STEAM PRESSURE GAUGE.
Maker/Donor: Presented by Messrs. The Budenberg Gauge Co., Ltd.
Date of creation: 1921.
Object entry information: This is a modern gauge of the diaphragm type. The diaphragm is of thin steel held between flanges and is corrugated to increase its sensitiveness. The upward movement of the diaphragm due to the steam pressure is transmitted to the index spindle by means of a connecting link attached to a toothed segment gearing with the central pinion, an extension of which carries the pointer on the dial. A copper hair-spring, attached to the pinion at one end and to the frame at the other, serves to take up backlash between the teeth of the quadrant and pinion. The gauge is graduated for pressures up to 200 lb. per sq. in.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1921-724.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 420.
Object name: PRESSURE AND VACUUM GAUGE.
Maker/Donor: Presented by Messrs. The Budenberg Gauge Co., Ltd.
Date of creation: 1921.
Object entry information: This is a compound gauge on the Bourdon principle (see No. 414) for indicating both pressure and vacuum. When steam under pressure is admitted to the Bourdon tube it tends to uncoil, the free end moving outwards or away from the boss; if, however, the pressure of the steam is below the atmosphere, the free end of the tube moves inwards. The tube is connected to the pointer by the usual toothed quadrant and pinion. A hard copper hair-spring is provided to eliminate backlash. The gauge is graduated from atmospheric pressure in lb. per sq. in., and below atmosphere in inches of mercury to 30 in. vacuum.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1921-726.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 421.
Object name: PRESSURE GAUGE WITH STEEL BOURDON TUBE.

Date of creation: 1921.
Object entry information: This is the Bourdon type, and as it is intended for high pressures steel is used for the tube. It reads to 1,500 lb. per sq. in.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1921-727.

description: 6" Steel-tube Pressure Gauge, graduated to 1500 lbs. per sq. in., with glass dial showing interior, no.5695831

Maker/Donor: Presented by Messrs. The Budenberg Gauge Co., Ltd.
Object entry information: This gauge is for use in testing minute variations in air or gas pressure. It is constructed on the principle of the aneroid barometer, and consists of two corrugated diaphragms soldered together at the edges. The back diaphragm is fixed at its centre to the frame of the mechanism, whereas the front diaphragm is free to move, the capsule expanding or contracting in response to pressure variations. The index pointer is operated by means of a vertical shaft, mounted between centres, which carries two small levers, one of which engages with the centre of the moving diaphragm, while the lower lever enters a slot in the arm of the toothed quadrant, the latter moving the pinion and spindle to which the pointer is attached. The instrument is furnished with an extended scale, graduated up to 1 in. water column, with subdivisions in hundredths of an inch.

Object entry information: This gauge is for use in testing minute variations in air or gas pressure. Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 423.
Object name: BOURDON GAUGE TUBES.
Maker/Donor: Lent by Messrs. Schäffer and Budenberg.
Date of creation: 1894.
Object entry information: These specimens illustrate the method of manufacture of two types of Bourdon tube; one is the ordinary tube for steam gauges, and the other the tube of hydraulic gauges for very high pressure. For the steam gauge the tube is made from sheet metal with a brazed joint along what will be the inside edge of the coil. When making the joint the tube is somewhat circular, but is afterwards flattened to an elliptical section of about 0.625 in. by 0.187 in., which is then bent to the coil form. The hydraulic gauge is made from a short length of octagonal steel bar, bored up the centre, afterwards screwed at the ends, and greatly reduced externally so as to obtain sufficiently thin walls, while retaining the strength at the screwed extremities. The tube is then heated and bent to the form shown.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1894-152.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 424.
Object name: STEAM GAUGE TESTER.
Maker/Donor: Made by Messrs. W. McNaught & Son. Received 1913.
Date of creation: 1913.
Object entry information: This is an instrument for boiler inspectors, etc., for use in checking the indications of ordinary dial gauges. In construction it resembles the McNaught engine indicator (see No. 321). There is a cock for screwing to the steam pipe, and to this is screwed a wood lagged cylinder with a piston 0.25 sq. in. area. External to the cylinder and attached to the piston rod is a helical spring in tension. The point of attachment of the spring which moves over a scale of 1 lb. with adjustment for zero point. An extension of the piston rod has a hook for attaching weights for directly checking the accuracy of the spring (1 lb. weight equals 4 lb. pressure).
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1913-88.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 425.
Object name: INTERMITTENT PRESSURE RECORDER.
Maker/Donor: Designed and made by Mr. A. Rigg in 1859. Received 1907.
Date of creation: 1859.
Object entry information: This instrument was designed and made by Mr. A. Rigg in 1859. Its object was to record the pressure, once in every thousand revolutions, of a beam engine driving millstones for grinding white lead. The instrument is connected with the engine by the shaft projecting from the front of the box, which drove a ratchet inside, operating three discs acting as cams. The cams revolved at different speeds, and when the notches cut in them coincided, a small lever, held in contact with the cams by a spring, fell into the depression and opened a valve, putting the indicator (the McNaught indicator (see No. 321)), into communication with the engine cylinder; the steam pipe for this connection is shown at the back of the box. The variations in pressure were thus admitted, then recorded, on an endless paper band, the variations in pressure for one complete revolution of the engine. The travel of the paper band round the drum was about 0.25 in. for every thousand revolutions of the engine, and as the engine made 18 rev. per min., the intervals of recording pressure were about 55 min. A portion of a record taken with this instrument in 1859-60 is shown. The recorder was also used for testing the continuity of a water supply by taking the pressure at every thousand revolutions of a water wheel temporarily arranged to drive it.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1907-141.

title: Rigg's apparatus for recording engine pressure
description: Rigg's apparatus for recording pressures at every 1000th stroke of in engine

Maker/Donor: Lent by Messrs. W. H. Bailey & Co., Ltd.
Object entry information: This apparatus, patented in 1868 by Sir W. H. Bailey and Mr. J. L. Norton, is designed to indicate the steam or other pressure, and also to make a continuous record showing any fluctuations that may occur. The recorder consists of a casing containing at the bottom an ordinary Bourdon pressure gauge, and at the top a clock. Between the two is placed a rotating cylinder around which is fitted a chart marked with time and pressure lines; the cylinder is rotated by the clock, and a vertically moving pen actuated by a rack and pinion from the gauge spindle, marks on the paper a line showing the pressure at any time. The pressure lines on the chart are uniformly spaced, but are figured to agree with the gauge readings.

Catalogue number: 426
Object name: PRESSURE RECORDER.
Maker/Donor: Lent by Messrs. W. H. Bailey & Co., Ltd.
Date of creation: 1912

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 427
Object name: RECORDING PRESSURE GAUGE.
Maker/Donor: Contributed by the Seal Lock and Registering Pressure Gauge Co., Ltd.
Date of creation: 1874
Object entry information: The feature of this gauge, patented by Mr. G. A. Everett in 1873, is that, in addition to the ordinary indication of the actual pressure, it is made to indicate the number of times a given pressure has been exceeded in the working of the apparatus to which the gauge is fixed, and also the extent to which such pressure has been exceeded. The latter object is effected by a short index or pointer, which turns about the same axis as the ordinary index, and is pushed forward by it as the pressure rises, and remains as a record of the maximum attained. The number of times that a given pressure has been exceeded is recorded by three small pointers working on one axis, driven by a system of ratchet wheels.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1874–140.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 428
Object name: RECORDING PRESSURE GAUGE.
Maker/Donor: Presented by Messrs. The Budenberg Gauge Co., Ltd.
Date of creation: 1921
Object entry information: This instrument, of the Bourdon type, produces a continuous record of the varying pressures maintained during a period of 24 hours in a steam, hydraulic or air-compressing plant; irregularities in working can thus be detected. A reservoir pen on the end of the pointer which is connected by a link to the Bourdon tube works one revolution in the 24 hours. To facilitate the removal of the chart the pen arm is jointed, and can be raised by means of a knurled adjusting screw. The dial is 8 in. diam., and pressures up to 120 lb. per sq. in. can be recorded.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1921–729.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 429
Object name: "THERMOFEED" REGULATOR.
Maker/Donor: Made by Messrs. Ronald Trist & Co., Ltd.
Date of creation: 1914
Object entry information: This is a sectioned example of the device, patented by Mr. A. R. Trist in 1911, for regulating automatically the quantity of feed-water delivered to a boiler so as to maintain a constant water level. Waste of fuel, due to incorrect or large variations in level which occur with hand-feed regulation, are thus avoided. The apparatus consists of two parts, a float chamber and a regulator. The float chamber is a cast-iron vessel connected near the top with the steam space of the boiler, well above the water level, and at the bottom with the water space well below the water level. Within this vessel is an electrolytically sealed copper float connected by toggle levers with a vertical spindle, carrying at its upper end a two-faced controlling valve which rests on either of two seatings formed on the opposite faces of a gunmetal block. The valve seat and toggle levers are attached to a long sleeve passing through the cover of the float chamber, the sleeve being screwed for part of its length which passes through a nut, by which its height can be adjusted so as to set the water level at any desired point. Steam is led from the underside of the controlling valve seating block through radial holes with a pipe leading to the regulator. The upper part of the regulator is open to the atmosphere. The regulator consists of a gunmetal feed valve with a piston working in a cylinder above it. The upper part of the cylinder is connected with the pipe from the controlling valve, while its lower end is open to the atmosphere. The feed valve is normally held open by a spring, acting through a lever, and is pressed down to close it when steam is admitted to the cylinder.
Object/Inventory number: N/A

Maker/Donor: Contributed by the Seal Lock and Registering Pressure Gauge Co., Ltd.

Within this vessel is an electrolytically sealed copper float connected by toggle levers with a vertical spindle, carrying at its upper end a two-faced controlling valve which rests on either of two seatings formed on the opposite faces of a gunmetal block. The valve seat and toggle levers are attached to a long sleeve passing through the cover of the float chamber, the sleeve being screwed for part of its length which passes through a nut, by which its height can be adjusted so as to set the water level at any desired point. Steam is led from the underside of the controlling valve seating block through radial holes with a pipe leading to the regulator. The upper part of the regulator is open to the atmosphere. The regulator consists of a gunmetal feed valve with a piston working in a cylinder above it. The upper part of the cylinder is connected with the pipe from the controlling valve, while its lower end is open to the atmosphere. The feed valve is normally held open by a spring, acting through a lever, and is pressed down to close it when steam is admitted to the cylinder.

title: Recording Pressure Gauge
description: Recording Pressure Gauge, G.A. Everett 1873
maker: Seal Lock & Registering Pressure Gauge Co.

Maker/Donor: Presented by Messrs. The Budenberg Gauge Co., Ltd.
Object entry information: This instrument, of the Bourdon type, produces a continuous record of the varying pressures maintained during a period of 24 hours in a steam, hydraulic or air-compressing plant; irregularities in working can thus be detected. A reservoir pen on the end of the pointer which is connected by a link to the Bourdon tube works one revolution in the 24 hours. To facilitate the removal of the chart the pen arm is jointed, and can be raised by means of a knurled adjusting screw. The dial is 8 in. diam., and pressures up to 120 lb. per sq. in. can be recorded.

Catalogue number: 426
Object name: PRESSURE RECORDER.
Maker/Donor: Lent by Messrs. W. H. Bailey & Co., Ltd.
Date of creation: 1912
Object entry information: This apparatus, patented in 1868 by Sir W. H. Bailey and Mr. J. L. Norton, is designed to indicate the steam or other pressure, and also to make a continuous record showing any fluctuations that may occur. The recorder consists of a casing containing at the bottom an ordinary Bourdon pressure gauge, and at the top a clock. Between the two is placed a rotating cylinder around which is fitted a chart marked with time and pressure lines; the cylinder is rotated by the clock, and a vertically moving pen actuated by a rack and pinion from the gauge spindle, marks on the paper a line showing the pressure at any time. The pressure lines on the chart are uniformly spaced, but are figured to agree with the gauge readings.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1912–87, S.M. 1245.

Catalogue number: 427
Object name: RECORDING PRESSURE GAUGE.
Maker/Donor: Contributed by the Seal Lock and Registering Pressure Gauge Co., Ltd.
Date of creation: 1874
Object entry information: The feature of this gauge, patented by Mr. G. A. Everett in 1873, is that, in addition to the ordinary indication of the actual pressure, it is made to indicate the number of times a given pressure has been exceeded in the working of the apparatus to which the gauge is fixed, and also the extent to which such pressure has been exceeded. The latter object is effected by a short index or pointer, which turns about the same axis as the ordinary index, and is pushed forward by it as the pressure rises, and remains as a record of the maximum attained. The number of times that a given pressure has been exceeded is recorded by three small pointers working on one axis, driven by a system of ratchet wheels.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1874–140.

Date of creation: 1914
Object entry information: This is a sectioned example of the device, patented by Mr. A. R. Trist in 1911, for regulating automatically the quantity of feed-water delivered to a boiler so as to maintain a constant water level. Waste of fuel, due to incorrect or large variations in level which occur with hand-feed regulation, are thus avoided. The apparatus consists of two parts, a float chamber and a regulator. The float chamber is a cast-iron vessel connected near the top with the steam space of the boiler, well above the water level, and at the bottom with the water space well below the water level. Within this vessel is an electrolytically sealed copper float connected by toggle levers with a vertical spindle, carrying at its upper end a two-faced controlling valve which rests on either of two seatings formed on the opposite faces of a gunmetal block. The valve seat and toggle levers are attached to a long sleeve passing through the cover of the float chamber, the sleeve being screwed for part of its length which passes through a nut, by which its height can be adjusted so as to set the water level at any desired point. Steam is led from the underside of the controlling valve seating block through radial holes with a pipe leading to the regulator. The upper part of the regulator is open to the atmosphere. The regulator consists of a gunmetal feed valve with a piston working in a cylinder above it. The upper part of the cylinder is connected with the pipe from the controlling valve, while its lower end is open to the atmosphere. The feed valve is normally held open by a spring, acting through a lever, and is pressed down to close it when steam is admitted to the cylinder.

title: 9" Recording Pressure Gauge reading to 120lbs per sq in.
description: 9" Recording Pressure Gauge reading to 120lbs per sq in., with chart carrier, chart, winding key for clock movement, lock and key for front of case and bottle of ink. No. 5695562

Object entry information: If the water level rises, the float is lifted and the controlling valve is lowered by the toggle levers until it rests on its upper seat. Steam can then pass from the float chamber to the regulator cylinder so as to force down the piston and close the feed valve. When the water level falls, the controlling valve is raised on to its lower seat, steam is cut off from the regulator and its cylinder is exhausted to the atmosphere, so that the spring comes into action and re-opens the feed valve. The steam connection between the controlling valve and the regulator is fitted with a double-seated valve, which in one position permits steam to pass to the regulator, but in the other position shuts off the steam and permanently puts the regulator to atmosphere, so that the latter may be put out of action if desired. In case of puncture of the float or breakage of the mechanism, the feed valve will remain wide open, so that there will be no risk of shortness of water. It is claimed that the water level can be maintained within 0.125 in. of correct level with ordinary boilers, or within 0.25 in. with water-tube boilers. The example shown is for a 2 in. diam. feed pipe.

Catalogue number: 430.
Object name: FEED WATER FILTER.
Maker/Donor: Made by Messrs. Maudslay, Sons & Field.
Date of creation: Received 1909.
Object entry information: This is a filter for removing grease from condenser water before feeding it back into the boiler. It has a cylindrical chamber with a removable top cover and water connections at the top and bottom. Within this is a " cartridge " consisting of a number of horizontal circular grids, between which are placed sheets of wire gauze and turkish towelling or flannel. The cartridge is held down on a flange by set screws passing through stuffing-boxes in the cover, and the water, entering at the bottom, passes up through the grids and leaves any grease in the towelling. The filter is arranged with a by-pass in the piping, so that it may be cut out for the purpose of substituting a clean cartridge for the dirty one. The filter is designed for a pressure of about 150 lb. per sq. in.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1909–109.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 431.
Object name: MODEL OF OIL SEPARATOR. (Scale about 1:4.)
Maker/Donor: Lent by Messrs. Bakers (Leeds), Ltd.
Date of creation: 1921.
Object entry information: The trouble brought about by the presence of grease in boiler feed water is well known, but the loss of efficiency in feed heaters, etc., owing to the deposition of oil carried forward by exhaust steam has not been so widely recognised. The mechanical separator shown is for the purpose of removing such oil. It was patented in 1902 onwards by Mr. W. J. Baker, who had been working on the subject earlier. The separator is most conveniently made, as shown, cylindrical in form, with the inlet and outlet branches arranged to suit its position. The exhaust steam carrying oil and water in suspension enters an expansion compartment, where reduction of velocity and temperature takes place, allowing the water and oil to coalesce into drops that impinge on the sides and on the surface of water, filling the lower part of the vessel 3 to 6 in. in depth. The steam passes under a deflector or baffle into the second compartment, where it impinges on vertical angles of special section staggered in rows. The oil and water so arrested trickle down these collectors by gravity and float off at the grease off-take, which is provided on the shell behind these collectors. It is claimed that the apparatus is thus self-cleansing. A drain on the bottom cover is provided for periodical blow-off purposes. A set of water-gauges is fitted to indicate the water-level. The apparatus is applicable also for other purposes, such as the extraction of tar from fuel gas. The apparatus is made in a very large number of sizes, from 1.5 in. diam. exhaust (160 lb. of steam per hour) to 40 in. diam. (150,000 lb. per hour).
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1921–657.

Catalogue number: 432.
Object name: MODEL OF AIR HEATER. (Scale about 1:4.)
Maker/Donor: Lent by S. Utting, Esq., M.I.Mech.E.
Date of creation: 1921.
Object entry information: The object of this heater, known as the “Thermix,” is to utilise the sensible heat in flue gases from boiler and industrial furnaces. The heater was patented in 1920 be Monsieur Emile Prat and is constructed by the Etablissements Emile Prat-Daniel, Paris.
Object/Inventory number: N/A

Object entry information: The apparatus is placed in the waste gases flue from a boiler or furnace. The features of the heater are the simplicity of design and the ease with which worn-out parts can be replaced; it consists of a frame built up of rolled steel, containing plain flat plates of steel about 3 mm. thick, superposed with distance pieces and coils of steel wire between each, the object of the latter being to transmit pressure uniformly along the edges of the plates and so ensure tight joints. Alternate cells thus formed are in communication with the flue gases and with the cold air respectively. While the former have a straight run the latter has a course transverse to the waste gases in the shape of the letter U, as indicated by the arrows on the model; this U-shaped course is ensured by inserting a series of diaphragms. The air is circulating usually by means of a centrifugal fan. The heated air is used for various purposes, such as the supply of boiler furnaces, heating and drying materials, etc. The dimensions of the heater vary according to the working conditions; the largest single unit so far constructed has nearly 20,000 sq. ft. heating surface.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 433.
Object name: STEEL TUBE MERCURY THERMOMETER.
Maker/Donor: Presented by Messrs. The Budenberg Gauge Co., Ltd.
Date of creation: 1921.
Object entry information: This is a thermometer for taking the temperature of boiler flue gases, superheaters, etc. Its action depends on the expansion of mercury in a closed vessel. A steel cylinder, formed in the end of a tube by which it can be inserted in the boiler flue, etc., is connected through two flexible steel tubes with two Bourdon type tubes. The tubes are shaped like volute springs and their free ends are connected by linkage to a toothed quadrant; the increase of pressure due to the expansion of the mercury under heat is thus transmitted to the pointer indicating on the dial. Instruments with single tubing are liable to error when the latter exceeds 15 ft. in length, due to variations in the temperature of the tubing itself, and to obviate this double coils are used. The movement or expansion of the coils resulting from pressure variations in the flexible tubes is compensated in the mechanism. The flexible tubing may be any length up to 150 ft., so that the indicator dial may be placed in a position convenient for observation, yet well away from the source of heat. Temperatures from 100° F. to 950° F. can be recorded.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1921–731.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 434.
Object name: CARBON DIOXIDE THERMOSCOPE.
Maker/Donor: Presented by Messrs. The Underfeed Stoker Co., Ltd.
Date of creation: 1914.
Object entry information: This is a portable instrument, patented in 1908 by Mr. B. C. Hinman, for measuring the percentage of carbon dioxide (CO₂) in flue gases, and is thus of use for checking and improving plant efficiency. In principle it makes use of the reaction between carbon dioxide and caustic soda. A hand-operated plunger working in a pump barrel draws a sample of the gas mixture from the flue through a three-way cock and rubber connection. This gas is allowed to fall to the temperature of the room, which may be read on a thermometer enclosed in the pump rod. The lower end of the pump rod is graduated with a scale marked in degrees of temperature, and by drawing the plunger out to the graduation corresponding to the room temperature, the correct amount of gas is used. A small cylindrical cartridge, containing a definite quantity of pulverised caustic soda, is packed at both ends and inserted in a receptacle in the instrument, where it is surrounded by the bell-shaped bulb of a thermometer which fits closely round it. This thermometer reads against an adjustable scale graduated in percentages of carbon dioxide, the scale being set to zero before the instrument is used. Having taken the sample of gas, the rubber tube is connected to a hard rubber plug beneath the cartridge and the plunger depressed. The gas is driven through the cartridge and the rise in temperature reads directly as a percentage of carbon dioxide.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1914–223. S.M. 645.

Object name: COMBUSTION INDICATOR FOR BOILER WASTE GASES.
Maker/Donor: Lent by Messrs. W. R. Patents, Ltd.

Object entry information: This is an apparatus on the diffusion principle, patented in 1916 by Mr. H. Webster for determining the percentage of carbon dioxide in flue gases of boilers, and hence enabling a check on the firing to be maintained.

Alternate cells thus formed are in communication with the flue gases and with the cold air respectively. While the former have a straight run the latter has a course transverse to the waste gases in the shape of the letter U, as indicated by the arrows on the model; this U-shaped course is ensured by inserting a series of diaphragms. The air is circulating usually by means of a centrifugal fan. The heated air is used for various purposes, such as the supply of boiler furnaces, heating and drying materials, etc. The dimensions of the heater vary according to the working conditions; the largest single unit so far constructed has nearly 20,000 sq. ft. heating surface.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1921–441.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 433.
Object name: STEEL TUBE MERCURY THERMOMETER.
Maker/Donor: Presented by Messrs. The Budenberg Gauge Co., Ltd.
Date of creation: 1921.
Object entry information: This is a thermometer for taking the temperature of boiler flue gases, superheaters, etc. Its action depends on the expansion of mercury in a closed vessel. A steel cylinder, formed in the end of a tube by which it can be inserted in the boiler flue, etc., is connected through two flexible steel tubes with two Bourdon type tubes. The tubes are shaped like volute springs and their free ends are connected by linkage to a toothed quadrant; the increase of pressure due to the expansion of the mercury under heat is thus transmitted to the pointer indicating on the dial. Instruments with single tubing are liable to error when the latter exceeds 15 ft. in length, due to variations in the temperature of the tubing itself, and to obviate this double coils are used. The movement or expansion of the coils resulting from pressure variations in the flexible tubes is compensated in the mechanism. The flexible tubing may be any length up to 150 ft., so that the indicator dial may be placed in a position convenient for observation, yet well away from the source of heat. Temperatures from 100° F. to 950° F. can be recorded.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1921–731.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 434.
Object name: CARBON DIOXIDE THERMOSCOPE.
Maker/Donor: Presented by Messrs. The Underfeed Stoker Co., Ltd.
Date of creation: 1914.
Object entry information: This is a portable instrument, patented in 1908 by Mr. B. C. Hinman, for measuring the percentage of carbon dioxide (CO₂) in flue gases, and is thus of use for checking and improving plant efficiency. In principle it makes use of the reaction between carbon dioxide and caustic soda. A hand-operated plunger working in a pump barrel draws a sample of the gas mixture from the flue through a three-way cock and rubber connection. This gas is allowed to fall to the temperature of the room, which may be read on a thermometer enclosed in the pump rod. The lower end of the pump rod is graduated with a scale marked in degrees of temperature, and by drawing the plunger out to the graduation corresponding to the room temperature, the correct amount of gas is used. A small cylindrical cartridge, containing a definite quantity of pulverised caustic soda, is packed at both ends and inserted in a receptacle in the instrument, where it is surrounded by the bell-shaped bulb of a thermometer which fits closely round it. This thermometer reads against an adjustable scale graduated in percentages of carbon dioxide, the scale being set to zero before the instrument is used. Having taken the sample of gas, the rubber tube is connected to a hard rubber plug beneath the cartridge and the plunger depressed. The gas is driven through the cartridge and the rise in temperature reads directly as a percentage of carbon dioxide.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1914–223. S.M. 645.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 435.
Object name: COMBUSTION INDICATOR FOR BOILER WASTE GASES.
Maker/Donor: Lent by Messrs. W. R. Patents, Ltd.
Date of creation: 1921.
Object entry information: This is an apparatus on the diffusion principle, patented in 1916 by Mr. H. Webster for determining the percentage of carbon dioxide in flue gases of boilers, and hence enabling a check on the firing to be maintained.

description: Carbon Dioxide Thermoscope with rubber connection, in leather case
object_name: carbon dioxide thermoscope; carbon dioxide thermoscope

Object entry information:
An absorbent for CO₂, such as potash or soda, is enclosed in a chamber having porous walls, and the variation in the pressure inside the chamber when surrounded by gases indicates the amount of CO₂ by the difference in heights of liquid within a U tube, against a scale on which the percentage is red. The porous vessel is protected from flue dust, etc., by a filter.
There is one print showing the attachments of the indicator and another its mode of installation on boilers of the Lancashire and water-tube type respectively.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 436.
Object name: MODEL OF FEED-WATER HEATER. (Scale 1:8.)
Maker/Donor: Lent by Messrs. Joseph Wright & Co., 1901.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: In this heater, which was patented by Mr. R. Berryman in 1871–6, the exhaust steam from the engine is passed through a group of U-tubes, secured into a V-shaped tube plate which serves also as a diaphragm between the steam inlet and outlet; improvements in detail, including the combination with it of an oil separator, have since been added by the makers.
The upper part of the apparatus is made of boiler plate and surrounds the tubes, but can be lifted off for cleaning them externally; into it the feed-water is introduced, the deposited impurities settling in the V-shaped depression of the tube plate from whence they are washed out at intervals. Beneath this shell is the middle belt, into which the steam enters on one side and, after passing through the tubes, is condensed into water which collects in the base. The base is divided by a diaphragm, which also supports the tube plate and has openings below through which any remaining steam can pass away; the collected water is discharged by a siphon when it exceeds a certain depth.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1901-39.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 437.
Object name: DRAWING OF FEED-WATER HEATER.
Maker/Donor: Lent by James Atkinson, Esq., 1890.
Date of creation: 1890
Object entry information: In this feed-water heater, patented by Mr. J. Atkinson in 1877, the exhaust steam from the engine enters at the steam inlet and passes in a direct unimpeded course through a channel provided for it, which is of a similar sectional area throughout, to the steam outlet, from which the exhaust pipe conducts away the steam not utilised in heating the water.
The channel is open at the top to the lower side of the tube plate. Screwed into the tube plate are a number of vertical tubes, open to the exhaust steam at the bottom, but closed at their upper ends, which are left perfectly free to expand or contract without straining. In each of these heating tubes is a small circulating tube leading from near their upper ends to the channel through which the exhaust steam passes, and the mouths are so arranged that the passing steam causes an induced current out of them, and thus out of the upper ends of the heating tubes, removing the air which they contain, or which may be carried in with the exhaust steam, and causing them to be filled with steam. A small portion of the heating tubes projects into the exhaust steam, and assists in diverting the steam into them.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1890-107.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 438.
Object name: “COMPACTUM” FEED-WATER HEATER.
Maker/Donor: Lent by J. Kirkaldy, Esq., 1887.
Date of creation: 1887
Object entry information: This is an apparatus, patented by Mr. Kirkaldy in 1885, for heating the feed-water for a boiler by means of the exhaust steam. It consists of four helical coils of pipe, partly interlocking with one another, through which the water flows, and these are enclosed in a chamber through which the steam passes. The ends of the tubes are secured in holes through the cover plate of the chamber by nuts, and the four at each end are covered by a small box to which one of the external water pipes is attached. The coiled pipe is corrugated longitudinally so as to increase the proportion of heating surface to sectional area and space occupied.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1887-130.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 439.
Object name: DRAWING OF FEED-WATER HEATER.
Maker/Donor: Lent by Messrs. Hawksley, Wild & Co., 1894.
Date of creation: 1894
Object entry information: In this form of feed-water heater the water passes up through vertical tubes, and then down through similar tubes to the boiler feed-pipe below.
The tubes are enclosed in a vertical cylindrical shell through which the exhaust steam is passed, a vertical baffle plate directing the steam over the surfaces of the tubes. The drawing also shows a modified form, in which the steam passes through the tubes and the water is outside them, but both arrangements leave the tubes free to expand independently of the outside shell.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1894-180.

Screwed into the tube plate are a number of vertical tubes, open to the exhaust steam at the bottom, but closed at their upper ends, which are left perfectly free to expand or contract without straining. In each of these heating tubes is a small circulating tube leading from near their upper ends to the channel through which the exhaust steam passes, and the mouths are so arranged that the passing steam causes an induced current out of them, and thus out of the upper ends of the heating tubes, removing the air which they contain, or which may be carried in with the exhaust steam, and causing them to be filled with steam. A small portion of the heating tubes projects into the exhaust steam, and assists in diverting the steam into them.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1890-107.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 438.
Object name: “COMPACTUM” FEED-WATER HEATER.
Maker/Donor: Lent by J. Kirkaldy, Esq., 1887.
Date of creation: 1887
Object entry information: This is an apparatus, patented by Mr. Kirkaldy in 1885, for heating the feed-water for a boiler by means of the exhaust steam. It consists of four helical coils of pipe, partly interlocking with one another, through which the water flows, and these are enclosed in a chamber through which the steam passes. The ends of the tubes are secured in holes through the cover plate of the chamber by nuts, and the four at each end are covered by a small box to which one of the external water pipes is attached. The coiled pipe is corrugated longitudinally so as to increase the proportion of heating surface to sectional area and space occupied.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1887-130.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 439.
Object name: DRAWING OF FEED-WATER HEATER.
Maker/Donor: Lent by Messrs. Hawksley, Wild & Co., 1894.
Date of creation: 1894
Object entry information: In this form of feed-water heater the water passes up through vertical tubes, and then down through similar tubes to the boiler feed-pipe below.
The tubes are enclosed in a vertical cylindrical shell through which the exhaust steam is passed, a vertical baffle plate directing the steam over the surfaces of the tubes. The drawing also shows a modified form, in which the steam passes through the tubes and the water is outside them, but both arrangements leave the tubes free to expand independently of the outside shell.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1894-180.

Object entry information: An absorbent for CO₂, such as potash or soda, is enclosed in a chamber having porous walls, and the variation in the pressure inside the chamber when surrounded by gases indicates the amount of CO₂ by the difference in heights of liquid within a U tube, against a scale on which the percentage is red. The porous vessel is protected from flue dust, etc., by a filter.
There is one print showing the attachments of the indicator and another its mode of installation on boilers of the Lancashire and water-tube type respectively.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1921-411.

Catalogue number: 436.
Object name: MODEL OF FEED-WATER HEATER. (Scale 1:8.)
Maker/Donor: Lent by Messrs. Joseph Wright & Co., 1901.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: In this heater, which was patented by Mr. R. Berryman in 1871–6, the exhaust steam from the engine is passed through a group of U-tubes, secured into a V-shaped tube plate which serves also as a diaphragm between the steam inlet and outlet; improvements in detail, including the combination with it of an oil separator, have since been added by the makers.
The upper part of the apparatus is made of boiler plate and surrounds the tubes, but can be lifted off for cleaning them externally; into it the feed-water is introduced, the deposited impurities settling in the V-shaped depression of the tube plate from whence they are washed out at intervals. Beneath this shell is the middle belt, into which the steam enters on one side and, after passing through the tubes, is condensed into water which collects in the base. The base is divided by a diaphragm, which also supports the tube plate and has openings below through which any remaining steam can pass away; the collected water is discharged by a siphon when it exceeds a certain depth.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1901-39.

Maker/Donor: Lent by Messrs. A. Lowcock, Ltd.
Object entry information: Plate VIII., No. 2. The name "economiser" is applied to a type of feed-water heater originally introduced about 1845, in which the water before entering the boiler is caused to take up some of the heat in the waste gases leaving the boiler flues and thus economise fuel. A subsidiary advantage is that more duty can be obtained from the boiler with it than without it, and troubles from expansion and contraction are minimised. The apparatus is built into the main flue between the boiler and the chimney. In the particular case shown in the model the boiler is of the Lancashire type and the apparatus is arranged in a by-pass flue with suitable valves, so that the boiler may be worked with or without it. The economiser shown embodies improvements patented by Mr. A. Lowcock and Mr. T. Sykes between 1880 and 1894. It is constructed of vertical cast-iron pipes whose ends are forced by hydraulic pressure into top and bottom headers; the top headers are provided with a lid or cleaning cover, while the bottom ones have a slope towards the blow-off branch pipe, to which is attached a blow-off valve. Each tube is fitted with scrapers, which are moved slowly up and down to remove the soot which would otherwise accumulate and would seriously detract from the efficiency of the apparatus. The scrapers are worked in balanced groups by chains passing over pulleys actuated by worm gear, the reversals at the end of their travel being effected by a tappet-moved, three bevel wheel clutch, and assisted by a rolling weight. The soot scraped off falls into a chamber below the pipes and is removed at intervals through cleaning doors. The feed-water is forced into the economiser by the feed-pump or injector through the bottom branch pipe at the end furthest from the boiler and leaves by the top branch nearest the boiler, so that the hottest gas meets the hottest water. The economiser is made in sections of from 4 to 12 pipes in width and of any length to suit the number and capacity of the boilers installed. Each tube has over 10 sq. ft. of heating surface. The feed-water is usually supplied to the economiser at 32 deg. C. (90 deg. F.) and leaves at 120 deg. C. (250 deg. F.) to 150 deg. C. (300 deg. F.), a saving of fuel of as much as 20 per cent. is claimed. An indirect advantage of the use of an economiser is that most of the impurities of the feed-water are deposited in the apparatus, whence they can be blown out daily and thus avoid incrustation in the boiler.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 441.
Object name: FRESH WATER CONDENSER.
Maker/Donor: Lent by Messrs. Royles, Ltd.
Date of creation: 1902.
Object entry information: This condenser embodies improvements patented by Mr. O. M. Row in 1891, and in the form represented it would be used in connection with a boiler or "evaporator," for obtaining fresh water from sea water; with slight modifications, however, the arrangement can be converted into a feed-water heater. The condenser consists of an outer casing containing a number of vertical tubes, the ends of which are either expanded into a tube plate or made tight by some form of screw joint; the cooling water circulates within the casing, its inlet and outlet being at the side, while the steam or vapour to be condensed passes through the tubes, entering at the top and being discharged as condensed feed or drinking water at the bottom. If the water is required for drinking purposes it is aerated by the pipe shown, the air entering through the hooded orifice and passing into the condenser, where it mixes with, and is partially absorbed by, the distilled water. The chief feature of this condenser is the form of tube employed, of which a short portion of an actual length is shown. This "Row" tube is indented at intervals along its length, so as to reduce the section at each indentation to a narrow rectangle at right angles to the adjacent ones; in this way the free passage along the tube of the vapour and water, both inside and outside, is checked, and the formation of steady streams avoided, thus increasing the transference of heat by the greater amount of impact contact secured.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1902-46 to 48.
