Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: [443.]
Object name: [STEAM PUMP.]
Maker/Donor: [Lent by J. Cameron, Esq.]
Date of creation: [1887]
Object entry information: [This type of direct-acting flywheel donkey pump was patented by Mr. Cameron in 1852, and has since been extensively adopted for boiler feeding and similar work. The steam cylinder is arranged vertically over the pump barrel, and the pump rod is attached to an inverted kite-shaped casting which terminates in the pump plunger; within the loop of this casting is arranged a connecting rod, attached to it and to the overhanging crank of a flywheel shaft, so that direct action is secured while the control of a crank and flywheel is retained. The slide valve is worked by an eccentric on the crankshaft, and the other end of this shaft is provided with another crank working a similar single-acting pump; the cranks are set opposite, so that the pumps deliver alternately. Sometimes double-acting pumps are substituted, while very frequently there are two steam cylinders in the arrangement shown. The pump valve bores are formed in the supporting columns which act as air vessels.]
Object/Inventory number: [Inv. 1887–131]

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: [444.]
Object name: [STEAM PUMP.]
Maker/Donor: [Contributed by Messrs. J. Withinshaw and Co.]
Date of creation: [1869]
Object entry information: [This simple and early form of the self-contained double-acting steam pump was patented and constructed in 1867 by Messrs. J. Withinshaw and J. E. Baker. The slide valve for the steam cylinder is worked by a tappet motion from the piston rod which is common to both steam and water cylinders; the tappet itself consists of a collar secured to the piston rod and enclosed in a cylindrical sleeve which is loose on the rod but is provided with caps which are struck by the tappet when near the extremities of the stroke. This sleeve moves a lever connected with the slide valve, and an extension of the lever forms a handle by which the valve can be moved when starting. The steam cylinder is 5·5 in. diam. and the pump 3·25 in. diam.; the steam chest cover has been removed to render the slide valve visible.]
Object/Inventory number: [Inv. 1869–19]

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: [445.]
Object name: [VERTICAL STEAM PUMP.]
Maker/Donor: [Lent by Messrs. Alexander Wilson & Co.]
Date of creation: [1871]
Object entry information: [This is a small direct-acting plunger pump, with a flywheel for controlling the motion and working the slide valve. The steam cylinder is above, and, on its cover, carries the bearings of the flywheel shaft. The piston rod forms the plunger and is consequently large—thus reducing the speed when little steam taken on the up-stroke when but little work is being done. From the plunger projects a form of crosshead sliding on a vertical guide, and from the crosshead extends upward a connecting rod to a crankpin on the flywheel. At the other end of the flywheel shaft is a small overhanging crank, working a block capable of sliding in a slot formed in an extension of the slide valve rod. This arrangement is equivalent to steam distribution by a simple eccentric with an eccentric rod of infinite length. The pump valves are arranged in a valve box attached to the pump barrel.]
Object/Inventory number: [Inv. 1871–7]

Catalogue number: [446.]
Object name: [FEED PUMP (working).]
Maker/Donor: [Made by A. G. Mumford, Esq. Received 1907.]
Date of creation: [N/A]
Object entry information: [This is a direct-acting suction and force pump for boiler feeding, etc. The flywheel, controlling the slide valve of the steam cylinder through an eccentric, is driven without the intervention of a connecting rod by a block on the crankpin, sliding in a slot at right angles to its length in the common piston rod which thus has a simple harmonic motion. The suction and delivery valves are of the mushroom type. The steam cylinder is 2 in. diam. and the plunger 1·2 in. diam. with a common stroke of 1·9 in.]
Object/Inventory number: [Inv. 1907–45]

Maker/Donor: [Lent by J. Cameron, Esq.]
Object entry information: [This type of direct-acting flywheel donkey pump was patented by Mr. Cameron in 1852, and has since been extensively adopted for boiler feeding and similar work. The steam cylinder is arranged vertically over the pump barrel, and the pump rod is attached to an inverted kite-shaped casting which terminates in the pump plunger; within the loop of this casting is arranged a connecting rod, attached to it and to the overhanging crank of a flywheel shaft, so that direct action is secured while the control of a crank and flywheel is retained. The slide valve is worked by an eccentric on the crankshaft, and the other end of this shaft is provided with another crank working a similar single-acting pump; the cranks are set opposite, so that the pumps deliver alternately. Sometimes double-acting pumps are substituted, while very frequently there are two steam cylinders in the arrangement shown. The pump valve bores are formed in the supporting columns which act as air vessels.]

Object entry information: [This simple and early form of the self-contained double-acting steam pump was patented and constructed in 1867 by Messrs. J. Withinshaw and J. E. Baker. The slide valve for the steam cylinder is worked by a tappet motion from the piston rod which is common to both steam and water cylinders; the tappet itself consists of a collar secured to the piston rod and enclosed in a cylindrical sleeve which is loose on the rod but is provided with caps which are struck by the tappet when near the extremities of the stroke. This sleeve moves a lever connected with the slide valve, and an extension of the lever forms a handle by which the valve can be moved when starting. The steam cylinder is 5·5 in. diam. and the pump 3·25 in. diam.; the steam chest cover has been removed to render the slide valve visible.]
Object/Inventory number: [Inv. 1869–19]

Catalogue number: [445.]
Object name: [VERTICAL STEAM PUMP.]
Maker/Donor: [Lent by Messrs. Alexander Wilson & Co.]
Date of creation: [1871]
Object entry information: [This is a small direct-acting plunger pump, with a flywheel for controlling the motion and working the slide valve. The steam cylinder is above, and, on its cover, carries the bearings of the flywheel shaft. The piston rod forms the plunger and is consequently large—thus reducing the speed when little steam taken on the up-stroke when but little work is being done. From the plunger projects a form of crosshead sliding on a vertical guide, and from the crosshead extends upward a connecting rod to a crankpin on the flywheel. At the other end of the flywheel shaft is a small overhanging crank, working a block capable of sliding in a slot formed in an extension of the slide valve rod. This arrangement is equivalent to steam distribution by a simple eccentric with an eccentric rod of infinite length. The pump valves are arranged in a valve box attached to the pump barrel.]
Object/Inventory number: [Inv. 1871–7]

Maker/Donor: Made by J. Stannah, Esq.
Object entry information: This machine, patented in 1876 by Mr. Stannah, has the steam cylinder above and a single-acting pump below, the large piston rod being carried down to form the pump plunger. The cylinder, framing, and pump are all in one casting. Projecting from the piston rod is a stud, on which is a flywheel free to revolve. At another point within the flywheel is attached the free end of a connecting rod, the other end of which is capable of swinging on a fixed centre on the cylinder front. As the flywheel is driven up and down the connecting rod compels it to rotate, and the momentum carries the engines over the dead centres. The motion of the connecting rod actuates a small cylindrical slide valve by which the distribution of steam to the cylinder is effected. By imagining the connecting rod to be fixed, and the rest of the engine to be free to swing, it will be seen that the arrangement is equivalent to an oscillating cylinder engine with the steam distribution by the motion of the trunnions. This example has a 1.75 in. cylinder, 0.875 in. plunger, and a stroke of 2.25 in., and is intended to make 110 revs. per min.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 448.
Object name: DIRECT-ACTING STEAM PUMP (working).
Maker/Donor: Made by J. Bernays, Esq.
Date of creation: 1892.
Object entry information: This pump, patented in 1884 by Mr. Bernays, is remarkable for the arrangement of crank and connecting rod by which the flywheel is connected with the reciprocating plunger, the result being that the stroke of the ram is twice the diameter of the crank path. The machine is arranged with the steam cylinder at one end, the large piston rod of which is carried through and forms the plunger of a single-acting pump at the opposite end of the machine. The flywheel and shaft with an overhanging crank are placed midway, the crankpin being connected with a pin on the pump ram by a connecting rod whose effective length is equal to the radius of the crank path. This connecting rod is produced backwards, and terminates in a circular end which engages alternately in two notches formed in a portion of the framing or the extremity of the short arm of the flywheel shaft. The outer extremity of the short connecting rod is in this way controlled, and the kinematic chain closed during the time it would otherwise be incomplete. The result is that the throw of the crank is increased by the length of the connecting rod at each end of the stroke. The adjacent diagram shows the positions of crank and connecting rod at various portions of a revolution, the connecting rod being coloured blue, the ram red, and the stationary notches grey. The admission of steam is controlled by an ordinary eccentric and slide valve, but when required to drive by hand, a handle is inserted in the fly-wheel. The suction and delivery valves are contained in boxes with circular flanges, which can be bolted on to suit a horizontal or vertical arrangement of the pump.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1892–126.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 449.
Object name: DIRECT-ACTING STEAM PUMP.
Maker/Donor: Made by Messrs. Miller & Tupp.
Date of creation: Received 1901.
Object entry information: This is a small boiler feed-pump constructed upon a system patented by Mr. J. J. Miller in 1884. The steam cylinder and the pump are a single casting, and the piston rod forms the pump plunger; on one side of the cylinder is a chamber containing a crank-disc fixed to the shaft of an external flywheel, while an eccentric hole in this disc receives the spherical end of a pin projecting from the elongated piston of the steam cylinder. The piston as it reciprocates therefore turns the fly-wheel, and the engine itself undergoes continuous rotary motion. In the cylinder wall there are two steam ports, considerable to-and-fro movement between them, while the piston has two axial grooves and an exhaust port between their top and bottom faces respectively, the arrangement being such that the piston, by its rotating motion, acts as its own slide valve and gives a steam distribution similar to that obtained by the use of an eccentric without angular advance (see also No. 122). The cylinder is 1.1 in. diam. by 0.68 in. stroke and the plunger is 0.56 in. diam.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1901–40.

Object entry information: This machine, patented in 1876 by Mr. Stannah, has the steam cylinder above and a single-acting pump below, the large piston rod being carried down to form the pump plunger. The cylinder, framing, and pump are all in one casting. Projecting from the piston rod is a stud, on which is a flywheel free to revolve. At another point within the flywheel is attached the free end of a connecting rod, the other end of which is capable of swinging on a fixed centre on the cylinder front. As the flywheel is driven up and down the connecting rod compels it to rotate, and the momentum carries the engines over the dead centres. The motion of the connecting rod actuates a small cylindrical slide valve by which the distribution of steam to the cylinder is effected. By imagining the connecting rod to be fixed, and the rest of the engine to be free to swing, it will be seen that the arrangement is equivalent to an oscillating cylinder engine with the steam distribution by the motion of the trunnions. This example has a 1.75 in. cylinder, 0.875 in. plunger, and a stroke of 2.25 in., and is intended to make 110 revs. per min.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1892–125.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 448.
Object name: DIRECT-ACTING STEAM PUMP (working).
Maker/Donor: Made by J. Bernays, Esq.
Date of creation: 1892.
Object entry information: This pump, patented in 1884 by Mr. Bernays, is remarkable for the arrangement of crank and connecting rod by which the flywheel is connected with the reciprocating plunger, the result being that the stroke of the ram is twice the diameter of the crank path. The machine is arranged with the steam cylinder at one end, the large piston rod of which is carried through and forms the plunger of a single-acting pump at the opposite end of the machine. The flywheel and shaft with an overhanging crank are placed midway, the crankpin being connected with a pin on the pump ram by a connecting rod whose effective length is equal to the radius of the crank path. This connecting rod is produced backwards, and terminates in a circular end which engages alternately in two notches formed in a portion of the framing or the extremity of the short arm of the flywheel shaft. The outer extremity of the short connecting rod is in this way controlled, and the kinematic chain closed during the time it would otherwise be incomplete. The result is that the throw of the crank is increased by the length of the connecting rod at each end of the stroke. The adjacent diagram shows the positions of crank and connecting rod at various portions of a revolution, the connecting rod being coloured blue, the ram red, and the stationary notches grey. The admission of steam is controlled by an ordinary eccentric and slide valve, but when required to drive by hand, a handle is inserted in the fly-wheel. The suction and delivery valves are contained in boxes with circular flanges, which can be bolted on to suit a horizontal or vertical arrangement of the pump.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1892–126.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 449.
Object name: DIRECT-ACTING STEAM PUMP.
Maker/Donor: Made by Messrs. Miller & Tupp.
Date of creation: Received 1901.
Object entry information: This is a small boiler feed-pump constructed upon a system patented by Mr. J. J. Miller in 1884. The steam cylinder and the pump are a single casting, and the piston rod forms the pump plunger; on one side of the cylinder is a chamber containing a crank-disc fixed to the shaft of an external flywheel, while an eccentric hole in this disc receives the spherical end of a pin projecting from the elongated piston of the steam cylinder. The piston as it reciprocates therefore turns the fly-wheel, and the engine itself undergoes continuous rotary motion. In the cylinder wall there are two steam ports, considerable to-and-fro movement between them, while the piston has two axial grooves and an exhaust port between their top and bottom faces respectively, the arrangement being such that the piston, by its rotating motion, acts as its own slide valve and gives a steam distribution similar to that obtained by the use of an eccentric without angular advance (see also No. 122). The cylinder is 1.1 in. diam. by 0.68 in. stroke and the plunger is 0.56 in. diam.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1901–40.

title: Smallest size direct acting "Dolphin" feed pump
description: Smallest size direct acting "Dolphin" feed pump, with flywheel, Miller patent 1884

Object entry information: there is a steam-moved main or distributing valve working horizontally and controlling the admission and exhaust of the steam to the cylinder ends, and an auxiliary valve, worked by a tappet gear, moving vertically on the back of the main valve and controlling its movements while also serving as a cut-off valve. The main valve is an ordinary slide valve, hollow, cylindrical at its middle, where ports are formed, and it slides on a cylindrical face which is provided with the usual cylinder ports. The cylindrical ends at fro fit into small cylinders or caps in the ends of the steam chest; the D-shaped part of the valve forms a flat face across which the auxiliary valve moves, and ports are formed in it leading to the ends of the main valve, and others admitting steam to the cylinder ports. The auxiliary valve is moved by a tappet lever driven from the middle point of the piston rod, and it admits steam alternately to the ends of the main valve thus causing it to move to and fro; the auxiliary valve also cuts off the steam at about 0.75 of the stroke, the remainder being performed by expansion. When starting or when otherwise necessary steam may be admitted during the whole stroke through by-passes cut in the main valve and its caps; these are opened by rotating the caps from outside the valve chest. As the main valve must be at one end or the other of its stroke, the pump is always ready to start. The water cylinder is double-acting; it has a gunmetal liner and the piston is packed with ebonite rings. The inlet and discharge valves are of the Kinghorn pattern (see No. 451), each having three discs with a spring and guard above; they are arranged one above the other and their seatings and guards are held in position by a single screw above. The pump has a steam cylinder 3 in. diam. and a water cylinder 3.5 in. diam., the stroke being 6 in. It is capable of delivering 700 gal. of water per hour when working at 31 double strokes per min.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 451.
Object name: MULTIPLE DISC VALVE.
Maker/Donor: Metallic Valve Co. (Presented by)
Date of creation: 1922
Object entry information: This feed pump valve, patented by Mr. J. G. Kinghorn in 1886, is designed for high pressures. Shock is much reduced by the independent action of each disc and by the cushioning effect of the film of water formed between them. It is claimed to be lighter than other types of valves for the same service. The valve consists of three superimposed discs, of decreasing diameters, made of a tough rust-resisting metal, which are free to move independently on a fixed central stud, the lowest disc resting normally on the flat seating. The two lower discs are perforated in such a way that the openings can never overlap. A heavy guard is fitted to limit the valve opening, and this contains a helical spring, which tends to keep the valve shut. When water is forced through the valve the discs lift and some of the water flows through the perforations and between the discs, forming films which act as cushions when the valve strikes the guard. A similar action occurs on closing. In this way shock and wear are reduced, giving the valve a long life. When dealing with a large quantity of water it is better to use several small valves of this type rather than a single large one.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1922-615.

Catalogue number: 452.
Object name: GIFFARD'S INJECTOR.
Maker/Donor: Messrs. Sharp, Stewart & Co. (Contributed by)
Date of creation: 1875
Object entry information: This is a sectional example of an injector following very closely the arrangement described by M. Giffard in his original patent of 1858 for "Improvements in Feed Apparatus for Steam and other Boilers, which improvements are also applicable to the raising and forcing of fluid." Steam from the boiler is admitted into the apparatus through the inlet marked "steam," and a supply of water is laid on to the other inlet marked "water"; the outlet at the end is for the passage of the water that is being forced into the boiler, while the "overflow" outlet is provided for the escape of any water or steam that may accumulate in the apparatus when it is working imperfectly, as when starting. The live steam passes through the annular space between the solid cone and the conical nozzle, and thence issues as a fine hollow conical jet, moving at a high velocity; the particles of steam drag with them some of the surrounding air, thus causing in the enclosing space a reduction of pressure, so that the supply water enters by the atmospheric pressure. When thus started the water continues to flow and the steam of it condenses within it, thereby giving it sufficient velocity to force its way through a check valve into the boiler. Maker/Donor: [N/A]
Object entry information: "independent adjustment, since if too much water be drawn in by the inductive action of the steam jet, the combined stream will not have sufficient velocity to force its way into the boiler. The action of the injector is more fully realised when it is remembered that the steam from a boiler issues into the atmosphere with a velocity that may be fifteen times as great as that of a water jet from the same boiler; this steam may, however, be condensed in five times its weight of water, so that after the distribution of the momentum of the steam jet into the mass of the combined jet a final velocity more than double that of a simple water jet from the boiler is obtained. This high velocity energy is converted into pressure energy more than sufficient to overcome the boiler pressure, by the slight divergence of the combining or delivery cone, which acts as a Bernoulli tube."

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: "453."
Object name: "COMPOUND INJECTOR."
Maker/Donor: "Lent by Messrs. Körting Bros.,"
Date of creation: "1885."
Object entry information: "This construction of double injector was patented by Mr. E. Körting in 1873 and 1876. It consists of two slightly different Giffard injectors (see No. 452), arranged in series, so that the first, or lifter, feeds the other, or forcer, which delivers into the boiler. The delivery chambers of both lifter and forcer communicate with the overflow pipe by a three-way starting cock; the latter and the two conical steam valves are manipulated by a single hand-lever. When starting, the lever is moved through a part only of its travel, thus slightly opening the steam valves and at the same time opening both delivery chambers to overflow; the arrangement then readily lifts water by its steam exhauster action. The handle is then moved right over, so as to open fully both steam valves and close completely the overflow, after which the forcing injector feeds into the boiler."
Object/Inventory number: "Inv. 1885–153."

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: "454."
Object name: "COMPOUND INJECTOR."
Maker/Donor: "Lent by the Hancock Inspirator Co.,"
Date of creation: "1887."
Object entry information: "This form of double injector was patented by Mr. J. F. Hancock in 1876– 1877. It consists of two Giffard's injectors (see No. 452), arranged in series, so that the first acts as a lifter and the second as a forcer, an arrangement that facilitates starting. The forcer valve at the top admits steam to the second injector, and there are two overflow valves, the upper one when open allowing the water and condensed steam from the lifter to pass direct to the overflow. In a modification of the above by the same makers, all the valves are actuated by a single lever."
Object/Inventory number: "Inv. 1887–127, 19,616."

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: "455."
Object name: "EXHAUST INJECTOR."
Maker/Donor: "Lent by Messrs. Davies & Metcalfe, Ltd.,"
Date of creation: "1902."
Object entry information: "This is a sectioned example of the injector patented by Messrs. Hamer, Metcalfe, and Davies, in 1877–80, in which, by an important modification in the usual construction, self-starting is secured and the apparatus is enabled to work with the exhaust steam from an engine, instead of requiring live steam from the boiler. The injector consists of a cast-iron casing containing the usual three nozzles, the steam nozzle, however, being exceptionally large on account of the large volume of steam to be passed, and having a conical spike in its centre to assist in concentrating the steam. The combining nozzle is the leading feature, however, as it is split or divided into two parts over a portion of its length by an axial plane, and one of these parts is hinged to the main portion at its upper end, so as to become a movable flap. The combining and delivery nozzles are connected together, and the water supply orifice beyond them is rendered adjustable by means of a nut at the delivery end. The overflow pipe has a chamber with a partition across it, which forms a water seal, and so prevents the entry of air into the combining cone. When starting, the steam and water escape freely into the overflow by the open flap, but when the combined jet acquires such a velocity as to be capable of feeding the boiler its exhaustive action becomes sufficient to close the flap, so that the water passes into the boiler through the delivery pipe. These injectors will, with exhaust steam, feed against a pressure of about 75 lb. per sq. in.; if required to supply a boiler at a higher pressure, an extra steam nozzle, supplied with boiler steam, is added to assist in the work; or else a supplementary injector supplied with boiler steam is used, which takes the water, already heated and raised to a considerable pressure by the exhaust injector, along into the boiler."
Object/Inventory number: "Inv. 1902–140."

Object entry information: "This form of double injector was patented by Mr. J. F. Hancock in 1876– 1877. It consists of two Giffard's injectors (see No. 452), arranged in series, so that the first acts as a lifter and the second as a forcer, an arrangement that facilitates starting. The forcer valve at the top admits steam to the second injector, and there are two overflow valves, the upper one when open allowing the water and condensed steam from the lifter to pass direct to the overflow. Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: "455."
Object name: "EXHAUST INJECTOR."
Maker/Donor: "Lent by Messrs. Davies & Metcalfe, Ltd.,"
Date of creation: "1902."
Object entry information: "This is a sectioned example of the injector patented by Messrs. Hamer, Metcalfe, and Davies, in 1877–80, in which, by an important modification in the usual construction, self-starting is secured and the apparatus is enabled to work with the exhaust steam from an engine, instead of requiring live steam from the boiler. The injector consists of a cast-iron casing containing the usual three nozzles, the steam nozzle, however, being exceptionally large on account of the large volume of steam to be passed, and having a conical spike in its centre to assist in concentrating the steam. The combining nozzle is the leading feature, however, as it is split or divided into two parts over a portion of its length by an axial plane, and one of these parts is hinged to the main portion at its upper end, so as to become a movable flap. The combining and delivery nozzles are connected together, and the water supply orifice beyond them is rendered adjustable by means of a nut at the delivery end. The overflow pipe has a chamber with a partition across it, which forms a water seal, and so prevents the entry of air into the combining cone. When starting, the steam and water escape freely into the overflow by the open flap, but when the combined jet acquires such a velocity as to be capable of feeding the boiler its exhaustive action becomes sufficient to close the flap, so that the water passes into the boiler through the delivery pipe. These injectors will, with exhaust steam, feed against a pressure of about 75 lb. per sq. in.; if required to supply a boiler at a higher pressure, an extra steam nozzle, supplied with boiler steam, is added to assist in the work; or else a supplementary injector supplied with boiler steam is used, which takes the water, already heated and raised to a considerable pressure by the exhaust injector, along into the boiler."
Object/Inventory number: "Inv. 1902–140."

Object entry information: "independent adjustment, since if too much water be drawn in by the inductive action of the steam jet, the combined stream will not have sufficient velocity to force its way into the boiler. The action of the injector is more fully realised when it is remembered that the steam from a boiler issues into the atmosphere with a velocity that may be fifteen times as great as that of a water jet from the same boiler; this steam may, however, be condensed in five times its weight of water, so that after the distribution of the momentum of the steam jet into the mass of the combined jet a final velocity more than double that of a simple water jet from the boiler is obtained. This high velocity energy is converted into pressure energy more than sufficient to overcome the boiler pressure, by the slight divergence of the combining or delivery cone, which acts as a Bernoulli tube."
Object/Inventory number: "Inv. 1864–65, 19,236."

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: "453."
Object name: "COMPOUND INJECTOR."
Maker/Donor: "Lent by Messrs. Körting Bros.,"
Date of creation: "1885."
Object entry information: "This construction of double injector was patented by Mr. E. Körting in 1873 and 1876. It consists of two slightly different Giffard injectors (see No. 452), arranged in series, so that the first, or lifter, feeds the other, or forcer, which delivers into the boiler. The delivery chambers of both lifter and forcer communicate with the overflow pipe by a three-way starting cock; the latter and the two conical steam valves are manipulated by a single hand-lever. When starting, the lever is moved through a part only of its travel, thus slightly opening the steam valves and at the same time opening both delivery chambers to overflow; the arrangement then readily lifts water by its steam exhauster action. The handle is then moved right over, so as to open fully both steam valves and close completely the overflow, after which the forcing injector feeds into the boiler."
Object/Inventory number: "Inv. 1885–153."

title: Sectioned example of exhaust injector
description: Sectioned example of the original form of the flop nozzle exhaust injector
place: Romiley, Stockport, Greater Manchester, England, United Kingdom

Maker/Donor: Lent by Messrs. Holden & Brooke.
Object entry information:
This is a sectioned example of an injector patented by Messrs. Holden and Brooke in 1884, and is specially constructed and proportioned for working with the exhaust steam from an engine, instead of requiring live steam from the boiler. The principle is the same as that of the ordinary Giffard's injector (see No. 452), but the details are modified to suit the lower pressure of steam employed; the apparatus is, however, even more remarkable than the original form, since by it the exhaust steam forces the feed into the boiler against the full steam pressure.
A large annular conical nozzle is provided for the steam jet in consequence of the great volume of low-pressure steam. In starting, the steam and water escape freely by an opening in the combining tube and through a clack valve to the overflow; when this jet acquires the necessary velocity to enable it to overcome the pressure, the accompanying exhaustive action causes the overflow clack to close. The injector is self-starting, as the overflow automatically opens when feeding ceases.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 457.
Object name: RESTARTING INJECTOR.
Maker/Donor: Lent by Messrs. Gresham and Craven.
Date of creation: 1887.
Object entry information: This is an injector patented by Mr. J. Gresham in 1884–5, in which there is a fixed steam nozzle and no hand-controlled valves, the arrangement being automatic in its starting adjustments. This is accomplished by forming the combining cone as a separate piece free to slide in a bush, so that it acts as a valve of short lift. In starting, the mixed water and steam escape through the overflow until the mixture has acquired a velocity sufficient to enable it to enter the boiler; then the reaction forces the valve upward, thus closing the overflow.
In this construction the cones can be removed for cleaning without breaking any pipe joints, an arrangement introduced by Mr. Gresham in 1877.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1887–126, 19,626.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 458.
Object name: DRAWING OF ONE-MOVEMENT RE-STARTING INJECTOR. (Scale full size.)
Maker/Donor: Presented by Messrs. Holden & Brooke, Ltd.
Date of creation: 1921.
Object entry information: The original injector, in which only one handle was used for starting the injector and regulating the water and steam supply, was patented by Mr. R. G. Brooke in 1890. The example shown is of this type, but embodies several improvements, and, although not compound, can work with comparatively hot feed water.
The control handle is fixed to a spindle, which is free to revolve but is incapable of longitudinal motion within the body of the injector. Near the lower end of the spindle is a quick-threaded screw and at its extremity is a cone valve. The steam nozzle has a sleeve on its nut engaging with the thread on this spindle, and the nozzle and nut are free to slide longitudinally, but not revolve, within the injector casing, a gland being used to prevent steam leakage. The combining cone is fixed and divided near the centre of its length by the main overflow gap. The outlet from the overflow chamber is regulated by an automatic valve. There is also an overflow gap between the combining and delivery cones.
The injector body is made in two parts and can easily be taken down, while provision is made for the lubrication of the chief working parts.
When the starting handle is in the closed position the steam nozzle is screwed up to its highest point so that the cone valve on the spindle closes the entrance to the steam nozzle. As the handle is turned the steam nozzle is forced downwards away from the cone valve and nearer to the combining cone. The effect of this movement is at first gradually to open the steam inlet, while the water has practically free access to the combining cone, and later, while the steam passage remains fully open, the lower end of the steam nozzle approaches so close to the combining cone as to reduce the water inlet area, and thus the water supply can be reduced to about one-half of the full delivery.
The injector is restarting and can be used for lifting. With no lift and steam at 160 lb. per sq. in. it can take feed-water at 115° F. (46° C.), or at 135° F. (56° C.) if the pressure is only 50 lb. per sq. in.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1921–259.
title: Holden and Brooke's patent Exhaust Steam Injector

The effect of this movement is at first gradually to open the steam inlet, while the water has practically free access to the combining cone, and later, while the steam passage remains fully open, the lower end of the steam nozzle approaches so close to the combining cone as to reduce the water inlet area, and thus the water supply can be reduced to about one-half of the full delivery.
The injector is restarting and can be used for lifting. With no lift and steam at 160 lb. per sq. in. it can take feed-water at 115° F. (46° C.), or at 135° F. (56° C.) if the pressure is only 50 lb. per sq. in.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1921–259.
title: Coloured sectional drawing No. O.S. 5773 of Brooke's Patent
description: Coloured sectional drawing No. O.S. 5773 of Brooke's Patent, One-movement Injector

Maker/Donor: [Messrs. Davies & Metcalfe, Ltd.]
Object entry information: [This is a sectioned example of an injector patented in 1908 by Messrs. J. J. C. and R. D. Metcalfe. Owing to the use of two exhaust steam nozzles in series it can deliver against a pressure of 120 lb. per sq. in., instead of only about 75 lb. per sq. in. as in the single jet type (see 455). The exhaust steam from the engine passes into the ejector through a hand-controlled wing valve, after which part of it passes through the central exhaust steam nozzle and part through the annular nozzle surrounding the draft tube. The combining nozzle is of the flap type, arranged to give a very free outlet, and an automatic hinged valve is fitted to the overflow chamber. When the wing valve is opened steam passes into the injector. When the water, which must be under a slight head, is turned on it passes through the injector to the overflow mixing with the exhaust steam and condensing it, thus causing a partial vacuum which draws in more steam. In this way in a short time the velocity of the steam through the two nozzles is sufficient to give the necessary momentum to the water. The condensation of steam and the giving up of its momentum takes place in two stages, thus increasing efficiency and enabling the delivery pressure to reach as high a value as 120 lb. per sq. in. In other respects the injector works like the usual automatic live steam injector. The water supply is regulated by moving the central exhaust nozzle, which can slide longitudinally within the injector body towards the draft tube, thus reducing the annular area through which the water has to pass. This movement is performed by means of an eccentric pin fitting in a slot on the outside of the nozzle and worked by the external water regulator handle. For working the injector when the engine is not running a live steam connection is provided. The main body of the injector is of cast iron, but all nozzles are of gunmetal and can be easily removed.]

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: [460.]
Object name: [DRAWING OF A HOT WATER INJECTOR.]
Maker/Donor: [Messrs. Davies & Metcalfe, Ltd.]
Date of creation: [1921]
Object entry information: [This shows a self-contained injector designed to work on the same principles as No. 459, but has a double steam nozzle, as patented in 1905 by Messrs. J. C. and R. D. Metcalfe, which renders it particularly suitable for use when the feed-water has to be lifted. It can work with feed-water at temperatures up to 140° F. (60° C.). The steam nozzle comprises an outer annular suction jet and an inner forcing jet. A single handle controls the steam inlet to both nozzles through a conical valve. On the same spindle as the conical valve is a cylindrical valve fitting into the end of the forcing nozzle, and preventing the inlet of steam until the valve spindle has moved through a small distance. This arrangement ensures that, when starting, the lifting jet comes into operation before the forcer. The nozzles are so proportioned that suction is always produced in the feed pipe even with the forcing nozzle in action. The arrangement of the overflow chambers and valves is the same as that in No. 459, but owing to the use of a double nozzle, the end of the forcing nozzle projects within the combining nozzle beyond the first overflow gap. On starting or restarting the overflow from the lifting nozzle escapes through the first gap, and the overflow from the forcer through the hinged flap and thence through the pressure controlled overflow valve. This injector will work with steam pressures from 30 to 300 lb. per sq. in.]
Object/Inventory number: [Inv. 1922–107.]

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: [461.]
Object name: [HOT WATER INJECTOR.]
Maker/Donor: [Messrs. Davies & Metcalfe, Ltd.]
Date of creation: [N/A]
Object entry information: [This is a sectioned example of a self-contained live steam injector for stationary boilers which is automatic and self-starting. It is controlled by two handles only and can work with very hot feed-water owing to the use of overflow chambers controlled by a method patented by Messrs. J. C. and R. D. Metcalfe between 1899 and 1907. The steam supply is regulated by a hand-operated screw-down needle valve at the entrance to the steam nozzle. The combining nozzle is surrounded by two overflow chambers, the first communicating with the interior of the nozzles through a fixed annular gap, while the nozzle in the second or main chamber is provided with a short hinged flap, (a device used on earlier injectors, see, for example, No. 455), which gives a very free overflow when required and yet leaves no gap in the nozzle when the injector is feeding. The overflow gap between the combining and pressure nozzles also opens into the second chamber. The first overflow chamber has an ordinary automatic drop valve fitted between it]
Object/Inventory number: [N/A]

title: Drawing of Automatic Restarting Hot Water Injector
description: Drawing of Automatic Restarting Hot Water Injector. Made in Museum from white print (Inv. No.1921-150) supplied by Davies & Metcalfe Ltd., Romiley

Object entry information: and the overflow pipe, while the outlet from the main chamber is controlled by a mushroom valve which normally opens under pressure, but which is arranged to be held shut when the jet enters. This is done by means of a plunger, (working in a cylinder into which water after leaving the pressure cone enters), which acts on the overflow valve by means of a lever pivoted near its centre. A positively acting valve is necessary owing to the high final temperature of the feed-water which may exceed 212° F. (100° C.), which, in turn, means that the overflow pressure will be well above that of the atmosphere. It is found that in the first overflow chamber a partial vacuum is formed and this is utilised to draw in an additional supply of water, thus increasing the delivery and strengthening the jet. The passage communicating with the water supply is provided with a non-return valve to prevent steam being blown back at starting. The injector is constructed of gunmetal and is designed so that all nozzles may be withdrawn from one end of the casing without the use of special tools and appliances. It requires no regulation of steam or water once the water cock has been set for the usual working pressure.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 462.
Object name: CENTRIFUGAL STEAM SEPARATOR AND DRAWING.
Maker/Donor: Lent by J. C. R. Oakes, Esq.
Date of creation: 1888.
Object entry information: This apparatus, patented in 1885 by Messrs. C. V. Boys and H. H. Cunyng-hame, is for intercepting and separating the water held in suspension in steam from ordinary boilers. The wet steam enters the separator through an inlet near the top tangentially to the circle and whirls round with great rapidity, throwing the drops of water against the sides, whence they run to the bottom, while the steam passes out through a central outlet at the top. A glass tube or water-gauge may be fixed at the side to show the level of the accumulated water, which may either be run off through the bottom valve at intervals by hand or be drained by a steam trap. An adjacent drawing shows the internal construction of the separator.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1888–277 and 278.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 463.
Object name: McDOUGALL’S DIRT SEPARATOR.
Maker/Donor: Lent by the Chad-derton Iron Works Co.
Date of creation: 1888.
Object entry information: This is a form of trap for removing from steam any water or solid matter mechanically carried along from the boiler or steam pipes. It consists of a circular vessel, closed with a removable cover, and divided into two chambers by a central diaphragm, which is perforated and covered with a metal gauze screen. The steam enters the vessel tangentially, then passes through the screen and onwards to the engine, the screen intercepting any solid matter, whilst a recess around the screen collects the water and delivers it to a drain pipe.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1888–341.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 464.
Object name: STEAM DRYER.
Maker/Donor: Presented by Messrs. Princeps & Co.
Date of creation: 1914.
Object entry information: This apparatus, known as the “Little Scorcher,” is for removing moisture from steam, and is of the spiral type as patented in 1907–8 by Mr. C. E. Jeffcock and Mr. W. H. Yardley. The steam enters by one branch and meets a screw of three blades each of one complete turn. The steam in striking the blades parts with its water which trickles down the blades of the screw to the lowest point and drops between vertical diaphragms through a perforated grid into a collecting chamber beneath. It is claimed that the steam is not baffled and that the water cannot be carried forward or taken up again by the steam. There are no joints in the apparatus, and it can be made in cast iron or cast steel according to the pressure required. The chamber is drained by a gunmetal asbestos-packed cock or else by a steam trap. The apparatus is made in sizes from 2 in. to 18 in. in diam. The size shown is for a 6 in. diam. pipe.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1914–117.

Yardley. The steam enters by one branch and meets a screw of three blades each of one complete turn. The steam in striking the blades parts with its water which trickles down the blades of the screw to the lowest point and drops between vertical diaphragms through a perforated grid into a collecting chamber beneath. It is claimed that the steam is not baffled and that the water cannot be carried forward or taken up again by the steam. There are no joints in the apparatus, and it can be made in cast iron or cast steel according to the pressure required. The chamber is drained by a gunmetal asbestos-packed cock or else by a steam trap. The apparatus is made in sizes from 2 in. to 18 in. in diam. The size shown is for a 6 in. diam. pipe.

Object entry information: and the overflow pipe, while the outlet from the main chamber is controlled by a mushroom valve which normally opens under pressure, but which is arranged to be held shut when the jet enters. This is done by means of a plunger, (working in a cylinder into which water after leaving the pressure cone enters), which acts on the overflow valve by means of a lever pivoted near its centre. A positively acting valve is necessary owing to the high final temperature of the feed-water which may exceed 212° F. (100° C.), which, in turn, means that the overflow pressure will be well above that of the atmosphere. It is found that in the first overflow chamber a partial vacuum is formed and this is utilised to draw in an additional supply of water, thus increasing the delivery and strengthening the jet. The passage communicating with the water supply is provided with a non-return valve to prevent steam being blown back at starting. The injector is constructed of gunmetal and is designed so that all nozzles may be withdrawn from one end of the casing without the use of special tools and appliances. It requires no regulation of steam or water once the water cock has been set for the usual working pressure.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1921–430.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 462.
Object name: CENTRIFUGAL STEAM SEPARATOR AND DRAWING.
Maker/Donor: Lent by J. C. R. Oakes, Esq.
Date of creation: 1888.
Object entry information: This apparatus, patented in 1885 by Messrs. C. V. Boys and H. H. Cunyng-hame, is for intercepting and separating the water held in suspension in steam from ordinary boilers. The wet steam enters the separator through an inlet near the top tangentially to the circle and whirls round with great rapidity, throwing the drops of water against the sides, whence they run to the bottom, while the steam passes out through a central outlet at the top. A glass tube or water-gauge may be fixed at the side to show the level of the accumulated water, which may either be run off through the bottom valve at intervals by hand or be drained by a steam trap. An adjacent drawing shows the internal construction of the separator.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1888–277 and 278.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 463.
Object name: McDOUGALL’S DIRT SEPARATOR.
Maker/Donor: Lent by the Chad-derton Iron Works Co.
Date of creation: 1888.
Object entry information: This is a form of trap for removing from steam any water or solid matter mechanically carried along from the boiler or steam pipes. It consists of a circular vessel, closed with a removable cover, and divided into two chambers by a central diaphragm, which is perforated and covered with a metal gauze screen. The steam enters the vessel tangentially, then passes through the screen and onwards to the engine, the screen intercepting any solid matter, whilst a recess around the screen collects the water and delivers it to a drain pipe.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1888–341.

Maker/Donor: Lent by J. J. Royle, Esq.
Date of creation: 1887.
Object entry information: This steam trap is constructed so that the mechanism is outside the steam pipe and, not being subjected to the steam pressure, can be readily examined. It was patented in 1882 by Mr. J. J. Royle. The section shown represents a cast-iron cistern closed by a cover, and pro-vided with an inlet on one side and a siphon discharge on the other. The inlet is
Object/Inventory number: N/A

Object entry information: closed by a small valve controlled by a powerful float, so that it can resist the steam pressure. The valve leaks slightly, and so the water drains into the cistern, and thus raises the float. This further opens the valve which then admits more water, and finally a little steam that then forces the accumulated water out of the trap by a siphon pipe. A partition divides the lower portion of the cistern into two parts, and the entering water fills the first portion before reaching the float. A small hole in the cover which allows a slight passage of water to take place, and this is useful in lifting the float after blowing through. There is a small dead-weighted air valve on the cover which allows any accumulated air to escape, but an expansion rod closes it if steam attempts to pass.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 466.
Object name: STEAM TRAP.
Maker/Donor: Presented by Messrs. Lancaster & Tonge, Ltd.
Date of creation: 1921.
Object entry information: The trap shown, which is of the weighted bucket type, was originally patented in 1884 by Mr. H. Lancaster and Mr. R. F. C. Tonge. The example shown is a new design more compact than the old one. The valve at the inlet is a loose disc brought up to its seat by a quick-pitched screw working in the inner valve box owing to its being attached to a float or bucket. There is thus no danger of the valve sticking; in fact, it can act as a safety valve, as any excessive pressure will by virtue of the quick pitch of the screw overcome the resistance of the float. Normally the float is in the lowest position and the valve is full open. After the condensed water has drained through the hollow spindle into the interior of the float, steam follows and drives out the water through the internal pipe. The float, becoming buoyant, rises and closes the valve. The steam inside the float condenses, water from the box flows in through small holes in the float, the latter becomes water-logged and the cycle recommences. To obviate the trouble due to re-evaporation, an adjustable air valve is fitted to the top of the valve-box is provided with a slotted flange to allow of its partial rotation. The trap is made in a number of sizes from 0.375 in. to 3 in. diam. inlet. The example shown is the 0.5 in. diam. size.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1921-612.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 467.
Object name: McDOUGALL’S STEAM TRAP AND DRAWING (full size).
Maker/Donor: Lent by the Chadderton Iron Works Co.
Date of creation: 1888.
Object entry information: This steam trap was patented in 1885 by Messrs. I. S. and J. T. McDougall, and consists of a closed cast-iron box, containing a counter-balanced firebrick float, which controls a horizontal piston valve arranged in the lower portion of the box, and communicating with a drain pipe. The trap is connected with the lower portion of the steam pipe to be drained, and when the water collected in the box reaches a sufficient depth the float lifts and allows some to escape. An external handle is provided for moving the float lever by hand when desired, for testing, without having to open the trap. The attached sectional drawing shows the internal construction.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1888-290 and 291.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 468.
Object name: VAUGHAN’S STEAM TRAP.
Maker/Donor: Received
Date of creation: 1886.
Object entry information: The sectioned example shown is a steam trap for a 3 in. pipe, and consists of a cast-iron vessel fitted with two deflectors by which the steam and its contained water are thrown into the lower portion of the vessel where the water settles by gravity. From the chamber the water escapes by a pipe, communicating with an automatic valve so constructed that it will allow the water to pass but not the steam. This is accomplished by using a horizontal iron pipe carrying at its end a hand-wheel and a stop valve, and having within it a copper pipe which carries the seat of the valve at one end but is rigidly fixed only at the opposite extremity. The valve is slightly withdrawn from its seat so as to let the water escape, but when all the water is exhausted and steam enters the copper pipe the greater expansion of copper (about 50 per cent. more than iron) elongates the internal tube sufficiently to close the valve. After a while the further accumulation of water in the collecting chamber cools the copper tube sufficiently to open the valve again. By opening the valve wide, a complete blow through for scouring purposes can be effected.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1895-57.

Object/Inventory number: N/A

Object entry information:
212 deg. F. This water enters the chamber, and flows out through a pipe attached to the other end. The Bourdon tube is of tempered steel and hermetically sealed, but contains a volatile liquid, the pressure of the vapour from which rises very rapidly with increase of temperature, so that the difference in the vapour pressure at 210 deg. F. and 212 deg. F. is sufficient to give a considerable variation in the span of the tube.
The valve and tube are connected together, and pressed by an external set screw against the reaction of a spring towards the valve seat, so that the adjustment can be accurately made. When cool the valve is fully open, so that the steam pipe is drained on starting; the valve remains open until steam enters the trap and causes the Bourdon tube to lengthen so as to completely close the valve, which remains closed until the temperature falls below 212 deg. F.
Unless the discharge from the trap is to be at a higher level the apparatus is free from internal pressure.

The valve and tube are connected together, and pressed by an external set screw against the reaction of a spring towards the valve seat, so that the adjustment can be accurately made. When cool the valve is fully open, so that the steam pipe is drained on starting; the valve remains open until steam enters the trap and causes the Bourdon tube to lengthen so as to completely close the valve, which remains closed until the temperature falls below 212 deg. F.
Unless the discharge from the trap is to be at a higher level the apparatus is free from internal pressure.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1896-118.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 470.
Object name: STEAM TRAP.
Maker/Donor: Presented by Messrs. Geipel & Lange,
Date of creation: 1906.
Object entry information: This steam trap, patented in 1893 by Mr. W. Geipel, depends for its action upon the difference in the coefficients of expansion of brass and iron. In the body of the trap are situated two tubes arranged to form two sides of an isosceles triangle; at the apex is situated the valve, whilst the third side is the distance between the ends of the tubes. These ends are fixed in the body of the trap whilst the apex of the triangle is free to move. One end of a spring-controlled lever presses against the valve spindle, which, together with the valve and its seat, is free to move when caused to do so by the expansion of the tubes. The valve is open when the trap is cool, free communication being then established between the steam inlet pipe (brass) and the water outlet (iron). When in use, steam in the brass pipe causes it to expand more than the iron pipe, and the vertex of the triangle, which is practically the valve and its seat, moves, and closes the valves. This position continues until sufficient water collects in the steam pipe to cool it, when its contraction again opens the valve and the water is automatically blown through. Varying pressures of steam are allowed for, as a pressure sufficiently high to cause large movement of the valve would only press the spindle back and compress the spring. The spring is adjusted by means of nuts to keep the valve closed when in use against the normal steam pressure.
This trap may be used in any position, and may be blown through by hand on depressing the lever. The example shown is the smallest size made and has a discharge capacity of 250 gal. per hour.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1907-150.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 471.
Object name: STEAM TRAP.
Maker/Donor: Lent by the United Asbestos Co., Ltd.,
Date of creation: 1905.
Object entry information: This is an example of an expansion steam trap patented by Mr. J. E. L. Ogden in 1898, and improved in 1904-5. Its action depends on the expansion and contraction of a tube operating the valve through which the condensed water is discharged.
It consists of a tube of brass, or other metal with a high coefficient of expansion, connected at one end with a valve casing, the other end being secured to a flange attached to the steam piping which it is required to drain. Two iron rods are mounted with their inner ends carried in a collar pivoted on the end flange, and with their outer ends carried, one against the valve casing and the other against the shorter arm of a spring-loaded lever. The lever operating against the steam pressure bears against the discharge valve spindle and keeps the valve closed.
When the trap is cold, it is arranged that the valve is open owing to the pressure of the upper iron rod on the shorter arm of the bellcrank lever. Steam then passes freely through the trap, raising the temperature of the brass tube, which, expanding, relieves the pressure of the iron rod on the lever, and allows the spring to shut the valve. Condensed water then collects in the brass tube, and, as its temperature falls, the tube contracts, thus opening the valve, when the same series of operations recurs. The effect of the expansion of the brass tube is magnified, first by the bellcrank lever having unequal arms, and then it is doubled by having a pair of iron rods and making the collar against which they bear pivot about the end flange on knife edges.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1905-44.

title: Ogden's patent 1898. "Annular" Steam Trap No.140 in gunmetal
description: Ogden's patent 1898. "Annular" Steam Trap No.140 in gunmetal, partly sectioned, for 1/2" diam. pipe

Maker/Donor: Presented by Messrs. William Geipel and Co.
Object entry information: This is a sectioned example of the float type steam trap patented in 1913 by Mr. W. Geipel. In its design particular attention has been directed to preventing the loss of steam commonly met with at the valve and that occasioned by excessive radiating surface; to eliminating levers and pivots and to rendering the valve readily accessible. The float or bucket and the chamber are cylindrical as this gives small area for a given floatation power. The bucket has a central stem, which is guided by wings in a tube, and has at its upper end a pilot valve closing, when the bucket is empty, on a seating free to move on the stem itself; this seating in turn acts as the valve of a larger seating open to the discharge. Thus a large opening is provided when the steam pressure is low, i.e., when steam is first turned on and the condensation is great, or a small opening when the pressure is high. These valves and valve seats are made of nickel and are renewable. To examine the valve, the upper part carrying with it the main valve seating can be unscrewed and in doing so this does not involve breaking a steam joint. To blow through it is only necessary to depress the knob on the top; this pushes the main valve off its seat. The trap shown is stated to be suitable for a discharge of 100 gall. per hour, equivalent to a pipe surface of 500 sq. ft., at a pressure from 10 to 200 lb. The trap is screwed for a 0.75 in. pipe.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 473.
Object name: STEAM TRAP.
Maker/Donor: Lent by The Premier Cooler & Engineering Co., Ltd.
Date of creation: 1921.
Object entry information: This trap, known as the “Unic,” depends for its action on the throttling or labyrinth principle universally used for the gland packing of steam turbines. The working element is a cone of small taper, on the surface of which right and left-handed intersecting helical grooves of either fine or coarse pitch are cut. The cone is placed in a seating next to a chamber into which the condensed water drains, and which is provided with a baffle to throw down impurities. Condensed water fills the chamber and flows through the grooves of the cone to the outlet branch. Steam, however, throttles itself at the intersections of the grooves and is prevented from escaping. The lower part of the first chamber acts as a receptacle for the mud, which can be blown out by opening the by-pass valve. The trap shown, No. 15, is suitable for any pressure up to 240 lb., but is designed for small water capacity only; at 120 lb. pressure its rated capacity is 500 lb. per hour. Its weight is 13 lb. only. For large capacities the trap is made with cones nested one inside another concentrically to as many as five, and in larger sizes 2, 4 or 7 of these nests are arranged in parallel.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1921–549.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 474.
Object name: MODEL OF BOILER CLEANER. (Scale 1:12.)
Maker/Donor: Lent by Messrs. A. Ross, Hotchkiss & Co.
Date of creation: 1906.
Object entry information: This is an arrangement in which the circulation of the water in the boiler is usefully employed in order to remove foreign matter. It was patented in 1883 by Mr. J. F. Hotchkiss and in the model it is shown as applied to a Lancashire boiler, but it may be fitted on any tubular boiler. It consists of a cast iron spherical vessel, placed on the top of the boiler, preferably at the back end, and connected with it by two stand-pipes, both being continued internally. The up-flow pipe ends in a horizontal funnel-shaped mouth, which is so placed that its lower edge is not higher than the low-water level of the boiler. The mouth is directed to the front end of the boiler in order to receive the surface currents of hot water flowing towards it. The return pipe is continued through the boiler shell as far below the level of the funnel mouth as the construction of the boiler will permit, to the bottom of the spherical vessel a blow-off pipe is led to a convenient place for discharging. When the boiler is in use a continuous circulation is set up through the spherical vessel, convection causing the hot water to rise in the funnel-mouthed pipe, and, becoming cooled, to pass through the return pipe to the bottom of the boiler. The impurities in the boiler water driven to the water level by ebullition are carried with the ascending water into the external and comparatively quiet vessel on the top where the sediment is precipitated. This deposition is assisted by a vertical diaphragm or baffle inside the sphere and cast with it, which prevents undue agitation of

An incidental advantage claimed for the apparatus is that circulation in the boiler is greatly assisted, a continual stream of hot water being delivered to the bottom of the boiler. Catalogue number: 475.
Object name: BOILER TUBE BRUSHES.
Maker/Donor: Lent by Messrs. Bromell's Patents Co., Ltd.
Date of creation: 1920.
Object entry information: These are steel brushes, known as the "Simplex," for cleaning soot and scale from the inside of boiler tubes, as patented by Mr. A. G. Bromell in 1906. The bristles are short and of steel wire, with sufficient elasticity to prevent deformation if used only for the size of tube for which they are designed. The tool sets steel pads riveted to the arms, which are of stiff steel united to a rod screwed for attachment to the scraper rod. There are two patterns. No. 1 is adjustable in diameter, the arms being bulged by wing nuts on the central rod; these nuts also protect the bristles on entering the tube. This adjustment allows for wear of the bristles. The brush is suitable for tubes 1.5 in to 2.5 in diam. Pattern No. 2 has arms which are flexible enough to allow of its adjusting itself to inequalities in the tube. This brush is suitable for the same range of tubes as the preceding.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1920–666 and 667.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 476.
Object name: MODEL OF SOOT-BLOWER. (Scale 1: 2.)
Maker/Donor: Lent by The Diamond Blower Co., Ltd.
Date of creation: 1921.
Object entry information: This blower, known as the "Diamond," is for removing the soot from the exterior of tubes and boiler economisers, etc. It consists of a pipe, placed at right angles to, and having a number of jets or nozzles opposite spaces between, the boiler tubes. One end of the tube has a fitting passing through a stuffing-box into a blower head connected with the boiler. This end is toothed externally and engages with a worm wheel. On one end of the spindle of this wheel is a mushroom valve, closing the opening from the boiler, on the other is a collar. The outer end of the jet pipe is supported in a special bearing made to strut between adjacent tubes. The action of turning the worm spindle first screws the valve off its seat, which allows boiler steam to enter; further effort then overcomes the resistance of the jet tube and it moves through a predetermined arc, meanwhile ejecting the steam. On reversing, steam is shut off and the tube is restored to its initial position. The operation occupies only about 1 min. As the jet tube is exposed dry to the furnace gases, it is made of "Pirek" metal, which will stand a temperature of 1,000 deg. C. A print shows the method of operating the blower.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1921–481 and 482.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 477.
Object name: BOILER SCALING TOOL.
Maker/Donor: Lent by The Diamond Blower Co., Ltd.
Date of creation: 1921.
Object entry information: This tool, known as the "Diamond," is for removing the scale deposited on the inside of boiler and economiser tubes. It is really a valveless pneumatic hammer, comprising a short heavy piston with grooved packing reciprocating in a cylinder at right angles to the end of the air supply pipe by which it is manipulated. The piston acts as its own valve and in normal working cushions enough air to prevent it coming to rest in the closed position; if this does happen, however, it can be readily restarted by turning over the supply pipe when the piston drops by its own weight. The exterior of the cylinder is serrated to act as a scraper. The example shown is for a tube 1.5 in diameter.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1921–480.

An air blow-off cock is provided at the top of the vessel. An incidental advantage claimed for the apparatus is that circulation in the boiler is greatly assisted, a continual stream of hot water being delivered to the bottom of the boiler. Further improvements in the apparatus were patented by Mr. A. Ross in 1894, one of the chief of which was the provision of a charging orifice in the spherical vessel. Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 475.
Object name: BOILER TUBE BRUSHES.
Maker/Donor: Lent by Messrs. Bromell's Patents Co., Ltd.
Date of creation: 1920.
Object entry information: These are steel brushes, known as the "Simplex," for cleaning soot and scale from the inside of boiler tubes, as patented by Mr. A. G. Bromell in 1906. The bristles are short and of steel wire, with sufficient elasticity to prevent deformation if used only for the size of tube for which they are designed. The tool sets steel pads riveted to the arms, which are of stiff steel united to a rod screwed for attachment to the scraper rod. There are two patterns. No. 1 is adjustable in diameter, the arms being bulged by wing nuts on the central rod; these nuts also protect the bristles on entering the tube. This adjustment allows for wear of the bristles. The brush is suitable for tubes 1.5 in to 2.5 in diam. Pattern No. 2 has arms which are flexible enough to allow of its adjusting itself to inequalities in the tube. This brush is suitable for the same range of tubes as the preceding.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1920–666 and 667.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 481.
Object name: NON-CONDUCTING COMPOSITIONS.
Maker/Donor: Presented by Messrs. F. Leroy & Co., and Messrs. A. Haacke & Co.
Date of creation: 1887.
Object entry information: Presented by Messrs. F. Leroy & Co., and Messrs. A. Haacke & Co., 1887. These compounds are extensively used for covering cylinders, boilers, and steam pipes, with the object of diminishing the serious loss of heat which takes place when the surfaces are exposed to the atmosphere. The materials employed, in addition to being poor conductors, must be incombustible, and when dry should be hard enough to resist a certain amount of rough usage. They are applied, in the form of a paste, to the hot surface to be protected, and, owing to the introduction of a fibrous ingredient, possess sufficient tenacity to remain in a position without additional support; when dry the surface is smoothed down and finally coated with a thick paint, etc., which prevents subsequent softening should water accidentally fall on it.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1887-132 to 135.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 482.
Object name: HEAT - INSULATING MATERIALS.
Maker/Donor: Lent by Messrs. Newalls Insulation Co., Ltd.
Date of creation: 1921.
Object entry information: Lent by Messrs. Newalls Insulation Co., Ltd., 1921. The transfer of heat which takes place when pipes, etc., under steam or refrigerated, are exposed to the atmosphere can be largely obviated by covering them with non-conducting materials. These must have a certain amount of cohesion particularly where exposed to vibration. There are two general methods of application: in one the material is rendered plastic and built up to the required thickness on the hot surface; in the other, the material is made up into sections and fastened on with bands, etc. The former is cheaper, but the latter has the advantage of being removable for inspection. There are many mixtures of clay, etc., with vegetable fibre that reduce the heat loss about 55 per cent. as compared with the bare steam pipe, but the really suitable materials, with their efficiencies, are:—asbestos composition, 70 per cent.; magnesia composition, 78 per cent.; magnesia sections, 82 per cent.; asbestos composition, 87 per cent.; and cork sections, 88 per cent. Such materials or their like, devised to meet widely different conditions, are shown. Asbestos is represented by plastic composition of two grades in bags, and by corrugated paper material for sectional use. Magnesia, on account of its physical properties and of its high insulation value compared with its cost, is a very widely used material. The plastic form in bags, the plain slab, and the material in mattress form are shown. For pipe flanges, the heat loss from which is serious, sheet metal boxes lined with magnesia are used. Object name: DRAWING OF THE "FIRE MILL" PROPOSED BY AMONTONS.
Maker/Donor: Guillaume Amontons. (Prepared in the Museum, 1897.)
Object entry information: This design was submitted to the French Academy of Sciences in 1699 by Guillaume Amontons. It shows in section a closed cylindrical copper drum, 31.8 ft. diam. by 12.8 ft. wide, divided into twelve compartments by radial partitions, and containing a smaller concentric wooden drum similarly divided. The partitions of the inner drum are fitted with flap valves and are partially filled with water, while a curved copper pipe leads from each of its chambers to a corresponding chamber of the outer wheel. The drum is mounted on a horizontal axle, and on one side is a furnace to heat the air in the chamber nearest to it, so that the resulting increased pressure and volume being transmitted to the lower cell of the inner or water drum will force the water through the clack into the next higher chamber, and so on, thus continually keeping the water at a higher level on one side of this virtual water wheel than it is on the other, and thereby causing the drum to revolve. After the heated air had done its work it was to be cooled by the water in which the lower part of the drum was immersed. Amontons estimated that the above apparatus was to be equivalent to no less than thirty-nine horses, but his determination of the working capability of a horse was about 14,000 foot pounds per minute; this he considered was equal to the effort of six men.

Object name: DRAWING OF THE "FIRE MILL" PROPOSED BY AMONTONS.
Maker/Donor: Guillaume Amontons. (Prepared in the Museum, 1897.)
Date of creation: 1699.
Object entry information: This design was submitted to the French Academy of Sciences in 1699 by Guillaume Amontons. It shows in section a closed cylindrical copper drum, 31.8 ft. diam. by 12.8 ft. wide, divided into twelve compartments by radial partitions, and containing a smaller concentric wooden drum similarly divided. The partitions of the inner drum are fitted with flap valves and are partially filled with water, while a curved copper pipe leads from each of its chambers to a corresponding chamber of the outer wheel. The drum is mounted on a horizontal axle, and on one side is a furnace to heat the air in the chamber nearest to it, so that the resulting increased pressure and volume being transmitted to the lower cell of the inner or water drum will force the water through the clack into the next higher chamber, and so on, thus continually keeping the water at a higher level on one side of this virtual water wheel than it is on the other, and thereby causing the drum to revolve. After the heated air had done its work it was to be cooled by the water in which the lower part of the drum was immersed. Amontons estimated that the above apparatus was to be equivalent to no less than thirty-nine horses, but his determination of the working capability of a horse was about 14,000 foot pounds per minute; this he considered was equal to the effort of six men.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1897–118, 19,605.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 484.
Object name: MODEL OF STIRLING'S HOT-AIR ENGINE.
Maker/Donor: Dr. Robert Stirling.
Date of creation: 1816.
Object entry information: This is a replica in section of the model preserved in the University of Edinburgh, of the hot air engine designed and constructed by Dr. Robert Stirling, in 1816. His design is of interest in that it was an attempt to construct an engine working similarly to the theoretically perfect heat engine in which the cycle of operations is closed, the same mass of air being used throughout. The heat was distributed by means of a “displacer” which moved the mass of air to and fro between the hot and cold portions of the apparatus; Stirling also compressed the air before heating it. He was the first to apply a “regenerator” to absorb and restore alternately some of the heat of the mass of working fluid. In these ways he greatly improved the practical efficiency of this class of motor. In the model the furnace portion, probably coke-heated, is missing as in the original.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1923–419.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 485.
Object name: MODEL OF HOT-AIR ENGINE. (Scale 1: 8.)
Maker/Donor: P. R. Hodge, Esq. (Engine designed by Sir G. Cayley; improvements by Mr. H. Messer.)
Date of creation: 1807.
Object entry information: This engine is of the original type designed by Sir G. Cayley in 1807, in which is employed a closed furnace and two cylinders: a small or cold cylinder, forcing air into and around the furnace, and a larger one into which this heated air is admitted to perform the working strokes, afterwards being discharged into the atmosphere. The model embodies improvements patented by Mr. H. Messer in 1863-4, and has the hot cylinder and the furnace arranged in a rectangular base with the space between them filled with non-conducting material. The furnace itself is a firebrick chamber with a perforated bottom, closed above by a removable charging door. Air from the atmosphere is, by the cold cylinder, pumped into the casing of the furnace, where it is heated, while some of it maintains the combustion of the fuel. The heated air and gases then pass to the hot cylinder, where, on account of their greater volume, they perform much more work than was absorbed in working the air pump, the difference being the available power for overcoming the friction of the engine and doing external work. The cylinders are both single-acting, and are connected with opposite cranks on a shaft above. The admission and exhaust valves of the hot cylinder are of the drop type, and are controlled by cams operated by an eccentric on the crankshaft.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1867–42.
